description:
Great Vietnamese Cuisine!!!  Such a neighborhood gem.  It's a Must-Try if you like Vietnamese food. 

We love coming here with our friends so that we can try all their delicious dishes in one meal...from lollipop chickens to flaming quail to their infamous Dungeness crab garlic noodle.  

Too bad we only had 2 people last night, but we did good - Beef Carpaccio, Lollipop Chicken, Calamari, Chicken & Shrimp Crepe, Garlic Noodle and "Shaken" Beef.  They were so good and service was great (we got seated by the window so we were able to "people watch" as well).
author: SC K.

description:
Owners are from Hong Kong. They worked in a 5-star hotel. They definitely know a thing or two about cooking. 

It is labeled as Vietnamese but the food there has other dishes from Asia. There is something for everyone but not everything is for anyone. Its the family sharing from a plate style of restaurant.

I would come again. 

Bring a friend or a date. Its casual.
author: Brendan M.

description:
A last minute reservation at Le Soleil proved to be a delightful choice for a Saturday evening.

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Reservations are simple to make online, even when the restaurant can be packed on a weekend
+ Good for groups, or small dates
+ Great variety in dishes and courses, so you're bound to find something you like. We went with the shaken beef, garlic crab with noodles, imperial rolls, and endless other things.

The food can add up, but it's well worth it!
author: Claire S.

description:
The beauty of San Francisco is the variety of cuisines available in a 7 x 7 mile radius.  Not only merely by countries or nations, you can find various regional cooking styles whether north, south, east, or west.  With Vietnamese cuisine, the south and north areas specialize in different signature dishes.

My friends who hosted this meal picked this neighborhood gem for a recent weeknight supper.  Being my first time, I deferred to them in composing our meal.  The dining room was about half full as we were seated at a wall table on the left.  Our party of four fit comfortably here but, after our order was placed, the table seemed small given the food that was to come.

Here's what we shared family style:

Appetizers
1.  Green papaya shrimp salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W3bk1ovEVEhuuM2mhAb6ig&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Refreshing and clean, this was a perfect palate opener.  Love the tangy and sweet fish sauce dressing.

2.  Imperial rolls (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0mLUIvtX3JTJsH8VICstmg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Always appreciate chefs who stay true to the cuisine, using the proper wrapper (not Chinese spring roll) to make this.  Always a table favorite.

3.  Crispy calamari (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=E1hfdF_pLCiOBeOfVhyXoA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A non conventional take on fried calamari as this is seasoned with Thai chili sauce and other herbs.  Nice flavor contrast to the first two apps.

Mains
4.  Curry short ribs (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=8k-5WXGICzItTzseiSE3Tg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender and boneless, these were easy to eat and paired well with either the garlic noodles or the claypot rice.  The sauce was rich but note overly so.

5.  Garlic roasted Dungeness crab, whole (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Hb0KDx8ghfUY8J5WzizUmw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Served with garlic noodles, this crab was a solid dish.  The flavors weren't particularly distinct but you can't beat eating fresh crab when in season.  Be ready to lick those fingers.

6.  Caramelized sea bass (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fl0s19_lcgnZksbPO0RhDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Not my favorite but another decent dish.  Don't get me wrong, the fish was fine and paired well with the broccoli but it didn't particularly wow me.

7.  Claypot rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cTbzYy1pdlt9zGrHMaTM3A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - There is certainly no shortage of ingredients in this dish as shown in the picture.  Just wished the rice was a tad more crispy for that clay pot effect.

By the time we finished our meal, the dining room was just about full, seemingly with mostly neighborhood locals.  We asked our waiter to pack the leftovers and, after our gracious hosts paid the bill, tried to walk off dinner along Clement Street.

The food ranks four plus with an extra half star for the efficient service (rounding up to five).
author: Mike C.

description:
I've been to Le Soleil quite a few times now and I enjoy going back because it's quite close to where I live! I get the traditional Pho for lunch or garlic noodles for dinner. Most of the things about the Pho is decent, from the broth to the meat, but the only complaint is the meatballs. They tasted like crab meat - tasteless and spongy... The garlic noodles thankfully not salty! I loved the crispy garlic pieces that they put in the noodles, which added a nice touch. They marinated the noodles just the right amount so that it is flavorful, but not too much! 

Take note that there is a separate lunch and dinner menu. Unfortunately, the dinner menu does not have Pho... but garlic noodles are still a good substitute if you want your carbs! The garlic noodles are in quite small print at the very bottom of the menu, so be sure to pay attention! It may be listed as a side dish, but it is a main course by itself! The waitress was kind enough to point that out to me.
author: Louis Suo L.

description:
Good food and very nice staff. 

My boyfriend was kind of mad at the time and wanted an outside perspective on something that had happened. He asked the waiter and the waiter was nice enough to actually listen and acknowledge his problems. It was really nice of him.

Now onto the food. The imperial rolls were so good and their fish sauce seems to have had sweet chili also in it. It was delicious. I wish I could have a bottle of that for all my food. We also had ordered the five spiced chicken and wow it was moist and the skin was crunchy. I do wish there was more chicken.

I've been coming here occasionally for a long time and the food never disappoints. If you're looking for a little higher end Vietnamese restaurant, this is a good choice to try.
author: Allyson L.

description:
I guess I found my new go to spot for some vietnamese/french influenced eats. I was surprised it was not busy at all on a Friday at 7:20. We were promptly seated as soon as we entered the restaurant. 

As a started, we got soft shell blue crab. It's very rare for us to find any blue crab dish in sf so we got it as soon as we saw it. This was good but the lemon sauce that came with it did not go well with the sweet flavors of the blue crab.

The highlight of the night were the shaken beef and the macadamian crusted lamb chops. The shaken beef was tender and juicy with the right hint of spices. The lamb chop was perfect seared on the edges and when we cut into it, it had the perfect hint of pink. The garlic noodles here were cooked to perfection. It was soft and slippery and was in a generous serving size. 

The biggest con of the night was the laksa. There wasn't anything remotely amazing about it to make it $33. There were only four piece of shrimp, a couple pieces of fishes, mediocre sized tofu, and a bunch of baby octopus fillers. I can't even comprehend how this dish added up to $33.

Service was quick and friendly which was a plus. We got our food in a timely matter and the waiter kept making sure our water was filled.
author: Timothy C.

description:
Ambience is nice, service is good. Overall, I felt the appetizers were better tasting than the main dishes. 
The lotus root salad and green papaya salad were good, but tasted similar. I liked the duck rolls, calamari, beef carpaccio, and would have ordered seconds if we didn't have all the other dishes. Lollipop chicken and shrimp krispies were decent for deep fried food lovers. Garlic noodles and crab fried rice were just enough for side dishes. Thumbs up on oxtail soup, eggplant & tofu, and portobello mushroom. The lamb chops weren't my favorite. The shaken beef was tender.
author: Angelia H.

description: Go to yummy yummy on 12th and Irving. Same tasting food for a reasonable price. Way overpriced.
author: Alden C.

description:
The lobster was amazing!  

Had to special order it in advance cause they go out and purchase a 3 pound lobster just for you!  They said thats the only way chef likes to make it so its not on the menu.  It was amazing though!  Served on a bed of fried rice which was big enough to feed the table.  Everything else that we got on the menu was also amazing!

Lotus Root Salad (5): The appearance of this thing was interesting.  After the first bite though, flavors and textures just exploded!  Just a great combination with bits of beef to contrast the light, sweet, and tangy salad flavors.   

Caramelized Sea Bass (5): As expected, light and melts in your mouth.  Excellent!

Luc Lac Shaken Beef (5): Tender, juicy cubes of beef served with a sort of tangy sauce that contrasts the salty meat well. 

Fried Banana with Coconut Ice Cream (4): Lightly fried bananas with some smooth coconut ice cream.  Simple yet delicious.  

Young Coconut (5): I hesitated on this one.  Just thought it'd be a cut open coconut that you can drink the water from.  Did not expect how amazing this coconut water was!  It was sweeter than expected and had a very refreshing flavor to it.  The coconut meat was also super soft and sweet!  Almost like eating a healthy and natural almond jello.  I'd eat this every day if I could.  

Everything was pretty solid and amazing on this visit.  The food was on point.  The chef even came out and asked us if everything was good and up to our standards (probably cause we special ordered the lobster).  Overall, amazing experience.  Will likely return when we're in the area.  If nothing else than to get that lotus root salad and the young coconut.  Super good!
author: Jeremy L.

description: OMGOODNESS this place is amazing!! Everything we've ever tried here has been on point in flavor, quality and quantity. The servers make you feel like welcomed guests in their home. We highly recommend visiting this gem on Clement.
author: Crystal W.

description:
The whole restaurant was empty except for us... for two hours... on a Wednesday night. Based on the reviews, that was definitely a surprise. Almost felt kinda bad for them :/

We ordered:
- fried rice (with duck!): the duck pieces were small but overall it was a pretty tame dish but generous serving size.
- curry short ribs: really flavorful curry and the meat was extremely tender. Waitress suggested that we get the garlic bread to dip the curry in. It was fine but not necessary. The combination was kinda interesting and I think white rice would have been fine. Serving was also slightly more generous than I expected. 

Overall, definitely not the typical "authentic" Vietnamese place with $10 pho and vermicelli bowls but for the taste and ambiance, I'm a fan. Still kinda surprised at the lack of customers though... almost made me suspicious.
author: Lucy Z.

description: I love this place. Service is always great and the food is even better. It's a family business and you can tell the food is made with love. Whenever I miss my mom I order the beef porridge and it brings me right home. I really hope more people take advantage of this place. It's no frills, just great food.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
very nice restaurant for a group setting!  my friends and i, a party of 12, needed a place for a casual lunch, and one of the gals suggested this restaurant in the heart of inner richmond.  this was a GOOD choice b/c we were able to reserve ahead of time and they had a larger, corner table in the back which was perfect for our group, which included 4 babies/toddlers.

we arrived on a sunday afternoon, around 14.00, and the restaurant was fairly full, but not so full that we had a delay in service.  they had many lunch specials, as well as items to order a la carte.

hubby and i ordered the vegetarian spring rolls ($7) to share...these were rolls of mushroom, cabbage, carrot, celery wrapped inside thin rice paper, cut into 8 bite size pieces.  they came with a small side of sweet soy sauce which made for a tasty appetizer, and great start to our meal.

hubby ordered the lemongrass beef special ($13), which came with bbq beef, pickled carrot, mint, bean sprouts, lettuce and chili over a bed of vermicelli noodles.  he thought this was a tasty lunch plate, with great flavors, but he wasn't quite full after finishing his meal.

i ordered the tofu claypot ($12) which was a hot pot of fresh and fried tofu, mixed with assorted mushrooms, onions, and a bit of thai chili.  for a cool day, this was the perfect dish to order to satisfy my stomach.  i wasn't a fan of the fried tofu, but i loved the slightly silken texture of the fresh tofu and mushrooms.  the broth was amazing, not too salty, with a great blend of asian herbs.

service was quite prompt as we didn't have to wait long to order or have food prepared or receive the bill.  our water glasses were filled without us asking.

there was a single women's restroom, and single men's room in the rear, so i actually had to wait a bit, but it wasn't too bad...least the restrooms were kept clean!

parking was a bit of a challenge, esp since there was a farmer's market right outside the restaurant on sunday, but we lucked out and found something about 3 blocks away.

pretty good restaurant with delicious food and reasonable prices, esp for san francisco!
author: Ellen L.

description: Honestly, this place just has super poor quality meat. It smelled like dog food and it tasted even worse. I literally spit out the pork spring rolls and ordered a vegetarian entree. My BF, who loves meat, isn't picky, and was starving after not eating all day, didn't finish his meal and ordered pizza for when we got home. I wonder where they get their meat from..
author: Melissa C.

description:
Came here on a Saturday with a huge group. the place was full but only because we occupied half of the seating. We had a set dinner and the food was just horrible and it came out to $56 a person!!!

-egg roll was weak and soggy, no meat in there. 
-the beef salad had sushi ginger in there (wtf)
-crab chow mein had the skinniest crab with no goodies in the shell
-beef curry was the only good dish
-fried rice was normal. 

Again all this for $56 a person.... what a rip off. 

Honestly this place is pretentious and has no substance. Fancy sounding name and sky high pricing? You are better off going to that cheapo green pho place down the street on clement.
author: Steven C.

description: Omg this place. Amazing. There are so many things to get, none of them disappoint. I ordered once via Postmates or something similar and once had dinner at the restaurant. Both times the food was equally as fantastic. Garlic noodles are fantastic. Love the apps.
author: Emily M.

description: I can't speak to it's authenticity, but it's definitely not your standard pho spot, you won't even find pho on the menu! The chicken coconut soup was delicious, apparently a watered down version of the Thai one. The catfish soup was equally as good, though I realllly don't like pineapple in my food (no! It does not belong on pizza!). Lemongrass pork was tasty, but take note that rice noodles and rice are extra $2 (which is not tempting for those of us on a low carb diet ). The biggest standout was the shaken beef- oh my it was sooooo good!! It was juicy and tender and flavorful. Unfortunately it was $22 for a plate or else I would've ordered one entire entree for myself!
author: Ke C.

description:
Was recommended this place and it did not disappoint! **Big portions**
+ got the garlic noodles and five spice chicken - both super great
+ we got seated quickly and food didn't take too long
+ definitely order family style and SHARE everything

- wish they had more chicken/veggie options
(Their fried rice has duck)
If u do eat duck, order the fried rice!!
author: Mahima D.

description:
Place - Easy to find. Many tables are inside. Great asian style interior. Love the sit next to window. 

Taste - love garlic noddle. It was simple but great garlic flavor. It is good to eat other plate. I ordered the beef plate to eat with garlic noddle. It was a great combination. Beef plate was also good. It was little salty so good to eat with rice or noddle. It tasted like korean beef, galbi. 

Service and Price - Service was nice and price was little expensive but it worth to pay.
author: Da Won L.

description: The hidden gem of all hidden gems. It's 11 mins of walk from the presidio golf so we came here after some practice at the driving range. The quail is to die for, the clay pot rice is also excellent.
author: Vivien S.

description:
Another New Find Restaurant around my Neighborhood.... no Menu from the outside ..Decided to check it ....

It's a French/Vietnamese restaurant....

They have chilled Saigon Beer .. my First..

Starters good my friend saw the Shrimp Rice Crispy.... it's good......

Entry::Shaken Beef ... I'd come back for this ... 

Macadamia Lamb Chop is good .. wish they have something to dip into .. as it's taste like a pork chop to me without a Dipping sauce ..I dip the lamb chop to my friend Shaken Beef.. it's Good...

Overall It's good place to try ..

Service is good too ....

I'd come back
author: Donovan L.

description:
the most tender shaken beef in this city. period.
ordered home delivery ... first time here... such a pleasant surprise..
thank you Le Soleil team...
author: Rex R.

description: I'm usually all about supporting my chinese-yeeeknam peepo but they REALLY make it hard when common dining etiquettes are crossed.  It was a busy night but the table who came in after us got served the SAME dam thing we ordered BEFORE us.  Annoys the crap out of me.  On top of that, if you love viet food then you'll be pretty upset about the bbq pork spring rolls.  They're PUINY and nothing like what you're expecting.  I figured hey, I'm spending top dollar (9), for some bbq spring rolls that I crave from socal with the crispys and this place might do it....NOPE not even fkin close.  The garlic noodles were ok but a little bitter and bland, shaking beef was good tho...sigh so much disappointment for the overall experience.  You're better off going to Yummy Yummy on irving tbh
author: Vince L.

description: The best in town. The food is amazing, especially the curry crab and the fried bird. It's a MUST EAT FOR SURE!! I also give 5 stars because of the service level. The owner Annie, is super friendly and love to talk. Highly recommended!!
author: Jackie L.

description:
Small restaurant serving classic Vietnamese food with a touch of French influence that lends it sophistication. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable, the décor is understated and comfortable, and the noise level low. This is probably one of the few restaurants on Clement where you can hold a conversation without shouting.  

I've been here a number of times, and the food is consistently well prepared and tasty. My favorites are the imperial rolls, chicken rice, and seafood dishes, including the curry crab, garlic noodles with prawns, and lobster on glutinous rice, which is really outstanding. The beef carpaccio and various glutinous rice/ice cream desserts are also excellent. The menu is extensive and innovative, and the dishes very reasonably priced given the high quality of the food -- $12 for the lunch special and $10-20 for most dishes in general. Some of the seafood dishes are more expensive, but really well executed.

Note that the restaurant is on Clement so parking can be hard to find.
author: Alice L.

description:
Quality, authentic Vietnamese fare done in a slightly swankier, more polished setting than, say, hole-in-the-wall restaurants. That having been said, the prices are still quite reasonable.

Traditional dishes like the bo luc lac (shaken beef) and grilled pork are quite dependable. There are also vegetarian options like the tofu eggplant and curry veggies. But, gosh, the garlic-roasted Dungeness crab? Absolutely delightful, whether the crab itself or the egg noodles that serve as the bed. So deliciously garlicky. Just make sure you use plenty of Listerine afterwards if it's date night.

Service is reasonably quick and efficient, and the restaurant can get quite packed on weekends with a mixture of Asian and non-Asian customers. Worth making the excursion from elsewhere to check out.
author: Vincent L.

description: The food at this Vietnamese/French restaurant is quality and inspired, but getting increasingly fusion (macadamia nut crusted lamb chops) and pricey! So good food, but not the place to go if you're looking for just tasty, authentic, inexpensive Vietnamese food.
author: Will H.

description:
Tuesday lunch specials is a must experience.
This restaurant is usually closed for lunch but recently opened for lunch only on Tuesdays. My favorite dish is the coconut curry chicken noodle soup. Flavor is on point. The chef "Dennis" is amazing. Customer service is on point.
author: Harland C.

description: Went there with our friends last night. We preordered the sticky rice with lobster, one of our favorites. The shaking beef was very good so was the crispy calamari. The lamb chops were not as good as the ones I had before but they are still very tasty.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: Hidden gem in the inner Richmond area of San Francisco. I definitely recommend this place for their Shaken beef, Lamb legs and Laksa. They have the normal higher end Vietnamese food options like Crab, Garlic noodles etc. I really wouldn't classify this place to just be Vietnamese because in terms of flavor there is a twist. Also, how can you call Laksa as a Vietnamese dish?! Lol it definitely is a cushion restaurant and worth giving a shot to dine in. The chef is also nice and goes around the floor and greet customers. Crab and Garlic Noodle might not be the best to try here but it's still ok but definitely not Thanh Long or Crustaeseahn level.
author: Jan R.

description:
I was suprised by the cost of the crap dinner, 3 take out trays came to $220, when my daughter served me i was very angry that the crap leg was not cracked, trying to open the crap with my bare hands is not my idea of enjoyable dinning, at which point, i refused to continue. In all honesty, my five guests all enyoyed the meal, after the crap had been opened by the hammer from my tool draw.
Having alwas found their lunch*s to be very good, with excellent service, and most reasonable prices, this is just a bump on the road. Next time i*ll ask price and condition of the meal, looking forward to preordered lobster.    Gunther d.
author: Gunther D.

description: Great restaurant. Clean. Quality fresh ingredients, great presentation, very skilled chef. We've been coming to this place for the last 15 years. Never been disappointed.
author: Alex K.

description: This very good food for Virginia food,chicken noodle soup is very very good, and Spin rolls too  my children like here to eat
author: Run W.

description: Warm beer, bad service, overpriced and mediocre food. I ordered the house fried rice with chicken instead of duck and the chicken it came with was all dark meat, dry, and chewy. My boyfriend got the five spice chicken which was also all dark meat, very oily, and they charged $2 on top of a $17 entree for rice. Would not come back.
author: Marlee B.

description: I have been to this restaurant a dozen times as I live in the neighborhood. The service is perfect....but it is really all about the food. It is incredible: delicious, fresh, and creative. There are plenty of veggie & fish dishes. I have tried most things on the menu and haven't encounter anything that wasn't fabulous. The price is really reasonable considering the quality of the food. Would recommend Imperial rolls, Spring rolls, Green Papaya Salad, Sizzling Seafood, Halibut...do not miss the garlic noodles and green beans (two different dishes) that are in small type at the bottom: they are great! I have never tried the crab, but it looks AMAZING!
author: Robyn H.

description:
Never had a soup that had pineapple in it but I'm glad it did! Loved their soup because it had a good balance and a lot of different unexpected ingredients in it. I also told them to make it very spicy for me so there were 4 floating red dried chilis on the top. It still wasn't spicy enough so I asked for more spice and they came back with a small dish of freshly cut jalapenos and a selection of 3 sauces including chili garlic, siracha, and some other sauce. That was a very considerate of them and I'm glad they did because a combination of them gave the soup a real kick!
Also had their fried banana dessert which had plenty of ice cream but not enough banana.
We were seated almost immediately on a Saturday night which is pretty good for this strip but this place felt a little bit chaotic and waiters weren't that consistent with checking on us but it was a busy night for the restaurant.
author: Laura Y.

description:
Amazing chicken and shrimp crepe. Came out crispy and full of all the ingredients listed. Comes with lettuce, basil and some shredded carrots. I would come here just for this dish alone. 

I also ordered the crab and tomato noodle soup. It's was good. Definitely made differently from other places. 

I would definitely come back anytime. Lunch time wasn't too busy. Not sure about dinner.
author: Lyman C.

description:
Le Soleil is a gem find! It doesn't look like a Vietnamese restaurant on first look but offers authentic Vietnamese food. A good friend who is selective about food brought me here and I was a happy camper savoring every delectable dish.

The Chicken & Shrimp Crepe was DYNAMITE with coconut egg crepe filled with chicken, shrimp and bean sprouts! The warm Imperial Rolls served with fresh mint, lettuce, vermicelli and pickled veggie was HEALTHY and TASTY! The fresh summer pork roll was DELICATE and SPICY!  

Very authentic, flavorful, high quality ingredients and great service! I wish them much success and hope more people would discover this place.
author: Lis A.

description: Had family dinner here for hubby bday back in November. Sister told us about the quail that was on fire and we wanted to try it. The food came out out pretty good. Everything was really tasty and flavorful. The service on the other hand was ehhh. The staff that were working that night weren't really attentive.. their service wasn't horrible but we all felt a little ignored.. even when we were the biggest group at that time. Will I go back? Hmmmm
author: Jenny X. L.

description:
I went in for an early dinner tonight (around 6 PM) not knowing much about Le Soleil except that I've heard good things about it since I moved to San Francisco. This place is a winner for several reasons: food, ambiance, price, and service.

Since our dinner was rather early, we were the first table in the restaurant. Over the next 90 minutes, Le Soleil filled up with patrons. Clearly this spot is popular among locals. Why wouldn't it be? The food is fantastic. We started off with the imperial rolls (very tasty!) and the chicken & shrimp crepe (also good!). My favorite of the night was the shaken beef. I've ordered this dish at other Vietnamese establishments but I have to say this is the best one I've had. Succulent beef cubes sit over a bed of softened red onions and is served with a lemony sauce. This was a nice accompaniment with the house fried rice (with duck). Finally, the five spice chicken was also satisfying. It was boneless but with the skin on (mhmm!). It was served alongside a fresh slaw of cabbage, onions, carrot, and mint. The only thing that needed some improvement was the lychee iced tea. There was hardly a lychee taste in the beverage. Overall, the flavors were solid and the prices were fair.

Our server was attentive and the others who aided him came by a couple times to check up on us. Lastly, the restaurant is well-kept and is suitable for small or medium-sized groups. Le Soleil is a new favorite on Clement!
author: James Z.

description: Great Vietnamese Fusion restaurant in the Richmond.  The sea bass is fantastic and  garlic crab and garlic noodle are must order.   For lunch, the lemongrass beef over vermecilli with imperial roll is one of the best.
author: Lawrence L.

description: This is more than expected, they offer better meal here at night , with the crab it's delicious! Ask them what they recommend for the day and you would hv a wonderful night!
author: Alice T.

description:
Judging by the appearance of the storefront, I would not have guessed that The Sun, or Le Soleil, does Vietnamese food. The dark, polished, wooden furniture and decorative accents looks more elegant than your typical Vietnamese restaurant. The abacus on the walls were my favorite. 
The prices are also higher than that of a typical Vietnamese restaurant. Both our entrees were around $15. However, the dishes appeared more refined, with a hint of French influence. We just wanted a simple dinner, so we didn't know what to expect.

Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" - wok tossed steak, onions, lemon pepper dipping sauce:
The beef nuggets were juicy, tender, and sweet. The lemon pepper sauce just added a bit of tanginess. It's hard to go wrong with beef & rice.

Five Spice Chicken - grilled chicken, cabbage slaw, chili nuoc mam:
The chicken was tasty and seasoned well. I enjoyed the mildly spicy and sour fish sauce with it. The cabbage slaw added some textural crunch to our meal, since we didn't order any vegetables. 

Now that I'm aware of what this place has to offer, I'd be interested in coming back to try other dishes.
author: Joy W.

description: Delicious, slightly elevated Vietnamese cuisine with a French twist. We had the garlic noodles, some beef dish, and the sea bass, which was perfection in terms of consistency and flavor. Everything was really tasty and the service was excellent. Simple but classy. Good for a date night or family dinner. They have high chairs and were accommodating with my toddler who is a very messy eater.
author: Natasha F.

description: It was fantastic!  Tip for parking, get there at 4:45pm.  The squab was perfect.  The service was great for a busy Saturday night, plates were switched often.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Came across this place during lunch hours while walking through Clement, and it's a cute little restaurant with an elegant atmosphere. I love Vietnamese food, and their French-Vietnamese fusion is interesting and yummy! 

Before serving your actual order, they bring a small soup/chowder that's tangy and flavorful. Not really sure what was in it, but it tasted like tomatoes and a bit of onion. I really wanted to ask for seconds! My mom and I got the lemongrass beef with vermicelli noodles, and a plate of fried tofu with spring rolls. The tofu was perfectly crisp with fried onion on top, and the spring roll was fresh and delicious! There was also a small side of salad. The portions were perfect for me. The lemongrass beef was also tasty, not too fatty. I think the vermicelli noodles were pretty standard, though the egg rolls were great, crunchy and mouthwatering. 

The price range is a bit expensive for what you get, but I'd say that's a given as it's in SF and the place is pretty nice, clean, and fancy. Customer service is also friendly and quick. Check it out if you're in the area and can't choose where to eat!
author: Vivian L.

description: First time there and won't be last .  All the dishes we ordered were delicious and obviously not mass produced .  We love Vietnamese food but this is different.  Perhaps on the pricier side but worth it for a celebration meal .  I was surprised they did not automatically give us rice for three of the entrees but we ended up not needing it as we way over ordered.  Strongly recommend the crab entree .
author: MJ C.

description: Love the food here. We were feeling for something lite and refreshing tonight and decided to try this place out. Love their Papaya Salad and the Lotus Salad. Super refreshing but yet tasty.
author: Jane L.

description: Great quality food and has great standards. The food was delicious. I got the shaken beef , Thai ice tea and imperial rolls. All was amazing! This place is worth coming back to.
author: Russell T.

description:
Had a great time here the other night.  I hadn't eaten here in awhile, wow, it was excellent.  The service was really good, though two of the ladies I was with are Vietnamese.  So no language barrier!!  The atmosphere is really nice, and the food was so nicely presented.

We started with a fabulous papaya salad, crispy scallions, so good.  Next their shrimp spring rolls, with a delicious sauce, next, the coconut soup was perfect, refreshing.  The Vietnamese crepe was one of my favorite dishes there, I have had it before, a must!!  The shaking beef was ok, a little tough but the sauce with the rice shined.  The big star of the night was the roasted crab, wow, great presentation, absolutely delicious.  My only complaint, the need to give you possibly a bib and hand wipes, finger licking good!!

My new go to Vietnamese restaurant on my favorite foodie street in SF.
author: Carole W.

description: One of these places that I come back over and over and over again. Lemon soda was so cool and not super sugary like lemonade. It was just right. But too bad sometimes they're out.
author: Ji R.

description:
This place was great. I like the decor, food was delicious, and service was excellent.

The Chicken Lollipops $9 are a great starter. There were 5 chicken wings accompanied with sriracha aioli. The wings were cooked and seasoned well. It was soo good and great way to start my meal. Next I had the House Fried Rice $13. It was a nice portion for the price. The duck wasn't dry but it was a little tasteless. The fried rice was made perfectly. Although I'm more used to the flavors of King of Thai's Duck Fried Rice, this is a good choice. I also tried the Garlic noodles. It was good, but I feel that it lacked garlic flavor. It tasted more like a chow mein. For sure will return in the future.
author: Benita M.

description:
I hate writing reviews less than 3 stars but the $50 Dungeness crab was definitely not worth the cost and it was very dry. The noodles were plain. The dessert was just ok. On the other hand. The shaking beef was decent and the fresh coconut as well. Maybe we just ordered the wrong thing? 
The service was average. Unfortunately, I won't be making another trip here.
author: Couture A.

description:
Came here for my birthday lunch with my family. we don't usually go to a lot of vietnamese restaurants since we always eat vietnamese food at home. But we just wanted to give this place a try. When you read the name of this place, it doesn't sound like its a vietnamese restaurant. When you come inside, its very clean and modern. It wasn't full when we came in for lunch. 

The workers here are nice but there were only Couple workers who work in the customers: 1 who bring out food only while the other person takes your orders. The person who takes your order sometime bring out your food too. So it'll take them a while to get to you to give you your utensils and menus and as well getting your orders especially if they are busy. They would give lunch menu first if you come in for lunch but we also asked for the dinner menu so we can get more option of picking the foods. After we order most of the dishes come after the other. Some come at reasonable time while some took a longer than others

My family ordered so much food like we were ready to eat for dinner. The foods are in smaller portion. Here are the food that we ordered:
1. Garlic noodle with Dungeness crab (never seen crab on garlic noodle before)
2. Vegetarian brown fried rice
3. Catfish clay pot (this dish was really really sweet so you definitely need to eat with white rice)
4. Imperial egg roll
5. Escargot noodle (this one is soup). Thought it was interesting to see escargot in a noodle soup type. Almost the same color as bun rieu
6. Beef capriccio with shrimp chip: although its raw but it has a sweetness flavor to it
7. Papaya salad (thought it was alright)
8. Curry short ribs (the meats were very tender and curry was good and it was good to eat with rice)
There were so good that we almost eat everything that we order except for the fried rice only had a few bite. By the time the fried rice came out, we were already full but we took it home. Good thing that we didnt get the crepe. We thought we order the crepe but never came and good thing that they never charge for it anyways. May come back next time
author: Julie N.

description:
Excellent service and excellent food!
For starters, we totally enjoyed the duck spring rolls - very subtle flavor, but fresh.
Our second app, flambé of quail, was nothing special though. 
For our entree, we had their special fried rice, deep fried sea bass with brussels sprouts  and boneless short rib.
I always order sea bass and have never had it with a crunch... Super good!
For dessert we had the fried banana with coconut ice cream.
All that plus two glasses of wine do two people - $105.
Before I end, I have to reiterate - excellent service!
author: Cay A.

description:
As I was driving to Le Solei, I joked with my very traditional mother (the one who refuses to eat anything except Vietnamese food) over the phone and told her I was going to eat Vietnamese food made by a European guy. She flipped. "WHY... would you do that? It doesn't even sound good already. You should only eat Vietnamese food made by Vietnamese people" HELLA JUDGING OR WHAT MAMA N. I told her not to be so judgmental because fusion food can be pretty good sometimes. AND IT IS DEFINITELY GOOD! BTW, the chefs were not European. 

Le Solei brings in a modern angle of Vietnamese cuisine paired with French influences. Loved the décor as it consisted of intricate things like the ABACUS on their wall... WHAT? Ahah I thought it was super clever. 

Garlic Roasted Dungeness crab (half crab) $25: Dungeness crab pan fried in browned butter and garlic with egg noodles. The essence of the crab developed the flavors so well coupled with the delicious noodles that were smothered in browned garlic & butter. I actually quite liked this plate. It came with the crab cracker which was great because I already broke my tooth once biting onto a crab, it aint happenin again. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A#sZwYlLrELTJTm5TCQkxGjw

Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" $16:  Wok tossed flank steak over rice (more like over a lettuce and a bowl of rice on the side... BUT...)  served with lemon pepper butter sauce. LEMME TELL YA... this beef was tender like tender could ever be. Like the cow had a full on body massage and acupuncture or something before it became my food. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A#c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A

Fresh Spring Rolls $7: got the pork and shrimp one wrapped with vermicelli and rice paper served with peanut sauce and like some sriracha sauce in the middle? Damn, I died because I cannot handle any type of sauce. But the spring rolls itself were just ok.... not super authentic and not very flavorful as the ones I am used to. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=c7UIg8hi2DEABVpkFnM09A#Y3aSw8ymGAopZ2xPQ-PWeA
 
All in all, as everyone mentioned, and upscale Vietnamese restaurant with some French influences. A bit pricey, but still affordable.
author: Chena N.

description: Love this place ! We have been coming here for years and the food is still delicious . I come specifically for the crab and prawns. The beef was delicious also, but for the price , it's very small. I highly suggest the seafood though ! The portions are great.
author: Dorian M.

description:
If you are from Orange County California and have been to Little Saigon, then you know of a little place called "Brodard" or "Brodard Chateau." Since there's a lot of influence of French cuisine with Vietnamese cuisine and vice, versa, a lot of fancy Vietnamese restaurants provide a crossover between the two and sell pretty good food for a premium.

That's exactly what Le Soleil was and then some. Le Soleil (what a cool name by the way) is a fancy Vietnamese restaurant that has a lot of fancy crossover Viet/French dishes (like stuff with escargot, crab, etc.). I was craving some Vietnamese food and suggested this restaurant to my friend.

We came around 7pm and luckily found parking right away on Clement St. Fortunately, the Richmond area of SF isn't as bad as Sunset and so it's a bit easier to find parking. There wasn't a line and we were seated right away.

It seems like Le Soleil has pretty steep prices for Viet food that I'd otherwise pay very cheaply for. However, the pictures and reviews were good, so maybe this place really is reputable. As recommended, we got the garlic noodles, the chicken/shrimp crepe, and lemongrass beef.

First, the crepe. This "banh xeo" was BOMB.COM. I've had pretty good Viet crepes that my family has made, but this was is definitely up there as the best. It's $14, but eating just one or two is enough to get you full. What makes this one so good is that the ingredients (shrimp, bean sprouts, chicken) are very fresh and you can taste it. Please get this!

Lemongrass beef came out next and I was pretty disappointed. I guess I was expecting too much because for $17, you should be getting a good steal. However, you get a place of beef and salad that can easily be assembled and eaten at another Viet restaurant for about a third of the price. That said, it was still decent and a fine option if you are looking for a beef item.

Lastly, the garlic noodles. This was one of the highest recommended items and for $10, it's not a bad choice. However, it also tasted like you can make this yourself or buy this for a discount somewhere else. It was still good, and so if you are into garlic noodles and don't want to make them, check this one out. 

tl;dr Le Soleil is a very pricy but fancy Vietnamese/French restaurant. There are many good things about the place but be warned about what you may getting yourself into!
author: Bryan W.

description: I love their chicken lollipops. They're lightly battered and salted just right. I travel far just for them. The service rocks and everything else I've had in the menu was tasty, too.
author: Lisa P.

description:
The food is mediocre (but giving 2 star to balance the number of 4 stars)
I got the mushroom, tofu crepe, which first, was weirdly sweet and didn't balance out the inside very well.
Secondly, the salad that came with it was not cut at all so it was very hard squishing these huge leaves in my room.
Third, nothing against the food, but I don't like it when servings are huge. If you do, you should go for sure! Meal was $13 for a huge crepe. I wouldn't have minded it it was half the size.

The service was good though :)
author: Lina H.

description:
We walked yesterday with our little girl to the farmers market on clement street and after that we looked for a quick, yummy place to eat lunch. 
This restaurant is on the same street as the market and we both like vietnamese food so we checked it out. 
First the helped us with the stroller and removed a chair  to park it at the table. 
Also other families with small children enjoyed there lunch here so it's a "children friendly" place. 
We both ordered a "lunch special beef bowl" what comes with a soup and a imperial roll for 12$ per person. You can choose from 3 lunch special options (beef, chicken or tofu), but the also have other normal dishes you can order. 
10 minutes later we had a yummy meal! Everything was fresh and light. Perfect for a healthy lunch :D 
If you go next time to the farmers market ( every Sunday) check out this place. It's worth it!!!
author: Nadine B.

description: Like this place. Had seafood pho and the broth was amazing. Chock full of fish and shrimp.  I am a happy eater. Companion had chicken noodle pho which i tasted. Rich broth and , again, full of goodies.  Traditional fresh lemonade made the meal complete.   Reccomend this place for your pho fix
author: Lamb C.

description:
Braiiinz. 
Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab Braiiinz.

Overall the food was good, nothing was a super stand-out and the Dungeness was kind of just aight all things considered, but the garlic noodles served underneath with crab brains mixed in was the absolute highlight and luckily they don't skimp on that. 

I thought the garlic roasted crab itself was just okay- definitely not one of the meatier crab meals I've had this season, and the flavor wasn't as bold as I was hoping, but for the price it wasn't bad at all. 

Our group of 5 got a few dishes all to share and the meal with drinks and minus tip came out to $25 a person. 

Our dishes:

\\ Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab - Dungeness crab pan fried in browned & garlic with egg noodles. As mentioned the browned & garlic egg noodles with the crab brains were the table favorite, but the crab itself was just alright.

\\ Shrimp Rice Krispies - Shrimp Cakes with water chestnut, sweet rice crust, served with peanut sauce. I'd 100% get these again. 

\\ House Fried Rice - Duck and pineapple stir-fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. Not a huge fan. Was a bit too dry and too salty even for me, a person who would sneak into my grandma's car to lick the salt block she kept in the trunk to weigh down the back half of the car as a child.

\\ Imperial Rolls - Pork, mushroom, carrots, lightly fried, served with fresh vegetables & fish sauce. Again, these were just ok. A little too dry for my tastes. 

\\ Tofu Eggplant - Bean curd, eggplant, bell peppers in soy sauce, served with rice. It was just fine but not a standout dish by any means. 

Drink:
\\ Young Coconut - So freaking good. Served in the coconut, so fresh and only $4. Def helped cure my hangover from the night before.

If I could give 3.5 stars I would, but I can't. Based off the dozen or so specialty whole crab dishes I've had for my first crab season living in the bay area, I have to say that while this crab wasn't bad, it so far has been the least impressive, but the price was reasonable, the place is cute, decor is warm, service was fine, and the bathrooms were immaculate and bigger than my apartment.
author: Candice G.

description: Lunch on Monday and Friday have a special chicken dish, Hainan (similar to white steamed chicken)
author: Elpie K.

description: The service was meh. Expectations were running high and the crab seemed rather bland and the noodles lacking. The papaya salad was tasty tho. I feel a little like the Yelp community let me down on rating this a four star spot.
author: John-paul L.

description:
Wow! Went there for dinner and took the shrimp crepe and hot & sour catfish soup, and the burmese rose petal tea. Crepe was crispy, and the soup was so delicious. I'll be back!Not only the food was excellent, really good portions, but my friend and I got two dishes, two teas for less than $35. Where in the city can you still find this? Well, at Le Soleil! 
The server was super nice too.
author: Caroline V.

description:
Amazing, high quality Vietnamese- fusion food! We came here for lunch on a weekday and it was busy. 

I ordered the tofu lunch special which came with a curry coconut milk soup (reminded me of thai curry), vegetarian spring rolls, and slaw. I also asked for brown rice  instead of white. It was delicious and filling. My partner ordered the catfish 'fish and chips' - the batter was light and not overly heavy. 
We also ordered the lychee iced tea which was good but watered down due to the amount of ice. Next time, I would stick with the hot lychee black tea. The vietnamese iced coffee was solid. 

There were only two servers thus service was not stellar (they forgot our water). I also disagree with the other reviews on here as they seem to be outdated - prices are competitive to the other Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood and even less expensive (pho is $10 and lunch dishes are under $11) considering the quality of food. Definitely give this place a try!
author: Carol W.

description: My husband & I love it here. It's the ambiance, decor, delicious food, and great service.
author: Kate C.

description:
Food:
I tried the fish and chips. This meal is really heavy, which I know fish and chips are, but this one is a bit heavier because the fries aren't just fried, but also have tempura on them. The fish didn't really have much flavor but it was moist and tender. The fries come with a sweet chili sauce on them which made them even yummier.

Service:
Considering we came with a large group of 12 the service was great. They had our table set up for us (we made a reservation) and we all got drinks right away.

Ambiance:
Really nice design inside. It feels upscale without being overdone. It's clean and has a decent bathroom.
author: Susan G.

description: Love this place.. I just have to come at least once a month or I feel as if I'm missing something. The curry crab is my favorite. The list can go on. ( hai nam chicken, squab, beef carpaccio, chicken lollipops)Their service is superior and quality is excellent!!!
author: Blanca W.

description: Ok so this is about their pho. You get 2 choices.  Chicken pho or standard beef with flank, brisket and meatballs. I had the second.  Broth was rich and tasty. Noodles were well cooked but obviously from the dry, rather than fresh. There were mostly rice dishes in the menu and the place was full of customers, which is always a good sign. Service was good. Place is cute and clean.  But this is not your "classic" Vietnamese restaurant.  It leans toward the French culinary history of Vietnam.  Good but go elsewhere if you're looking for more authentic pho.
author: Monica K.

description: My friends and I were craving Vietnamese food so we decided to check out this place.  I tried the mango sticky rice and one of their soups.  I was disappointed when we ordered their fried chicken and we found blood on one of their pieces.  We told our waitress and she was really nice about it and apologized so she brought out a new batch.  The customer service was excellent it was just that chicken incident that made me give them 3 stars other than that it is a great place to dine at.
author: Mikayla M.

description:
Decided to take my family here for Father's day dinner. Restaurant was not full so reservations was not necessary. 

We ordered the following dishes:
-Garlic Crab: You can opt in for a whole crab or just half an order, also comes with a bed of garlic noodles that was tossed with the crab fat. The crab wasn't very meaty but the sauce was tasty. Garlic noodles reminded me of packaged ramen, would've preferred a chubbier noodle. The crab came precracked so it was super easy to open and eat. 4/5
-Curry Veggies: Thai curry with veggies bathing in it. Veggies included potatoes, broccoli, oyster mushroom &  tofu. Super tasty curry that went really well with rice. My sister loved the oyster mushrooms the most. 4/5 
-Imperial rolls: Tasted like your typical imperial rolls, fried really well, crispy on the outside, hot on the inside. 4/5
-Side of shrimp chips: My brother loves shrimp chips, so I ordered some for him and everyone loved it. Pretty tasty if you dip them in the fish sauce but not necessary 4/5
-Seabass: Sea bass on a bed of green beans and broccoli. Pretty tasty, it was my mom and sister's favorite. The fish had a semi crispy exterior and was seasoned really well. 4/5
-Shaking beef: This was my favorite dish, the beef was soooo tender and well seasoned! Meat is more on the medium well side but it was amazingly tender. Really good with rice or on it's own. 5/5
-5 spice chicken: Cooked well where the meat is still juicy but I didn't really care all that much for it. Nothing much to rave about. 3/5
-Lychee black tea: Whoa this was super yummy, not overly sweet and you can really taste the lychee undertone! 5/5


This place was yummy but it's definitely pricier than your typical Vietnamese cuisine. Would definitely come back to try other dishes.
author: Kelly L.

description:
This is one of my favorite Vietnamese spots in the city. I come here at least twice a month. The food here is a little modernized, and fused with different cuisines. 

My favorite thing on the menu is the beef carpaccio. I ALWAYS get this dish whenever I come, it's not even a question. It comes with shrimp chips, which soaks all the flavor when you put the beef on top of it.

My go to entrees are the shaking beef and the sea bass. The shaking beef is really flavorful and tender, but has a little Chinese flavor to it. The sea bass is always cooked to perfection and so are the brussel sprouts that come with it.

For lunch, the basil chicken and the five spice chicken lunch special are the best!

I want to give this five stars, but it is pretty pricey for Vietnamese food. I usually never mind the price as long as it's worth it, but they just raised their prices :(
author: Derek T.

description:
I have to be honest... I'm a bit conflicted about writing this review. Le Soleil is just a five minute walk from our house, and while it's getting harder and harder to get a table in this city without a reservation, we're usually able to walk right in. I have probably been here ten times, and I find it to be a great experience every time. The reason I'm conflicted about writing this review is that I want to praise this place... but I don't want the secret to get out! I like my minimal wait times for delicious food!

I have never had a dish here that isn't good. The wait staff is super friendly, and everything has such a unique flavor that I haven't really seen replicated at other similar restaurants in the bay area. There are lots of good cheap Asian places in the city, and this place isn't cheap... but it's also not super expensive. Dishes are in the $12 to $18 range. They have so many good dishes - I recommend coming here with a group of four and doing family style. With four people, you'll likely get a table pretty quickly, and you'll be able to share a lot of things.

If it's your first visit to the restaurant and you have four people, I would recommend starting with the imperial rolls and shrimp papaya salad. The rolls are fried, but you wrap them in lettuce and dip them in some sauce. The salad is super refreshing. For your main course, make sure to get the shaken beef or grilled pork along with garlic noodles w/ tiger prawns (not on the menu). Then pick something else that sounds good, and that should be a good meal.

There are some places that are good neighborhood spots, and then there are some that you'll go across town for. I think Le Soleil really is pushing into the latter territory.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Dishes that were ordered: papaya salad with shrimp, beef congee, and the whole crab. 

The papaya salad has a nice, clean taste. I do wish, however, there was more of a fish sauce taste. I found the sauce they used to be a bit too sweet for my liking. 

Beef congee was interesting from the norm since it's more of a thinner consistently and uses broken rice! It gave an interesting texture and the flavors were good. 

Whole crab had a decent amount of meat. The garlic noodles reminded me of instant ramen, but I really enjoyed the taste! Especially with the crab insides on top. 

There's no MSG used here, so the flavors might not be as mouth watering as typical Asian cuisine, but you also won't get that MSG hangover after. 

Service was a bit slow since we were seated behind a pillar, so it was hard to get their attention. 

Good option if you're in the area and don't want to endure a long wait on a weekend. They also take open table reservations. 

I'm curious to see how the lunch is!
author: Noelle H.

description:
Today we came here right when they opened. We ordered the usual, imperial rolls, tomato seafood noodle soup and viet ice coffee. We decided to try their shaking beef because others had great review on it. I would say it's totally worth it. I've been to a lot of places that makes it good but this is one of the best ones I've had. I do have to say it's missing a bit of something to go with it. Maybe tomato? I don't know exactly but regardless it tastes soo good with rice.

Everything else is also really delicious. The ice coffee felt too little. It was barely even half a cup once it's done brewing. And that's with Ice!!! I think they need to fill it a bit more. But it is really good. Not too sweet just perfect.

We really enjoy this place and recommend others to come here to try.
author: Kevin L.

description: Excellent lunch special dishes. Tried the beef/noodle dish and the chicken dish. Absolutely delicious. Great flavors. Overall a tad bit sweet but don't know if I'd change anything about that. Great service. Super polite staff even when we came close to closing time for lunch.
author: J P.

description: CAR BROKEN INTO OUTSIDE.  Great food and service, but had my car broken into parked outside.  They broke back window and took bags.
author: Eric F.

description:
Have been a handful of times. Their presentation for some of the dishes was quite surprising. For example, I ordered the quail, and when they presented it to our table, they ignited the quail in a big plume of blue flame, and it slowly crisped on the outside and was very tasty. 
Their portions are fairly sized, and their food is overall decent.
author: Mima G.

description:
This review is based on one dish and the service. I ordered the Chinese Chicken salad which should maybe be called the chinese cabbage salad because there's maybe 9 tiny pieces of shredded chicken. 

I thought the waiter was rude, they were understaffed for lunch and everything took forever. 

Despite this, I would go back because of the other reviews here. Maybe when it's less busy and try a different dish.
author: Emma M.

description:
Le Soleil is a small, upscale Vietnamese restaurant on Clement Street, in Inner Richmond. I've walked by so many times, but with all the other hole in the wall Viet places nearby, I couldn't legitimize coming to what seemed like an inauthentic restaurant. 

Well, I was wrong, because Le Soleil is both upscale, friendly and authentic. 

* Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" - 4.5 STARS ($16): This was delicious, tender, and flavorful. I actually think the serving size is a bit bigger than the bu loc lac at Bodega Bistro, and also more tender.

* Garlic Noodles - 2.5 STARS: This dish, a la carte, is not on the menu. I ordered a side of it, and it came in a huge portion (don't recall the price). The noodles were missing the texture and bite that I really love. I've had much better noodles at PPQ, Perilla, and Thanh Long.

* Beef Porridge Side - 5 STARS ($3.50): Porridge is such a soul warming, home-style food. It's hard to really stand out in the porridge space, Mission Chinese is the only one who has been called out by 7x7. This reminds me a bit of it, because it's rich and soupy, and very un-traditional (beef broth instead of chicken).

Le Soleil is one of my favorite Vietnamese spots in Inner Richmond, despite all the other hole in the wall places here. I think I've discovered my favorite porridge spot, can't wait to return and try the other dishes!
author: Jess C.

description:
Vietnamese food use to be a weekly staple for me. You could find me at Loi's, PPQ Noodle House, or Pho Huynh Hiep (Kevin's Noodle House) getting a nice facial over a hot steaming bowl of pho, face shoveling into a combo rice plate or getting buzzed off Vietnamese iced coffee. 

With age, came my intolerance to MSG and caffeine along with a couple of crow's feet, aching knees, and bladder leakage that will soon be in need of Depends. Not to mention passing out in front of the TV even before the guest list opens up at most clubs. Ohhh if only I can be 21 again. 

Anyhow, back to food talk because who doesn't love taking about food? :)

These days, I rarely if ever eat Vietnamese food because of the MSG. Yes, I know it's a staple in Asian cuisine but my body can no longer tolerate it so it makes it difficult to enjoy most Asian cuisine and the wallet-friendly prices. 

A rarity, Le Soleil serves upscale MSG-FREE Vietnamese cuisine with French influences. If you're looking for pho, please go somewhere else. It's ridiculous to complain that Le Soleil only has one pho option; they're not Pho 99. However, if you're looking to tantalize your taste buds with unique Vietnamese cuisine made with top-notch ingredients then Le Soleil is the place for you. 

The menu is fairly limited at just 22 items for dinner but with you can make special requests ahead of time with Chef Dennis (24-48 hour in advance so he can buy the ingredients) who's a super nice guy. His specialties on the menu includes Flambéed Quail, Caramelized Sea Bass, and Roasted Garlic Dungeness Crab. They also have brown rice. Yay!

We started with the Beef Carpaccio ($8). Sorry, no pic for this app since my phone decided to not share this deliciousness with you and deleted the pic *shakes fist*. The tender slices of filet mignon was lightly dressed in a citrus, mint, and chili concoction and served alongside a basket of freshly fried thick shrimp chips (not that stale, flimsy cheap shit at Chinese restaurants). A real solid starter. 

The Bo Luc Lac: Shaking Beef ($16) came next; spelled "shaken" on the menu. We added an egg on request (+$2) and it came on a sizzling platter which reminded me of Filipino sisig: http://bit.ly/186ePRX. Just when I thought I tasted the best bo luc lac at Bodega Bistro in TL, a bite of the mouth-wateringly buttery bo luc lac made me realized the BEST has been hidden here at Le Soleil. Not a dish I wanted to share, I'll tell you that much. 

All heads turned when the gargantuan Garlic Roasted Crab w/ Egg Noodles ($32) was placed on our table for two: http://bit.ly/18TBgMz. Insanely fresh, the crab was delicately tender and ohh sooo sweet. The bits of garlic infused just enough garlickyness without leaving us with major dragon breath. The innards of the crab was then mixed with the egg noodles for an artery-clogging carb fest. My only gripe was the noodles; it was more mushy and I like my noodles al-dente with a toothsome chew. Perhaps a thicker noodle would have fared better? 

I know people want to know if Le Soleil's crab is as good as PPQ or Thanh Long and there's really no comparison as both PPQ and Thanh Long uses tons of MSG to flavor their signature crab dishes. As I've said, that's like comparing real tits to fake ones. Don't get me wrong, I like fake ones too and I would get a pair to fix my lopsided ones but there's really no comparison.

Because it's not a complete dinner without dessert (especially when dining out), we wanted to order the Tempura Ice Cream but one of the waitresses brought us the Trio of Ice Cream. When we told her we had ordered the Tempura Ice Cream she said they didn't have it. We instead requested the Fried Bananas with Ice Cream ($4.50) which was tempura battered bananas served with coconut ice cream (sorry, no pic). Huh? They had the tempura batter for the bananas but not for the ice cream? This made no sense. 

Aside from this minor blunder, service was very friendly and attentive. A smile goes a long way which most Asian restaurants don't seem to get. But Le Soleil does. All smiles here--thank you!

Along with the atypical Vietnamese fare and good service, Le Soleil has a very contemporary and more upscale ambiance which makes it great for dates. Beware of the terrible parking situation in this area though. 

Everything about Le Soleil seems to warrant almost 5 stars. So why just 4? I asked if Chef Dennis can replicate Brodard's FAMOUS Nem Nuong Cuon in SoCal: http://bit.ly/1g5JNyD and he says he can with advanced notice. Going to hold out on that one extra star until I can meet my beloved crack rolls without travelling 400+ miles. If he can deliver, I will gladly upgrade to 5 stars with a big smooch on the face! I hope he doesn't mind sloppy seconds! I'm kidding....
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Le Soleil serves traditional Vietnamese cuisine in a quant modernized dining room.  All the wait staff wears black and are extremely friendly.  It's a perfect place to dine for a celebratory reason or for just because...

We booked easily online and was seated right away.  The tables are small and we could barely fit all the dishes served up for us for family style dining.  Or maybe we were just little piggies and should be ordering individual dishes instead.  But none the less, we are Asians, that's just how we roll. Banquet family style is more our to our upbringing.  Plus, we are piggies that wanna taste everything!!  

Each dish that came out was delightfully scumcious!  And here we goooo...

5 STARS - SUPER YUM
! - Lotus root beef salad - the lotus was crunchy with bits of marinated beef drizzled with a light tangy flavor
! - Beef carpaccio with shrimp chips - thinly sliced raw beef with a tangy lime sauce topped with a peppery chopped red onions with deep fried shallots.  You're supposed to eat this with the shrimp chip but I prefer to roll a beef up with onions and shallots, then pop it into my mouth.  It's a explosion of yummies in your mouth
! - Portobello Mushrooms with green beans and Brussels - I could had just eaten this dish alone with a bowl of rice and would had been content!  The portobello shrooms soaked up all the flavors of the sauce, it was tender beyond belief and could easily pass as a protein dish.  The green beans and Brussels were cooked with a slight crunchy texture and was so delicious to eat.  Yum!!

4 STARS - GOOD YUM
! - Shanking beef - this was marinated beef with a lemon pepper dipping sauce.  I wish the sauce had more pepper and lemon, it was a bit drowned out for me
! - Garlic crab with noodles - The crab meat was very fresh but it's not my favorite crab dish.  The noodles were good but again, I've had better.
! - Coconut lemon grass chicken soup - the broth was so good but I thought the chicken got in my way.  I love how there were pineapples found in the soup.

2.5 STARS - OKAY
! - BBQ pork spring rolls - it was okay, nothing special

We each had a glass of wine: Merlot, Sauvignon blanc, Pinot noir, Cabernet 

And the owner found out we were celebrating a birthday and he offered us a free dessert of flan with a lite candle.  That was so nice!

All this came out to $131+tip.  For a birthday celebration, this was a decent outcome, as we've spent wayyy more before.  And we were all content and extremely full!

NOTES:  no cocktail drinks available.  Dessert menu was kinda lame, they need to amp that part up.  Parking was not exactly easy.
author: Jenny T.

description: Friendly and warm service, good selection, and quality food! We got pho, Thai tea, and the pork and shrimp spring rolls for lunch and it was so good! Next time I'll try some of the more adventurous (French) soups. They have a good variety of things I've haven't seen before. It's a good French/Vietnamese combo without feeling too far from traditional Vietnamese food. Really liked it!
author: Kristan S.

description:
Sweet. We arrived early - the restaurant was serene. Service was quiet, discreet and perfect for our group. We ordered a few appetizers - the Imperial Rolls were the best. And two salads - the papaya was great. Skip the Chicken Wings Lollipops - great name - fried nothing.
As we left, we made plans to return.
author: Kae D.

description:
My family and I have been eating here for almost 10 years now so the owners, Chef Dennis and Annie, know us by name and personally serve us. While we like the traditional dishes like the shrimp-pork turmeric crepe and the crab-tomato noodle soup (best we've ever had!), we're also big fans of the fusion dishes like the seabass with brussels sprouts, the macadamia lamb chops, the curry short ribs with garlic bread, and the crab with garlic noodles. I like how Vietnamese food usually is served with a side of veggies to balance out the meat and carbs. They also have an extensive drink menu ranging from wines to beer to tea and juice. I love the fresh coconut juice (and eating the coconut flesh), and discovered a tasty beer from Brazil called Xingu black beer here. 

In addition to their regular menu, Dennis would recommend dishes to us that aren't on the menu, and if we're interested next time, we'd special order the dish the day before so that he can shop for the ingredients. It's wonderful to see a chef that loves his craft and gets excited about cooking for us. We've special ordered crab with steamed egg as well as lobster with sticky rice on special occasions since they're pricier (but worth it in quality). They also welcome our feedback so if you prefer a dish a certain way next time, let them know. 

My parents have lived in Vietnam so we can special order more traditional dishes, too, which he'll try to make with the available ingredients. At lunch today, I asked if he can make the cha ca hanoi fish and the bun cha hanoi grilled pork that I saw in Hanoi, he said sure. I believe that the grilled pork will be added to the regular lunch menu soon. I loved the fish which was lightly fried and served with a plate of veggies, rice paper, and anchovy dipping sauce - he advised us on how to properly wrap and eat the dish. I'm not usually a fan of the anchovy sauce but his version was so good that I finished the sauce.

Just make sure both are working that day and ask for the price of your special order so that there aren't any surprises. I've been there when either Dennis or Annie or both weren't working, and the experience and quality definitely declined so I don't recommend visiting then.
author: Diana B.

description:
Second time to this wonderful restaurant and it reminds me of why I love SF. It's Vietnamese fusion and every dish we ordered was delicious. There's certainly some dishes that stand out more than others. 

Appetizers:
Duck spring rolls: very good. Wish there were more pieces to go around. Good amount of duck.
Soft shell crab: very crispy and not to oily, but portion again, was on the small side.
Lolipop chicken: this was really really good. Juicy and tender chicken lightly fried. 
Lotus salad: my favorite salad. Basil, beef, and a tang of sweet and sour. 
Papaya salad: taste similar to the lotus salad but with papaya and shrimp

Entree:
Sea bass: omg this fish melted in my mouth. Crispy on the out side and soft and yummy on the inside. Love it
Shaken beef: this is s must try! The tenderest beef ever! Wish I had a whole pot of this sitting around. 
Lamb chops: this was good but lacked a bit of flavor. Meat was tender but didn't care too much for the messages potatoes.
Five spice chicken: if you are hungry, then look no further than this dish. Very yummy chicken and big portions.
Prawns with garlic noodles: All I can say is WOW when it came out. Huge plate of food and prawns were gigantic. They don't skimp on portion size this time.
Catfish clay pot: good but a bit too sweet for my taste. Maybe at this point, I've had so many good dishes that I was not too impressed.

Overall wonderful experience. Definitely will come back again if I'm in the area.
author: Lisa M.

description:
There's not much more to say other than order the steamed garlic Dungeness crab. It comes with garlic noodles and the most delicious salty brains. 

A vampire would risk his own life for the taste!

Such a gem!
author: Abby S.

description:
Higher end looking Vietnamese Restaurant.

I was hopeful and excited to try the beautifully decorated Le Soleil and looking at everyone's reviews I thought it would be a sure winner.

Le Soleil tries very hard to turn fine Vietnamese cuisine into an upscale dinning experience.

The overall presentation of the dishes are fairly nice, but the Vietnamese flavors misses the mark by a few notches. 

The best thing we had here was the deep fried soft-shell crab. The restaurant does take care of the nicely plated fried goodness.

I had the Lemon grass chicken and honestly it tasted like it was microwaved to me. 

My friend had the pho and it was overall pretty good but lacked a distinct stewed beef broth taste.

I think if you are in a pinch this place is ok to go to, but if you really want tasty Vietnamese food I would try somewhere else.
author: Vince N.

description: The food was very tasty, but the service ruined the experience, very pushy , slow and rude. Overcharged me on the receipt and when I pointed it out, while they corrected it - were very rude, again!
author: Natasha P.

description:
Le Soleil calls its cuisine New Vietnamese, a blend of Vietnamese and French styles. Its small, modern décor location on Clement St. is a perfect backdrop to showcase this Vietnamese fusion cuisine. 

The menu is not a multi-page listing, but one page with selections of appetizers, salads, soups and entrees.  After checking out the menu, we ordered:

Imperial Rolls - the rolls were lightly fried and consisted of pork, mushroom, carrots and served with vermicelli, shredded carrots and dichon and lettuce and mint with fish sauce on the side.  Wrap the roll in lettuce with the condiments and drizzle some fish sauce on it for a delicious appetizer. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw)

Green Papaya Shrimp salad - shrimp, green papaya, carrots, mint, tamarind sauce.  A refreshing salad that has hint of sweetness from the tamarind sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#RJ1Y4cU5b90Yn8N1M_N5tg)

House Fried Rice - duck and pineapple stirred fried with scallions and garlic.   Tasty fried rice with the minced duck.  
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#w9aePtdybcTgWGXxePIenQ)

Curry Short Ribs - braised boneless short ribs in yellow curry with potatoes, carrots and lime leaf served with garlic bread.  This was my favorite dish.  The short ribs were probably lightly fried creating a nice light crust to it. The beef was so tender and tasty with the coconut milk curry sauce.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/le-soleil-san-francisco?select=k9JRJAbcvQN3eebvGxTZsw#hY4bqKQNh1odO2yQWZH02Q)

A nice place on Clement for tasty New Vietnamese cuisine in a nice modern décor with friendly service.
author: Al L.

description:
Sweet place for a contemporary take on Vietnamese cuisine. We came for lunch but ordered from the dinner menu because the dishes were much better.

What to order:
Shaken beef: super tender beef cubes with softened onions

Beef carpaccio: came with yummy shrimp chips.. Was a smaller portion than usual and a bit too minty for my taste but overall good

Portobello Mushroom: on the dinner menu and comes with three mushrooms and green beans in what tasted like an oyster sauce. Tasty. 

Vietnamese ice coffee: standard faire.. If you haven't had it before, Viet coffee always comes with a nice kick and condensed milk ;)

What to think twice about:
Traditional pho - the broth was decent but could have used more of it in the bowl. Decent pho but I believe you can better elsewhere. Go for their more standout dishes! 


Service was nothing outstanding. Our server forgot our order of garlic noodles and seemed kind of grumpy. Really enjoyed the dinner entrees.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Quaint local restaurant. Waiter made good recommendations and was very attentive. The dishes were all tasty and not overpowering. We especially enjoyed the duck spring rolls. Finding Parking is a challenge.
author: Kim Y.

description:
After missing my first opportunity to try the food here with some friends due to unfortunate gastric distress, I found myself here on a lunch date a week later, not realizing that their lunch and dinner service menus were quite different. Fortunately, like many others, they'll still allow you to order off the dinner menu, even at lunch!

We ended up getting their [ http://instagram.com/p/YFCSFeQfhc/ ]:

* Sea Bass - I was a little surprised that the bass came out fried, but, the sweet and savory flavors, balanced out by the bitterness of the brussels sprouts made this my favorite part of the meal.

* Beef Carpaccio - The first time I've had raw beef before (despite being presented with various opportunities in the past), and I'd be lying if I said I didn't enjoy it! Like the sea bass, the predominant flavors were sweet, savory, and, well, tasty.

* Shaken Beef - While enjoyable, it's up against some pretty stiff competition with Newport Seafood's preparation of this dish down in SoCal, and falls a bit short in the tenderness department. But certainly still worth trying!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A large, spacious restaurant with plenty of seating, accessibility should not be a major issue.

Bathroom - The particulars a little fuzzy now, but I do remember theirs being accessible.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Really good food and very affordable.    Definitely recommend it. 
Crispy noodles dish was tasty and the lemongrass beef was delicious.   They also have a great coconut soup.
author: T K.

description:
My uncle took me here for dinner yesterday. When he picked me up he mentioned something about Vietnamese food. Sure why not. Showed up and it was totally not what I expected. Modern decor with dim lighting and spacious design. My uncle knew the owner and just let her decide what to make for us. 

Quail 7 (flamed in rum and comes with lemon citrus dipping sauce) - This is entertaining and delicious. They light the quail in front of you and let the flames add the crunch to the skin. It was pretty good. 

Lotus Root Salad 9 (protein, lotus root, carrots, shallots, basil, cucumber, and fresh fish sauce) - Usually comes with beef, but ours came with pork because my uncle is watching his health. This is probably my favorite dish. It was both hearthy and light/refreshing. 

Mango Sticky Rice 5.5 (fresh mangoes with sweet black sticky rice topped with warm coconut cream) - This was definitely unique. I never had a dessert like this before. 

We also had some off the menu stuff but its just a twist of what they have on their menu so same taste. 

Nice spacious and clean restrooms. One men and one women. 

Overall, it was a nice dining experience. Different. I really enjoy Asian fusion. 

Also the workers here are really nice.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend at 2:40 (they close at 3) and asked the waitress if they could still seat us for lunch (was trying to be considerate because we came in pretty late). She rudely answered "we close at 3" then walked away to tend to other tables without seating us. When we finally got seated, my friend and I quickly decided what we wanted to eat and decided to flag down a waitress (only two were working). The same waitress from before made eye contact with me and I mouthed that we were ready to order.  Right as she was about to walk over, the other waitress handed her something to be delivered to another table. Understandable. But after dropping off that plate, she went around and cleared plates off of several tables, refilled water, and even took the order of another table that came after us. PRIORITIES, lady, priorities. I was pretty hangry by the time she came around to us and just wanted to get this entire experience over with.
