I (finally) ordered the five spice chicken plate, and my friend ordered some sort of soup (forgot the name). I got my dish with a soup on the side which I was initially excited for, but turned out to be a weirdly flavored, sour mess. The skin on the chicken was NOT crispy and the rice was soggy and gross. The only part I liked about my dish was the cabbage salad. Sad. My friend's dish came out literally 10-15 minutes after mine did so we did the "should I eat, should I not eat" dance and I just awkwardly picked at my food. To my surprise, my friend's dish (once it finally came) was actually pretty delicious, so there's that. But it was overall a pretty disappointing experience. 

tl;dr the service was bad and the food mediocre so def would not return. Sorry not sorry.
author: Ara K.

description:
I'm not the biggest fan of Asian fusion places. I prefer my Asian food comfortably low-key, with minimal English and half a menu of items I've never tried. 

But take me somewhere with chunks of sticky rice embedded with nuts and meat, with an immense crab torn limb from limb, happily fried and its brains spilled out to mix with scallions and garlic ... 

..or put a huge bowl of bright red, spicy coconut curry with drowning chunks of duck in front of me that's too large to finish after devouring insane amounts of crab brain, so I get it to-go for the next day's meal but end up eating it over rice a couple hours later because I had a few too many beers...

I've found an asian fusion place I will absolutely be back to.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
My party ended up at Le Soleil by a sheer act of serendipity. We were already seated at B Star next door, but the unpleasant odor of the backroom (plumbing problems?) led us to seek an alternative venue. We were very glad it did. 

This Vietnamese-French fusion restaurant was a delightful surprise that surpassed our expectations. Great service, delicious food, and romantic decor. 

This small restaurant has an intimate feel. We initially thought we were at a Thai restaurant because we saw a Buddha and items such as curries and papaya salad on the menu. The group tried a variety of items and all were delicious. 

The only criticism - the food did not come out together, rather our dishes were staggered one by one. 

Overall, this was a very pleasant experience and I look forward to returning here on a date.
author: Nina M.

description:
On a busy Sunday waiting was less than 10 min for party of 6. Decoration and atmosphere was inviting. Clean place and bathroom is well kept too. Customer service was excellent, staff was very patient and accommodating. One of the guy at our table impatiently asked for a bowl twice because the staff forgot. The staff kept her professionalism and patient even though the guy at our table was being annoying and impatient. 

Highly recommend the curry short ribs. Why? I think the short rib was fried a bit with a crunchy texture and with curry is the best. The fried chicken lollipop is a must try too with a special sauce that comes with. Bill was very reasonable too for 6 adults. I think 7 dishes total. 

If you like coffee try the Vietnamese coffee!
author: rod h.

description: One of the best Vietnamese food I ever had! Nothing too special but very very nice. Casual but calm and costly. Definitely in my favorite restaurant list.
author: Kyoko U.

description: So great for lunch!  Lemongrass beef was delish! Serive was wonderful. Will definitely go back!
author: Jackie R.

description: Great friendly service and really delicious food! Never a long wait. Everything is yummy!
author: Alisa L.

description: First time here... wanted something "brothy"... person suggested the chicken noodle soup. .. absolutely delicious! Great flavor and just the right amount of everything. I will definitely be back to try everything else!
author: Shannan J.

description:
Average ok food.  Had about 10 dishes of which nothing was spectacular.

Garlic noodles, no garlic, no Parmesan.

Imperial rolls had a good crunch but non traditional as they left out pickled daikon/carrots.

Tomato noodle soup - noodles overdone

Rest was mediocre - like T.I. said "...don't want no mediocre, just bad..." dishes in his case.
author: Kevin L.

description: Love the 海南雞飯。The dish comes with ginger chicken broth rice and their unique sauce to dip the chicken.
author: Selina C.

description:
I like the food here a lot although it is a bit pricey.

Imperial Rolls = delicious and must try

Duck Fried Rice is also tasty and worth trying.
author: Dylan T.

description: The food is the best food in SF and their service is  friendly and fast, they treat u like family.
author: Fontine D.

description:
Traditional dishes morphed to modern cuisine!

We enjoyed a 4 course dinner with drinks covering a green papaya salad with shrimp (fairly traditional), shrimp balls done a lá "rice crispies"  -- like a tempura, but with whole rice kernels in.  The beef porridge was dekuc=xe comfort food and the tofu clay pot (tofu native and fried) with 'shrooms was so good we took the leftovers home with the remainders of our small bowl of incredible brown rice.  The brown rice was done almost like a well-prepared quinoa... kernels opened and neither soupy nor dry.

We have put this place on rotation!
author: Bruce B.

description:
Good restaurant for modern Vietnamese fusion food with a nice setting. 

Imperial rolls were delicious but overpriced, garlic noodle crab was also delicious but I wouldn't say their garlic noodles are the traditional kind you find at PPQ. It's more of a soy sauce garlic fried noodle dish. Crab was succulent and tasty even though I'm quickly getting sick of crab. 

I came here for the carpaccio and it was well worth it. The quail set au flambé table side  was cool but forgettable and very small portioned. I think you only get one tiny limp quail.

Overall, it was good and I would return if I was in the area. 

Oh yeah, bathroom was nice. Big plus.
author: Winnie L.

description:
GREAT deal for such a nice place and good food.  Will be back for sure!

Must orders:
Fried chicken wing: A+
Crispy / sweet calamari (secret menu item): A+++
Garlic noodles: A+
Luc Lac Shaken beef: A+
Caramelized seabass: A+
author: Jeff B.

description: Excellent stumble upon when B-Star had a hellacious wait. Good food, great service, and lovely ambience. A must try!
author: Drea L.

description: Lotus salad is so yum, decent price and great asian fusion restaurant.
author: Chloe N.

description:
Pretty good food but a pricier than your typical Vietnamese/Asian cuisine. We ordered: 
-chicken pops: pass. Reminded me of non crispy fried chicken 
-soft shell crab appetizer: not bad with the lemon sauce
-duck rolls: tasty. $9 for "8 pieces" but it's really two tightly rolled spring rolls that they cut up into 8 pieces. Value wise you're better off getting something else 
-oxtail stew: yum! I liked this dish with a side of white rice (they have a brown rice option as well) 
-shaking beef: I liked the size of the beef cubes. Standard dish at most viet restaurants and it comes with a salt/lemon/pepper sauce 
-sea bass: this is also a good dish. Cooked perfectly and great flavor. 

Water is orange infused. Ooh you fancy huh. 

Service was great. They brought the dishes out quickly and was very attentive in keeping our water filled. Bathroom was clean. 

Overall I would say def order oxtail stew and sea bass. I would come back and try their Garlic noodles with half crab ($25 mp today).
author: Elaine L.

description: I was in town visiting SF I ran in to a hidden Asian Fusion restaurant. I was stunned by the taste of the food. We ordered: lollipop chicken, quail, laksa,  imperial roll and spicy chicken coconut soup. The lollipop chicken had a tender juicy inside and the outside was crispy. The quail had a sweet taste and was flambeed baked on your table. The laksa had two jumbo shrimp with deep fried silky soft tofu, I loved the exceptional spicy flavor. The imperial roll does not have your ordinary egg roll wrapping, this restaurant uses rice paper for the wrapping. There was a lot of food on the menu that I wanted to try, such as dungeon crab with garlic noodle and sea bass. The ambience is very comfortable and relaxing, and I would definitely come again when I am in town.
author: Loretta L.

description:
I live right down the street from this cute restaurant and finally went in with my brother one Tuesday afternoon. The place was reasonably busy for a Tuesday and the food people were eating looked delicious. The portions are very large so I recommend sharing. My brother ordered a coconut milk drink that came inside of a coconut. I love small details like that in a restaurant. 

The staff was very friendly and the atmosphere was casual. The inside is very cute and chic as well. 

My brother ordered the Lemon Chicken and I ordered the Pho. The chicken was my favorite. So delicious! The Pho was good but I've had better.  We were full and happy when we left and didn't spend more than 20 dollars altogether. The lunch menu is a bit limited but all the choices look delicious and the ones we got tasted great.
author: Ashley M.

description: Great mix of French/Vietnamese food and decent price too! For starters, I would recommend getting the imperial rolls. It was very light and fresh! The crispy noodles and the beef lunch special with noodles were really on point. I'd definitely come back here again!
author: Jenn L.

description:
If somebody asks me where they can get a good food with affordable price, great ambiance and very nice service, I will definitely recommend them to go to Le Soleil.

I always love their foods. For dinner, I'll recommend you to get their Curry Short Ribs and Sea Bass.

1. Curry Short Ribs (4.5/5)
- I always love the flavor of the curry. I am not a big fan of curry but i love what they serve there. It usually comes with 7 pieces of meat, which is so tender and flavorful. It also comes with garlic bread, but I always change it to rice. I prefer to have it that way, but sometimes they also give me both rice and the garlic bread.

2. Sea Bass
- For those who can't eat curry or what to eat something less sinful. I will recommend them to order the seabass, it is served with brussels sprouts and it so tasty as well.

Others:
I always order their calamari, which taste incredibly great. They said they took it away from their menu because it takes long to cook it, but they will serve it if you ask. It might took a while, but it is worth the wait.

Friday specials : be sure to try their hainan chicken rice, I always go there once in a month to eat their hainan chicken rice.

Lunch Special : their claypot also taste really good but it's only served for lunch time. 

Service: the lady who work there, the chef, well everybody are so friendly, they accommodate my request very well, they even remember that I always want rice instead of garlic bread for my curry short ribs. Every time I go there, I always have a pleasant experience and happy tummy.
author: Ulrica J.

description:
Had a nice dinner here for a friend's birthday! Took them a while to set up our table even though we had reservations - then again, there were 12 of us, most of our party was late, and many of the groups sitting at the tables that would be ours were taking longer than expected.

Still - enjoyed the food, drinks, and service. All the food had great presentation so there were a lot of "ooh's" and "aah's. Also - the water is fantastic! They have a big pitcher in the bar at the back that has orange + lemon slices in it.

MAJOR BONUS POINTS because I forgot my leftovers, came back 20 minutes later after they'd closed, and the chef was so sweet that he made me an entire new dish! And it was a good one - the Luc Lac beef!

* Shrimp Rice Crispies - 4 stars
(Shrimp cakes & water chestnut filling, sweet rice crust, lightly fried. $7)
I really enjoyed this - think of it as a tightly packed shrimp cube, with crispy outer breading (like that dim sum dish), and a nice peanut-y sauce to dip. 

* Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" - 3.5 stars
(wok tossed flank steak, lemon pepper dipping sauce over rice. $16)
Really great quality beef, though a tiny bit overcooked for my taste. It has a great flavor by itself, but once I added the lemon dipping sauce (actually now that I'm reading this off the menu.. I should have dipped as per its name rather than poured it over all the beef) it became agonizingly tart.

* Macadamia Lamb Chops - 4 stars
(cumin & macadamia crusted lamb chops, with brussels sprouts & japanese sweet yam. $15)
All the ingredients just sounded so intriguing in combination and I don't regret ordering this! The lamb was great, just a hint of rareness in the middle of the chop. The brussels sprouts were a little soggy (I like 'em crispy) but still went well with the sweet yam (the purple type).

* House Fried Rice - 4 stars
(duck & pineapple stir fried rice seasoned with scallions and garlic. $11)
Tried a bite - holy cow this was good! The duck was SUPER tender and the pineapple flavor just enough to give this dish a sweetness without overpowering the savory flavors.

* Mango Sticky Rice ($5.50) - 3.5
Oh, this reminds me of those wonderful desserts in China! While all the ingredients were right, the rice wasn't quite sticky enough and was more hard and stale. It's all about that stickiness!

* Tempuraed Coconut Ice Cream ($4.50) - 4.5 stars
"WOW" was the first word out of everyone's lips who tried this. I've had coconut ice cream before but this one was just shockingly intense, in a great way! The tempura = an added awesome bonus.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
An interesting find in the City. Not your typical Vietnamese joint with mainly pho and vermicelli, Le Soleil actually deviates a lot from the traditional Vietnamese foods to more specialty items. 

There's a decent amount of street parking along the entire block which is convenient. The decor of the restaurant is classy without being uptight. We got the Shrimp Rice Krispies for appetizers which didn't have a whole lot of flavor and kinda had a weird texture but was cool to try. For my dinner I got the Caramelized Sea Bass and it was delicious. It was a soy glazed sea bass with a side of brussel sprouts and rice. The sea bass was packed with flavor without being fishy. I would definitely not mind paying Le Soleil another visit
author: Alysha F.

description:
I have long been a fan of PPQ but Le Soleil is a nice alternative.  

What I had:
- Roasted crab - 4/5 - $39 - good and the meat was not dried out. Sometimes PPQ's crab can get this way if you order the spicy or peppercorn crab there. It was roasted with a topping that was egg thinned out with the crab's insides I think. It tasted great but I felt terrible about eating the insides knowing how bad the insides are for you! The crab also seemed smaller than PPQ's, especially when it's crab season, it should be a little bigger. I think our crab was around 1.25-1.5 lbs. 
- Garlic noodles - 3/5 - was under the crab and tasted more like garlic chow mein than the typical garlic noodles I've had before. Still good but just different and nice that it was included in the crab's price.
- Shaking beef - 5/5 - $16 - awesome! But for that price it better be!

The location is a little small but the service was great. I loved the extras that PPQ didn't have like lemon soda, tea soaked finger bowls after crab, and the garlic noodles included in the price. I still like PPQ better, but this is a nice option.
author: Rachelle T.

description: We were in town for a Plough and the Stars session and needed a little something to eat so stopped in here. 8:30pm on a Tuesday night you do not expect to have to wait for a seat but we did. This led us to expect something very good and we were not disappointed. We just had a few appetizers because all we needed was a little something but they were very good (sorry I do not remember what they were) and watching the main courses being delivered made us decide that next time we would bring a bigger appetite. Add to that the fact that prices are quite reasonable particularly for the area.
author: Niall M.

description:
So while there are many items on the menu that sound great, keep your hungry eyes in check because the portions are large. Well, at least we thought so. We were famished and ordered three dishes between the two of us for dinner and we couldn't finish any of the plates. And even though we left quite a bit we were practically bursting out of our pants by the time out check arrived. (that sounded kinda wrong)

Food was standard; slightly on the bland side in my opinion but prefer bland than MSG which they don't use. I'll note my garlic noodles hardly tasted of garlic. 

Service can use some refinement especially keeping watch at the front of the restaurant since it appeared there isn't a dedicated host.
author: Esther A.

description:
I love this wonderful place!  I enjoyed my first visit recently and was very impressed with the gracious service, 'casual/smart' decor, tasty dishes (nice use of spices), the caramelized sea bass with brussels sprouts was so exceptional I had difficulty sharing it with my friend!

I subscribe to the James Beard take on food:  "Good is good".  Le Soleil food and its preparation is wonderful.  Good wine list, too.
author: barbara b.

description: Came here to try the garlic noodles and crab. I ordered the small order and so you get half of the crab. It was messy and hard to eat since you had to break the crab yourself. Overall it was good. Portions seem small in some dishes in my opinion.
author: Christine T.

description:
Great layout and design dinning. Great food and great services. I will visit again. 
My order ( the chicken noodle soup was great!)
author: ZHUOmei w.

description:
Those of you who have lived in the SF Bay Area and through the 1980s/90s will no doubt remember the famous Thanh Long restaurant (which spun its high end counterpart Crustacean) along with a few copycats or competitors offering somewhat similar fare. I cannot speak for Vietnamese expats and how they view this sort of fare, but they have taken some traditional and not so traditional receipes, and figured out a way to make the best use of local/American ingredients and made it into their signature dish (garlic butter roasted Dungeness crab). It's easy to say on one hand that it's Vietnamese style moo shoo poo poo doo doo...but it's not cheap for one thing!

Chinese American MSPPDD is cheap, and frankly even PF Chang's is not expensive like MY China or Koi Palace in comparison. The bottom line is, does it taste good, and what kind of clientele does it attract? WTF, did I just abbreviate moo shoo poo poo doo doo MSPPDD like Xiao long bao (XLB)??

With Le Soleil, while the style and approach can be argued to be similar to that of Thanh Long, there is a bit of a Chinese influence in a good number of the dishes. And that is because of the executive chef Dennis Wong, who is Vietnamese Chinese and who also understands the target demographic.

This restaurant continues to be very popular for a number of reasons. The food might not be authentic Vietnamese or regional specific by any means, but attracts a stready stream of clientele, mostly locals who live in the area (of which a majority are Cantonese speaking Chinese folks). 

With that said this meal was overall enjoyable.

Café sua da - eeeek no bueno. Crustacean and Thanh Long had a much better iced Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk in relation. This one had this whacked up Vanilla latte caramelly like flavor, like a really bad pre-made Lee's Sandwiches (McBanh Mi or Banh Bucks) iced milk coffee.

Young coconut - this was dessert. For those too lazy or don't have the hardware at home to cut it open. Drink the juice then use your ice cream scooping skills to carve out the coconut meat (delish).

Pan fried combination noodle - To be fair even a horrible chain (from the South and East Bay) New Tung Kee had something like this, but obviously this is way better. Vietnamese Chinese approach to HK style pan fried noodles (jeen meen), except the noodles were arranged like a "cake" format, with thicker layers that elevated the toppings (the stir fried combo of broccoli, chicken, shrimp etc). The sauce was a tad too sweet for my liking but otherwise seasoned well. Guessing the sugar is a bit of a crucial component to draw in the masses and is a bit of an unfortunate theme of a number of stir fry dishes here. So instead of asking to "hold the MSG, less salt, less oil" with here it's probably best to ask for "less sugar" in the dishes (unless sauces are pre-seasoned).

Flambe quail - this is actually one of their signature specials. The quail arrives at the table with some sort of flammable alcohol on top, and the watistaff sets it on fire for a pyro show....but don't worry the bird is already marinated and dead so it's not like Rage Against the Machine's first album cover, but is absolutely rockin'. When the fire dies down the bird is at the right temperature to be consumed. The flambé seals in the juices. Now in terms of flavoring the quail has this remarkable cross between a sexcellent soy sauce chicken coupled with the complexity of Cantonese cha siu (bbq) marinade...maybe a tad Lee Kum Kee esque in flavoring. It was like deja vu eating this. $hit, no wonder there were quite a number of Chinese customers in here. Although a tad sweet (my only gripe), this was very tasty.   

Stir fried Portobello mushrooms with Brussels sprouts and string beans - excellent stir fry with a good wok sear. Yet the theme of sugar is a touch strong here, although it provided the needed carmelization. If they could execute this similar to the sambal string beans at Shiok Singaporean Kitchen (more savory and umami), this would work even better.

Roasted crab with garlic noodles - ended up getting half crab, since there was already a lot of food. But those of you who love to whip out the cameras to let them eat first (before others) will know that excess is best...so therefore a whole crab over noodles will look a lot better than a few severed limbs (crab limbs that is). The noodles were like curly ramen....almost but not quite to the thinness of instant noodle ramen packets, yet were still quite tasty. Crab was not in season of course so not as fatty or juicy, but enjoyable.

It is said that the son (Walter Kwok) of one of the founders of Hong Kong commercial real estate conglomerate (Sun Hung Kei properties) dined here, and loved the food so much he was instrumental in helping Dennis open up Le Soleil at Royal Garden Tsim Sa Tsui in HK. Who are you to argue with the tastebuds of a multi zillionaire? If only I had a sponsor like that to write paid food reviews in HK  :-D
author: Ken K.

description:
Le Soleil's website is down and so we looked up their menu on Yelp. We ordered 2 entrees (no rice) and the price on Yelp came to $34, but when we picked it up it was $40 + tax. When I called to adjust the price they told me "better ask for price before you place your order...okay bye bye." 

We live in the neighborhood, but won't be going back as they were non-negotiable on the price and $40 is way too expense for take-out.
author: Hannah R.

description:
Rating: 3.5 stars 

I was craving pho and the place we were going to go was apparently shut down, so my sister suggested Le Soleil. I've always passed by it, but never thought of it as a pho place. Anyways, walked in at around 1PM and we were seated right away. They quickly brought us orange-infused water, which was nice. I don't like orange, but the offering of infused water is cool. It seems like they rotate what they infuse the water with as my sister said she had cucumber water another time. 

The menu is very small and limited at only one page, but they do have pho and bun rieu (although they call it something like tomato and crab noodle soup haha). Drinks are pretty expensive, $3.5-4.5 for stuff like Thai used tea... 

Our server was very cheery and nice, although we didn't get any water refills. 

Now, for the food. 
Pork & Shrimp spring rolls: These were okay, nothing special. Sadly, the peanut sauce was boring and tasted like watered down hoisin sauce... And my sister found a hair in one of the rolls, yikes. 
Traditional Pho: I must say that the broth was very good, it was flavorful and there wasn't oil floating all over. The slices of brisket were very tender and there was a ton of noodles. I dont like beef balls so didn't touch those. The one thing that bothered me was that they didn't chop up the green onions; they just cut up the stalk and threw it in. 
Five Spice Chicken: Sister enjoyed this a lot, and we both really enjoyed the creamy soup that came with it. I had some of the salad on the side and it was good, nice and refreshing. The egg rolls were also good, but I didn't try any of the chicken (not my cup of tea). 
Lemongrass Chicken: Sister's boyfriend had this, and it was a huge portion. He didn't like that the rice was buried underneath everything. Didn't try this, but it is spicy according to my sister so if you don't like spicy... 

Overall, not bad but maybe a little overpriced, but I guess you're paying to eat in nicer conditions than the usual pho place haha
author: Doris K.

description:
I found this place purely by using Yelp and I hope my review convinces you to come too. Le Soleil is a Vietnamese-French fusion restaurant that manages to be classy but not snobby. It's located in a quiet neighborhood in Richmond and the interior atmosphere is quite relaxing and modern as well. 

We arrived around 5:30 or 5:45 and the restaurant was almost empty. More people started coming in after 6:30 but it never felt crowded or noisy. Our waiters were very attentive in refilling our glasses (lemon- and apple-infused water) and changing our plates. But the food was the best part:

Beef Carpaccio -- Appetizer of thinly sliced rare filet mignon. It was my first time having raw beef and the meat melted in my mouth like fresh sashimi. Yum. The side notes of mint, onion, and roasted garlic were satisfying as well.

Green Papaya Salad -- This might have tasted better if it wasn't served right after the Beef Carpaccio, since it had the same mint-onion taste. The green papaya is in shreds and reminded me of turnip salad. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd order it again when I return (because I will return).

Quail -- Mmmm. The quail is already cooked when it arrives, but the waiter torches it at the table for good measure and good show. The four of us shared one quail, which was sweet and tender to perfection.

Caramelized Sea Bass -- Perhaps my perfect dish of the night. The texture and taste couldn't have been more satisfying and the brussel sprouts underneath were some of the yummiest I've had.

Dungeness Crab and Garlic Noodles -- I'm not a big fan of garlic noodles but these were delectable. I especially loved the crab, which was drizzled over with the contents of the crab shell (I'm Chinese and my family loves eating that). 

Turmeric Crepe -- I'm not a big fan of the fried taste so this wasn't my favorite dish, but it was also carefully prepared with carrots and greens on the side.

Tofu Eggplant -- Yummy, good with rice (rice texture was great too), and pretty reminiscent of Chinese food in flavor. 

My overall impression of Le Soleil was that each and every detail is carefully attended to. Not only was the food delicately prepared, but the bathroom was very clean and elegantly decorated, and the bill came in a bamboo cup instead of the usual tray or leather book. The meal was a little pricey, at $24 per person, but maybe that's just because we kept ordering more to try the menu. We got what we paid for, though. I'm so glad we live close to San Francisco because we are coming back here for sure.
author: Laura C.

description:
solid food and decent.service..
i think.dinner is better...order the shaken beef...shrimp garlic noodles...papaya salad...seabass..all pretty good
however I order the five spice chicken for lunch...chicken was very very blend...was it the chef or this dish is just bad? I dont know, but I will.be back for their dinner!
author: Jessie L.

description:
I came for my birthday. We've lived in the Richmond for a long time without having tried this place. I would rather just go to a normal Viet restaurant and pay a bit less for about the same quality food but it's nice that they are trying to do it just a TAD different in this area.


Long story short, we shared a few dishes between us but nothing really stood out (even the garlic noodle w/ crab and I am usually a crazy fanatic for it!!) It just wasn't garlicky enough and the crab didn't seem fresh so it didn't add anything to the dish.

I'm down for Americanized Vietnamese food if something was spectacular about it, but neh.
author: Emily C.

description:
Great place, bit pricey more usual than average (about 18-20 per dish depending on what you get) as the prices rose, but do try the curry short ribs. Its a weird in a good way mix of crunchy and tenderness.
All their dishes are pretty good so try those too.

But try the curry short ribs first
author: Chris C.

description:
This place is excellent. Service is great and food is wonderful!

I ordered the coconut drink to start. My boyfriend and I ordered the luc lac (small portion but flavors were amazing, would come back just for this), the fried rice and the Dungeness crab garlic noodles (good but not amazing).

Overall a great dining experience. I would come back just for the luc lac!
author: Siv L.

description: It is My first time here; family dinner for 7 every dishes that was serve to us are superve in taste and appearance, service is excellent dont need to ask the waiter for stuff they alway anticipate things that you need. The ambiance is great not too noisy architectural design of the place it self is amazing definitely i will come back to this place and recommend it to other friends and family. All in all I will give this place 5 star on every category
author: Allan A.

description: Food was excellent, even on a holiday (Mother's Day).  Service was attentive, as water glasses were constantly refilled.  Food came out at a nice pace.  Annie came by at the end of the meal.  Wow, she has been in business for 24 years!  Congrats!  I will continue to come back for the Vietnamese/French influenced food.
author: Robert K.

description: As far as Vietnamese food goes this is one of my favorite spots. A nice diversion from the typical Clement street joint.
author: Justin S.

description:
I'm addicted to Le Soleil. The relaxed yet romantic and sophisticated atmosphere...the traditional flavors...a menu with the right mix of authentic cuisines and bits of fusion flare...the wonderful staff and charismatic chef...

...the yelp checkin vegetarian spring rolls deal
...the Banh Xeo (crepe)
...the Goi Du Du (papaya salad)
...the Chau Bo (beef porridge -- yes, porridge and very worth it. The best I've ever had at a restaurant. I've never seen it made this way anywhere. Just the way my mom makes it at home.)
...Goi Cuon (fresh spring rolls with pork and shrimp) is what got me hooked the first time. Presentation is pretty! That is definitely a first for vietnamese spring rolls, ever. Plus they use the right amouny of each ingredient and carefully construct each roll to create the "perfect bites". Reminiscent of how good sushi rolls are rolled. Five stars just for this. I could eat Le Soleil's goi cuon every day.
author: Cat T.

description:
Le Soleil is located right next to B Star, which often gets more of the hype given the Burmese food craze. Do not let that fool you. This is truly a hidden gem!

We came here on a Thursday evening at around 615pm with no wait time. We ordered the following:

-Lotus Root Salad: 5/5 OMG, please do me a favor and order this. It's baby lotus root shoots (not like the huge Chinese purpley kind) with super flavorful and tender marinated beef and bean sprouts. The showstopper of the entire night IMO. My close friends all know I don't like eating salad, so if I'm raving about the salad, just get it.

-Garlic Dungeness crab with garlic noodles: 4.5/5
A close second to the lotus root salad. Extremely tasty and loved how there were chunks of crab in the garlic noodles themselves. Ugh. Drooling just thinking about it as I write this review. Compared to PPQ Dungeness Crab, I think the noodles here are wayyy better. Also, you can get the crab half or whole - we got half (3 people, but we also ordered other stuff). The reason for the 0.5 points docked off was that the crab portion was way smaller than I had expected. Or maybe I just eat a lot? Noted: I'll get (at least) a whole crab next time. Anyways...

-Duck roasted house special fried rice: 4/5 so addicting, with large pieces of roast duck and pineapple in the rice. The reason for the -1 pt: don't get me wrong, this was super super super tasty, and maybe my food standards are way too high, but it wasn't mind blowing. Don't let my comment fool you though, it was still extremely tasty and would order again.

-Sizzling seafood: 3.5/5 large portions of fish and big prawns. My issue with the dish was that the calamari was definitely on the rubbery side. Otherwise, the rest of the seafood was overall solid. 

-Mango with black sticky rice and coconut cream: 4/5 I love Asian desserts and this is no exception. The coconut cream and sticky rice were executed to a perfect consistency: light, flavorful, chewy but not soggy. 

***TIP: this place also surprisingly has really good teas. If you like fragrant teas, try the Blooming Tea next time.
author: Lena R.

description: Annie, the owner is very nice. She takes time to greet every customers personally. She asked us for our food preferences and recommended multiple popular dishes for us. Love their lotus salad!
author: Wing L.

description: Definitely worth an evening in the city.  The garlic crab was much better than Than Long/Crustacean, and the sizzling seafood platter was wonderful.  Could have been spicer, but the flavor was spot on.  Get the carpacio, it's a great way to start out.
author: Ryan P.

description:
I love coming to this place with my husband and friends.  I've never had a bad meal.  The food is great and so is the service.  We never make reservations and so far it's worked out for us.  

Favorites: Things you have to try 
Shrimp Rice Krispies
Chilean Caramelized Sea Bass with Brussel Sprouts 
and ask about the Fried Crab or Lobster.  You won't regret it.
author: Lexie S.

description:
Decent Vietnamese food.  I do not understand why it is so empty during lunch hour. Personally I prefer Vietnamese food to greasy American Thai/ Burmese/Chinese.  
We ordered Fresh Veggie spring roll, which was very good, with cabbage instead of rice noodles and tofu, the dipping sauce was very tasty as well.
The pork and shrimp fresh roll was ok.  Banh Mi with BBQ pork was good,with good texture and flavor, comes with salad. My Vietnamese crepe was above average.
The service was efficient and friendly.  All in all, $50, not cheap for Vietnamese but we did order a lot.
author: Yi Z.

description:
My fiancé's parents took me to this restaurant because is one if their favorites in the city and I loved it. Everything I ate was delicious! I specially loved the garlic noodles with crab, it was so tasty and the crab perfectly cook. My other favorite dishes were the quail and the sea bass.
The service was very good, I like that they bring each dish at a time, not all together, so you can enjoy each of them.
 The restaurant has a very relaxed atmosphere.
author: Ana O.

description: So delicious , will come again , Flaming quails . Steamed clams .lobster with sticky rice. Shaken beef. Curry crab with garlic breads, the best flaming quails I ever had!
author: Kaiya X.

description:
Haven't been here in a LONG time, came in for a plesant lunch with my husband.  

Ordered: Bun Xeo - 7 of 10, was nice and crunchy with a lot of veggies, but I wasn't fond of the coconut flavor.  Thats just my personal choice.  My mom never made it that way, maybe cuz she was lazy?

Claypot rice - 7 of 10, tastes great with the hot sauce provided.  Seemed like a small portion, but I eat a lot so maybe it was me?

Bun Bo Lac (shaking beef)  - EH.  I'd say 5 of 10.  Not much to write about. 

Customer service was great, very attentive.  Will be back for more num num.
author: Alice E.

description:
This is one of our go-to spots after church since they're usually not that busy and can accommodate big groups.  I love their lunch special. It comes with soup which is nice and brothy.  I usually get the beef meal but since i'm trying to live a healthy lifestyle, I asked them if they can substitute the rice with some kind of salad.  Yes they did! No questions asked.  Their salad was yummy too!  Their five-spice chicken is also good.

Service is good. It's a clean place.  Quality of food is great.  I would definitely try their dinner menu.
author: Claire J.

description: One of the best vietnamese place i've tried around the but sooo expensive!!! Like 100$ for 2 for one main dish and one dessert each!
author: Morgane M.

description: The food is good, it's a Vietnamese/French fusion. Prices are not bad. The service is friendly. I recommend it.
author: Maria L.

description:
4.5 stars...until i try their crab (they were out the other night)

This place is right across from Chapeau on Clement Street. I wanted to try it months ago but never had a chance to. 
What a fantastic place, I love everything on their menu. We had:

Lotus Root Salad =)
Beef Carpaccio, can't get enough of it all over the crispy chip...
Grilled Chicken (perfectly crispy)
BBQ Pork Spring rolls (YUUUUUM)
SeaBass....my mouth is watering just typing it out...
Garlic noodle (not the usual greasy kind...it's got more texture...)
Shaken Beef
Washed it all down with Coconut Juice...

I absolutely luv vietnamese cuisine and Le Soleil def delivered, above n beyond my expectation. Really like the simple yet elegant decor...and all the abacus on the wall!

MUST TRY!
author: Vee V.

description: Good food and good service. Highly recommend the whole Dungeness crab curry from the special menu( yes...They do have special menu). The favor is just perfect and it comes with the garlic bread. Three of us finished the whole crab with extra two bowls of rice and garlic bread. Originally we also ordered the clam but the waitress came back said the clam was not fresh so recommend us to take back from the order. Price was acceptable as we were paying $5x (excluding tips n taxes) for one order of spring roll, one crab curry, two bowls of rice.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Food: 3 stars
Service: 3 stars

On every level, this place deserves a "A-OK". I ordered the pork over vermicelli ($9), which was not bad at all. The pho is also "not bad", the spring rolls a little bit bland. Their clay pot rice also lacks flavor (but I've been spoiled by authentic ones) but everything is served piping hot, so that's a plus. The restaurant itself is very clean, and we loved that they serve fresh coconuts ($4).

Come by for a good lunch place to chat over Vietnamese fusion food :-)
author: Maggie G.

description:
MSG MSG!  Despite coming here because other reviews said the didn't use it, they do.

Pho was really small and had lots of chicken skin 

Lots of other places on Clement that are much better
author: Scott L.

description: Food was decent but definitely felt overpriced. This came even more true when we realized they charged us $10 extra to SUBSTITUTE garlic noodles with sticky fried rice. We asked if it was possible beforehand, but they never told us there was an extra charge. They assumed we already knew since sticky rice was not on the menu. We didn't and was surprised that we just paid $39 for a few tiger prawns and some sticky fried rice you can get at dim sum. They also crossed out the 10% or 15% tip calculation on the bill, and highlighted the 18% one. That just felt tricky!
author: Eleventy S.

description:
Came here for lunch with a friend to satisfy a pho craving on a cold SF day! A cute little restaurant - decorated very upscale for the Inner Richmond area.

We came here specifically for the Chicken Pho ($9) - which my friend was raving about. I was skeptical having had "chicken pho" at other restaurants and they are always too bland! Not enough of the spices like regular pho! But this pho was actually very flavorful! My only complaint would be the small amount of chicken - felt they were a little skimpy!

We also ordered Pork and Shrimp Spring Rolls ($6) to share - and were presented with 6 little nubs. I actually really did not like this dish because of the pork - super gamey!!! Even the peanut sauce could not mask it!

I appreciated the fancy plates and decor - all for a very reasonably price. Their pho also tasted very "clean", the noodles were chewy, and they served pretty good portions! Just stay away from the pork spring rolls and you should be good!
author: Eunice K.

description:
This restaurant is right in the heart of Richmond close to all the stores on Clement Street.  Upon entering the restaurant I was shocked to see how beautiful the interior is.  It is elegantly decorated and it has a zen like feel.  I feel comfortable and very relax right away.  

The menu offers many unique dishes.  I was intrigued to see something like Escargot Noodle Soup.  Every dish looks enticing that I want to sample them all.  We ordered a lot for just three people.  We started off with some appetizers.  Shrimp Rice Krispies  and it was served with peanut sauce like many other Vietnamese restaurants but the presentation here is very pretty.  The  Imperial Roll is like no others, it is authentic not a Spring Roll wanna be Imperial Roll. 

We ordered their lunch special  Lemongrass Beef served with Chicken Coconut Soup for $10.  We had the Escargot Noodle Soup, Beef Pho, Roast Duck & Pineapple Fried Rice and Chicken & Shrimp Crispy Noodle.  The food presents well with a touch of fusion look (see photos).  My husband will die for the Imperial Rolls.  I fell in love with the crispy noodle dish.   The food was amazing. It is so good that I'm giving this place 5 stars.   I want to add another star for excellent service if I could give it 6 stars.
author: Anita S.

description: This place is amazing! Great customer service, I recommend their soft shell crab to start. My caramelized sea bass was to die for, it was flaky and melted in my mouth. My party of four also ordered 2 shaken beefs and the lamb chops, all of which are must tries. All of their teas are so aromatic and fancy, I wanted to take the tea leaves to go. Their fried banana, mango & coconut ice cream, and their sticky rice was superb. I seriously felt like I had a satisfying, delicious meal. I understand that their menu changes seasonally so there is always a reason to come back and I will definitely be back to try their lunch!
author: Kawai N.

description: Went here for lunch and really enjoyed it.  They have really great lunch specials as well as a full menu.  Ordered the lemongrass beef and five spice chicken and both were fantastic.  Atmosphere is good, modern/clean.  Will definitely be coming back here.
author: Yasi N.

description:
Overall Impression: The coveted shaken beef has seen it's better days, but a pleasant experience nevertheless.

Cost: Closer to 1 dollar sign than 2 dollar signs as advertised. Hearty soup for two was 7, and shaken beef was 16. 

Taste: Shaken beef is prepared better at Aux Delices, but it is still a good piece of meat.

Customer Service: Not very good. Waitress forgot to take our order. Waiter forgot to get our bill. It was a busy night at the restaurant in their defense.

Ambience/Atmosphere: Good decor, well furnished, and a great date night spot.
author: Kevin T.

description: Delicious garlic noodles and my omnivorous friends love the Shaken Beef.
author: Jenn F.

description:
They've remodeled and are now open!! Yay!! 
My mom loves the Banh Xeo. She saids the ingredients are simple but Le Soleil is on point with the technique! The Banh Xeo comes out crispy everytime!
She also enjoys the eggrolls!!

I like to order the Bun Rieu and Curry Beef Stew!
author: A b.

description:
My favorite dish is the crab garlic noodles. (Whenever I go with family and friends we always order an extra side of the garlic noodles because it's really that yummy!)

We rarely have to wait for a table and the service is one of the best as well!
author: Heidi Q.

description:
My 5 star reviews may be getting out of hand, but this place is awesome! We go on weekends right when they open because Eats is always so packed and my boyfriend hates breakfast food (what.)  I can't get enough of their Chicken Coconut Soup.  The Imperial Rolls are always crispy and the Lemongrass Beef is high quality.  

Went for dinner with friends and it was delicious.  I had the Half Garlic Roasted Crab and almost died.
author: Kristyn K.

description:
Our group of 16 people went to Le Soleil last week as our Vietnamese Food Safari event in search of the best banh xeo in San Francisco.  Although, a few believed they have found it here, I find it to be very good but can not crown it was the best.  We were pleasantly surprise with other Vietnamese dishes there as well, so much so that my friend and I went back last night to try out more dishes.  

Last week was a treat for us, because Martin Yan of Yan Can Cook was also there with his friends.  Martin was nice enough to introduced Le Soleil's chef and posed for pictures with us. Back to the food - the banh xeo we had was quite good. It was crispy and loaded with bean sprouts and mung beans.  I would have liked it to have more pork and shrimp, but maybe my portion of the crepe missed the goodies inside.  I've always said a good banh xeo is only as good as the Vietnamese fish vinegarette (nuoc mam) it is dipped in.  The nuoc mam was near perfect and tasty.  We ordered two lotus root salads - very good and refreshing. Two shaken beef (bo luc lac) - one dish was very good and the second was perfection!  We ordered oxtail stew(off menu), a roasted crab, egg rolls, five spice chicken, garlic noodles, and lots of merlot to help things move along. Their eggrolls were flavorful as well.  Overall, we were very pleased with the food at Le Soleil. The waitresses were friendly and one even conversed with me in Vietnamese.  The old items are very reasonably priced for the quality of food and services they provide. I almost forgot to mention the sea bass - although tasty, it missed the mark as a Vietnamese dish.  Fried with too much batter, but still moist and tasty. I would have liked to see caramelized clay pot fish (ca kno to) served at this restaurant, but there are other places I can go for that.  Although we did not find the best banh xeo here, we did find many flavorful dishes that will sure to bring us back again and again. 

Enjoy!

Let me know what you think of the dishes serve at this restaurant.  Like any restaurant, there will be good days and bad days. I have a feeling this place has more good days than most.
author: Duke D.

description:
PROS -
The pumpkin ice cream dessert was tasty. The owner was nice for showing concern and comping one of our dishes, and sending over the free dessert.

CONS - I. can't. even.
The service was, honestly, the worst ever. More on that in a sec.

Appetizers: The imperial rolls were pretty standard, but good and crispy. The soft shell crab was salty, fishy and mushy -- but the shell wasn't even soft enough. The batter was tasty but sooo greasy.

Entrees: The beef curry short ribs had a great flavor and a good deep fried coating, which really hooked me at first, but they're fried to hell and swimming in creamy, greasy sauce. After a couple pieces I couldn't stomach any more. The lamb chops came with two pieces -- one overcooked, the other almost raw, sitting on what could only be described as gritty, sticky purple peanut butter without taste. Along with bitter, tough Brussels sprouts that were *actually* the least awful part of the dish.

Service: where do I even start....

The waiter who asked at the door whether we had a reservation (we did.) said we'd have to wait at least 10 minutes until more tables cleared. (Even though we saw an empty, clean table right there.) After several minutes waiting in the entryway, suddenly the owner noticed us and sat us right away, at that table.

It was a wait before anyone came to take our order... when the waitress finally came over, they were out of the appetizer we wanted (we saw other tables getting it before us). Instead of giving us a second to pick another she said "Sorry we're out of that, I'll come back later" and left.

She came back with our drinks awhile later. My bf's beer was in a bottle with some poured into the glass -- one inch of liquid in the bottom of the glass, about 5 inches of foam. We both laughed because it honestly looked like a joke. My wine was a white (not what I expected or wanted) so she went back to check if it was the one I'd asked for. She returned, and yes -- apparently I'd ordered the only white on the red side of the wine list. She was nice enough to offer a new glass no questions asked, I thanked her and said we're ready to order, too, she just dashed away with the unwanted wine saying "okay I'll come back later." bluuurrrgggghhhhhhh

We FINALLY order and get our dishes (see rant above) and were not impressed. The owner walked by and noticed our lamb dish was hardly touched and was bright bloody pink. She was so nice, apologized and offered to cook it more or bring us something new -- however we were pretty put off and said we were full anyway. She took it off the bill. I really appreciate that she cared so much and tried to make it a better experience.

So we were done eating, and a different waiter came to clear our plates. We had one short rib left, and even though he didn't love the dish, my bf asked for a box to take it home. The waiter says ok, then forgets and immediately throws a dirty bowl right into the dish. He heard my "Uh?!" as he ran off, and rushed back to apologize and tried to take the bowl out of the dish and sort of held it out as if we might still want it. OMG NO!!!!!!!!!!

Hence the free dessert. The owner was so apologetic and it's not like we were even complaining -- it's just that the experience was so clearly terrible from beginning to end. Because of the owner's obvious concern and kindness, I raised my star rating from 1 stars to 2. Unfortunately I just can't rate the place any higher no matter how good her intentions are.

This place could use an ENTIRELY new waitstaff, a better wine list that makes sense on the menu, a few fresh dishes that aren't so greasy, more consistent chefs -- just change everything please.
author: Laura W.

description:
We tried the soft shelled crab, which was really good and perfectly fried!  Had a nice lemony sauce that nicey complimented this cute dish.

The lotus root salad is also a MUST get!  Since it comes with a fish oil based sauce, it basically reminds me of vietnamese vermicelli, but without the noodle, meats, or chicken.  Great fried onion taste, and it's super healthy with all those root veggies.

Their 5 spice chicken is always veery tender and has a great flavor (I also very much like the fish sauce it comes with).

Their shaken beef is okay.  It's not bad, but I was expecting something more tender.

Lastly, for dessert, we tried the mango sticky rice.  The waiter really undersold this one, so I had my expectations low.  I've personally never had real mango sticky rice, and my friend said that is better.  But from somebody who's never tried it, I thought this fusion version was actually very tasty and interesting.

Overall, a little bit on the fancy side, so their apps and desserts, please expect small.  But their entrees are very generous proportions, and everything is very well-presented.

The overall flavor for every savory item is definitely citrus-- you'll find it in the sauces often.  Even their water is infused with orange and lemon.
author: Lily N.

description: We were in SF with our friends, and we were craving for Vietnamese food. We found Le Soleil via Yelp so we gave it a try. It turned out to be a perfect choice...love the decor, very intimate ambiance, and most of all, their food. We had flaming quail, beef carpaccio, crab with garlic noodle, bun rieu, caramelized sea bass, and a new beef stew dish recommended by the owner. For dessert, we had fried banana, and this dessert is a killer, complete our evening of wonderful food. Servers are very tentative, and well trained. The executive chef came out & checked on customers...that shows the caring for customers. We will definitely come back to Le Soleil whenever we are in town.
author: Vinh D.

description: Update: I make any out of town visitors come here at least once and they always fall in love! The food is so consistently good. The lunch specials are a steal for the amount of food that you get! My little guys love the garlic noodles and the chicken lollipops. There are too many great choices on the menu for me to pick a favorite, but I definitely recommend that you always start with the bbq pork spring rolls!
author: Hanster P.

description:
Wanted to try a new vietnamese fusion and this place came up. We stopped by for a Sunday dinner. Here's what we had:

Shrimp Krispy - fried grounded fillings with burnt rice for that nice crunchy bite. Came with a peanut sauce that overpowers the filling. Wanted to try it based on the description and it was ok. Think I'll try something else next time. 

Papaya salad - typical vietnamese salad. The fish sauce wasn't overpowering, so that was nice. Large portion too, so everyone had at least two servings. Crisp papaya and carrots along with fried onions. Just love he texture of this dish

Sea bass - delicious. Caramelized and the sea bass itself was cooked well. Definitely a good choice. Came with Brussels sprouts and rice. 

Macadamia encrusted Lamb shanks - not a particular fan of lamb in general, but the dish  was good. Came with Brussels sprouts. Again.

Portobello w/asparagus - tossed on a sweet soy sauce , these were a hit. Being a vegetarian isn't half bad. Came with white rice and of course ....Brussels sprouts. 

House fried rice - fried rice with dick and pineapple. Can't miss item and it was tasty. Lots of dishes came with rice so I'll pass next time. No Brussels sprouts with this dish. 

Many vietnamese fusion places out there and it's nice to have found another to add to the rotation. Service was friendly and they kept our water full every time in dipped below halfway. None of this matters unless the food is good so, that's the icing on the cake. I will be back.
author: Sammy T.

description:
It's funny, I've lived a few blocks from this place for the last 4 years but only just tried it for the first time last week. So many restaurants on Clement, so little stomach space.

Anyway. This place was pretty good, a nice ethnic respite from all the ethnic dives on the street. Not that I don't love my ethnic dives, but it's nice to not always have to have  ethnic food under fluorescent lights. The food was very tasty -- we got the caramelized sea bass (a-freaking-MAZING!) and the shaken beef (tasty but standard).

Next time, I might have to get the sea bass again, but will skip the shaken beef. The waitress said that the crab was sick-awesome, so will go for that. Had the mango sticky rice for dessert, not great not bad.
author: Nami S.

description: This place is amazing! The fusion of Asian favors are done with perfection and the food is great! Been here for brunch a few times and requested things that were not on the menu and the chef nailed it every time. Can't wait to try this place for dinner!
author: Elena S.

description:
The food and hospitality at Le Soleil makes my trip from Mountain View to San Francisco worth it!  My best friend and I just had dinner there, and we were treated graciously by the staff, and had their imperial rolls as an appetizer followed by garlic roasted dungeness crab, and five spice chicken.  All were to die for.  The staff accommodated our request to shell the crab; it was stellar!  I've previously had their caramelized sea bass, and that is also superb.  

Le Soleil is a destination restaurant that's an asset to the Richmond neighborhood.  Can't wait till my next visit.
author: Eileen W.

description: Great foods especially the samplers and the garlic crabs! Friendly service, clean and good value!
author: Andrew L.

description: My husband and I love this place for lunch! Turmeric crepes are refreshing and very tasty! Soup, the rice dish in the pot-yummy! Very reasonably priced, quick service and always tasty! I think the menu somewhat changed several months ago but the favorites are still there!
author: Natalya V.

description:
CRAB OVER GARLIC NOODLES!!

Le Soleil is not your average vietnamese restaurant.  Very beautifully decorated and intimate setting.  This is a great place to have date night or to eat with a group of friends/family.  The customer service is excellent!  The staff is very nice and knows exactly how to get a big tip from you.  

Food Highlights:
CRAB OVER GARLIC NOODLES, 5 Spice Chicken, & Shaken Beef.  This is only to name a few because my stomach does not have the capacity enjoy more of the rest of the good food on the menu.  The quality of Le Soleil's dishes aren't not like typical vietnamese pho restaurants.  The flavors are rich and you can taste a lot of different spices.  All ingredients taste very fresh.  A lot of heart is put into the food here which makes it feel as if I was eating fine dining.  I also heard the head chef has won many cooking competitions and awards in Asia.


I will definitely come back and show off this place to my other friends.  I highly recommend this place to all fellow yelpers & foodies.
author: Brian K.

description: The ambience is very clean nice and cozy with brown wooden chairs good lighting. The food comes out Inna timely manner and the food is amazing especially the shaken beef and grilled pork chop would recommend to anyone
author: Adrian L.

description:
I just simply love this place, the food, the decoration, and the excellent services. I am Vietnamese and my mom makes good Vietnamese food so I have lots of requests for viet food outside. Le Soleil really makes good food and mostly importantly, very reasonable price!!
I love the Imperial Roll,  Fried Chicken, Shaken Beef, Five Spice Chicken, and Garlic Noodles! Their chicken is very very juicy!! 
My friends love their Quail, she was scared when the waiter lights up the quail but when she had her first bite, she was very surprised because it was so delicious. 
The Mango sticky rice is a most try because they use black rice instead of the regular one. It's so good and their Creme Brulee is also very tasty! 
I really love this places!!
author: Tammy V.

description:
I would give this place 3.5 stars and here are the reasons why. 

Taste:
We ordered Dungeness crab (comes on top of garlic noodles), fried rice and shaking beef. First the garlic noodles were pretty good! Not overwhelmingly oily like the one at PPQ and the crab was mediocre and the amount of crab was disappointing compared to PPQ. 

Fried rice wasn't extraordinary-- it tasted like any other fried rice at a Chinese restaurant. 

What we really enjoyed was the shaking beef. The sweetness of the sauce created perfect harmony with their sour sauce.

Ambience:
If you're looking for casual dining you're at the right place. Upscale/romantic dining def not. 

Bang for your buck:
I wouldn't get crab if you're craving crab - I would go for other star dishes they are well known for.
author: Sarah K.

description:
We live in the Inner-Richmond and saw that Le Soleil has received great reviews.  This part of Clement St is home to many great restaurants as everyone knows.  So it's hard to go wrong here.  However, the consequence of being a street with a lot of culinary cred is that restaurants have to live up to it.  Also, this is a neighborhood "in transition." The middle-class Chinese and USF frat boys are being replaced by well-off Chinese and grown up frat boys with families.  Thus, there are restaurants to accommodate.  Let's check it out:

This is a restaurant for people who can not deal with hole-in-the-wall authentic ethnic food.  This is a place where the focus of each dish is aesthetic, rather than taste.  The menu is Asian fusion. You won't get anything displeasing, but you won't get anything incredible.  No matter what, you'll receive a nice little mint sprig cut perfectly on the side.  There is a nice quiet water trickle the whole time while you're eating, etc.  You get the picture. 
If you are looking for great food and incredible dishes don't go here.  If you're looking for upper-scale Asian fusion not meant to challenge any palate, this is your place.  Bland and boring in all ways.
author: sonrisa m.

description:
Poor waitress, the only one serving a full house on a labor day.  The food was okay, a little too greasy for me.  Garlic noodles did not taste like garlic noodles.  Crab was alright but not okay for the price you pay for.
Had a long wait for everything and did not have a chance to try their dessert.
author: Coco C.

description: We had Laksa Noodle Soup, Chicken Noodle Soup & Traditional Noodle Soup and all were delicious.  We all agreed we will come back.
author: Kevin K.

description:
DELISH. My friend, Wendy, introduced me to this place this week. What a GREAT restaurant. It's not straight up Vietnamese food, but more of French-Vietnamese fusion. 

The restaurant is small, but holds quite a few people. As the night wore on, I was surprised at how packed it got on a weeknight! The service was generally good and friendly. The restaurant felt intimate and had pretty decor. 

I let Wendy recommend the food since she had been here often. Everything was AMAZING. We had the Beef Carpaccio (SOOOO good and served on top of homemade shrimp crackers) and Shrimp Papaya Salad (light and refreshing, not too spicy!) for appetizers. 

Then, Wendy's boyfriend, Jerry, ordered the Curry Short Ribs and I ordered the Shaken Beef for entrees and we shared. The Curry Short Ribs was very unique - the short ribs were served in a clay pot with the curry, but seemed to have been fried first as it was crispy. It was a good dish. The Shaken Beef is a classic, but done SO well here - it was super tender and flavorful. I would probably order this every time... 

We ended the night with Tempura Ice Cream. The tempura batter was a thin coat and perfectly fried so that the ice cream was still nice and firm on the inside. It was also just really yummy, creamy ice cream. A great finish to a great meal!
author: Tiffie L.

description:
Not sure if it is because the gratuity is guaranteed (we had a large party), but the service was spotty. It was hard to get a waitress' attention just to get a glass of water. We ended up serving ourselves.

We had a bit of everything, and all of it was pretty good. 

Will probably come again since we're big foodies.
author: C C.

description:
HOLY COW this place is so good!! I don't give out many 5 star reviews but here are all the wonderful things that happened tonight:

-Papaya salad: refreshing, light and not too salty. very delicious actually. Most thai restaurants have papaya salad too but it always tastes like MSG/overly seasoned.

-SQUAB = HIGHLIGHT OF THE NIGHT. Highly recommend. Tastes like sweet soy sauce chicken. They light it on fire at your table to give it the finishing touch and some oooh aahhhs.

-Luc Lac Shaken beef: delicious, soft and succulent 

-Curry short rib: crunchy rim and melt in your mouth meet in the middle. The curry was average but the bread that came with it was pretty darn good, anyhow, brother was able to clean it even though he was already really full. 

Last but not least, props to the waitress who had to run the restaurant ALL BY HERSELF. she said normally there are 2 servers but the other server called in sick. She was literally running around non-stop, i felt so bad for her. But she did a great job and managed to be polite still!
author: Katherine C.

description:
The first time my bf and I came here, it was a lot better than expected.  It has slowly worked its way into our "places where we return to go" category. 

We tend to order one meal to many between the two of us to try out different items on the menu, but this time we didn't have any left overs. 

I highly recommend the Caramelized Sea Bass.  It was just the right amount of crispy-ness to make it addicting.  The Beef Carpaccio was also a big hit for us.   I haven't had anything on the menu to complain about yet, and we keep coming back for more.  

Parking it tough, but a great place to walk to if you live close enough and the bus goes near.
author: Erin W.

description: This has become a usual dinner place for my boyfriend and I. We love this place so much for its delicious food, ambiance, and amazing service. I would definitely recommend you order the five spice chicken and curry short ribs!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Great service, nice and clean restaurant....that's a great starting point for an Asian restaurant!  Now on to the good stuff.....the EATS.

We order the garlic noodles, but with shrimp instead of crabs (i wish we got the crabs).  We also ordered the cube or shaken beef, sea bass, and house fried rice.  Everything came out great and decent portion size.  The sea bass was perfectly crispy, but not over cooked, and the brussels sprouts were DELISH!  It's definitely a nice place to go.  Oh and for drinks, you MUST GET THEIR LYCHEE TEA!!  Seriously, I drank a whole pot to myself...it's DELICIOUS!
author: Allie D.

description: Super tasty and great value. The barbecue pork blew my mind!
author: Stephen H.

description: The place is not that impressive. We ordered Beef Carpaccio as appetizer and two entrees Lamb Chops and Curry Veggies. Food is okay. With that price, you can go to a quite decent place with larger portion. Curry veggies are pretty tasty.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
The food here is pretty decent. You can't get much vietnamese food in SF like you can in SJ, so I get what I can. Prices are pretty high for what it is. Flavors are on the sweet side.

This restaurant is near my place so I thought we'd give it a try. I didn't know what to expect because they had a "make reservations" option which is usually left for establishments that are actually busy. I don't remember if I actually made reservations but when we got there it was completely empty besides one other couple. 

Had the caramelized fish with greens and rice, the eggplant and tofu with rice, and the lotus salad with shrimp. It was nice to see the lotus salad since I haven't had much of that living in the city. Like I mentioned previously, the food was pretty good but really sweet.
author: Stine H.

description:
Garlic noodles - ok
Shaking beef - gooooood
Curry short ribs - gooooood
Sea bass - really goooooood
Coconut chicken soup - really gooooood.

Fried banana - good, but typical.
Tempura ice cream - meh
Sundae - excellent 

Great and friendly service. 
Dungeoness crab noodles looked amazing.  Will have to try when we go back.

Not good for children, as the main Yelp page says it is, which is why we went there.  Yes, we do check.  For the first time ever, my son decided that he was going to scream bloody murder - so we took him outside.  Very embarrassing, but thank you to all the patient and understanding patrons we apologized profusely to that night.  The staff was also very accommodating with my toddler.
author: Denise M.

description:
My wife and I came here because we saw the great reviews on Yelp. Unfortunately, it was just overpriced americanized Vietnamese food. The area is known for their great asian food, and my wife and I are regulars in the area. This falls short of places like Burma superstar(which is a few blocks down) or those small hole in the wall restaurants that the Inner Richmond is known for.

We ordered the Beef and the cod. Both were disappointing. Especially the beef. If you want a broccoli beef sauce that you can get at Panda Express with just higher quality meat and smaller portions and pay $15 bucks for it then you've found the right place. The cod was pretty good but tiny and FRIED so it was greasy. There were a lot of people here on dates and you could kinda tell that they thought this was high end asian food. It's not, I promise. 

I will give them props on their service, but sorry, I let the food speak for itself. Their service is to make up for the small portions and high-end Panda Express quality food.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I walk by Le Soleil on Clement Street very often, but I never tried it until I read Charmaine B's glowing review recently.  After leaving work early thanks to a lengthy meeting that left me without a lunch break I walked into a nearly empty restaurant for an early dinner.

The friendly waiter/server greeted me and seated me at a window side table.  The menus are well worn here, and the copy I got was literally falling apart in the middle.  The large number of selections on the menu surprised me, and I asked the waiter for additional time so that I could study it better.  

I have this stubborn opinion that mixing rice noodles with gravy is always a bad thing yet that's exactly what I ordered on this visit, the Pan Fried Wide Rice Noodles with Chicken and Prawns.  I don't often find Hoisin Baby Back Ribs on the appetizer menus of other Vietnamese restaurants so I ordered one of those too.

As I sat slurping from two tall glasses on my table, one filled with ice water and the other with soda, and peered out the window to people-watch the passers-by more restaurant patrons began arriving.  It was a short wait before my food arrived.

The noodle dish (pictured) arrived first and it looked really good.  The soy sauce-based gravy was very light and actually worked well on this dish which combined lots of chicken with cabbage, celery, carrots, broccoli, zucchini, onions and a couple of prawns on a tightly packed bed of pan-fried rice noodles that actually looked like less than what was on the plate.  The combination of flavors was lightly seasoned, and I found that I enjoyed this dish.

The baby back ribs (also pictured) must have needed extra preparation, but it arrived just as I was finishing up on the noodle dish.  The ribs certainly had the aroma of barbecue ribs.  The soft tender pork was just slightly overcooked as parts of the meat had reached a level of jerkiness.  Most of the rib meat retained good moisture though and paired well with the thick, sticky, gooey sauce that tasted much like hoisin sauce and molasses.  These were a bit messy to eat but awesome nonetheless.

Overall service is good, and the moderate prices are about the same as other restaurants of this type that I've sampled.  I would definitely return.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Tis the "season" to indulge in culinary wonders. This place is absolutely remarkable. Wonderful flavors in the beef carpaccio  and the bbq pork spring rolls. - fresh mint and a chili fish dipping sauce; who could ask for anything more? The shaking beef was good and the lemon pepper sauce gave another flavor profile to the dish. This place brings the "Season" all year long.
author: Allie P.

description: I really like this place. I've had lunch and dinner here and find the food to be tasty and consistent, and it's what keeps me coming back. You can usually get a table within minutes for 2-4 people, however when it's busy I think the service sometimes suffers. They seem to have new servers every time I visit and this could contribute to the problem. I like the ambiance at night with their dimmed lighting and dark wood interior. Their lunch specials are a great value and is a great place to have a bite after shopping the Sunday Farmer's Market.
author: Jules M.

description: First time here.  Service was good.  Had soft shell crab - light not greasy batter could have been better. The Beef Carpaccio - perfect light sauce Melt in my mouth!  Lamb chops - Gamey but tastey. I think it could have been prepared better. Sea bass - alot of flavor crispy Beautiful! Reasonably priced... I would be back, maybe to try the soup...
author: Thomas C.

description:
Their Chicken Noodle Pho beats TT and HKMG hands down.
But sure - they are a little pricey, but the quality is definitely well worth it.

They also have a branch in HK which serves up some really expensive high tea stuff at a hotel.  I guess they are doing well.

The lady owner is also very very nice.
author: Koalie W.

description:
Stopped by for the amazing happy hour specials while waiting for our table at B-Star next door.

Our server was nice enough to let us know that the rolls we ordered would be free if we checked in on Yelp! That was nice of him.

The Garlic Noodles were the best I've had anywhere, and the fresh spring rolls were delicious too. I'm totally going back for a full meal next time!
author: Kunal G.

description: Stopped in with the family for a quick dinner. Seated right away. The shaking beef was terrific as was the five spice chicken. The rice crispy shrimp appetizer was also quite good. Worth a visit.
author: Bob R.

description:
We had a wonderful dining experience here. The decor and ambience was inviting and comfortable. On a monday night, the place got full up while we were there. We had the Soft Shell Crab (Cua Loi) and the Lotus root beef salad (goi bo) as appetizers. Both were fantastic, in particular the salad, which might have been my favorite dish of the night. A wonderfully fresh mix of flavors. For our entrees we had the Shaking Beef (bo luc lac) which was recommended by our server. It was the best I've had anywhere. Just perfectly cooked, high quality and great flavor. I found the lemon pepper sauce it came with superfluous as the beef itself was so flavorful. We also had the lamb chops encrusted in macadamia nut, brussel sprouts and japanese purple yam. The colors of the dish were striking. I thought a bit less of it vs  the other dishes: then again the  bar was set impossibly high by them) but my wife really liked it. I thought the macadamia crust didn't work that well with the lamb. But it was a very rich and hearty dish, perfect for the cold night.

Service was super and the whole evening was just right. My wife who rarely writes reviews vowed to write one! The portions were large and there was enough to take home to relive at least part of the experience again the next day. Lotus Root Beef Salad...oh yes!
author: Henry Y.

description:
Came in for my 1 year anniversary and man, this place really surpassed my expectations.  Asked for the best table, got one right next to the window. 

Service was excellent, not only was our server attentive, the rest of the workers came by and checked up on us.  The OWNER himself even came out to greet us and have a chat.

FOOD WAS DELISHIOSO MUCHO.  My goodness their Beef Carpaccio was on the spot.  The Curry Short Ribs were cooked to perfection.  The flavor was so good and it melted in your mouth.  The Shaken Beef Dish was also very good.  It had a side sauce made of lemons and spices in which you could dip the dish into and it just made everything so mouth watering.  The Coconut Drink we ordered actually came from a COCONUT!

5 Stars all the way, GREAT DINING EXPERIENCE
author: Jeremy C.

description: One of the best place you can go in SF for top quality modern Vietnamese food in a very cozy dining atmosphere.  Their crab garlic noodle is to die for!!!
author: Wil L.

description:
Came in on a quiet Monday to have dinner with a couple of gf's, the service was very attentive and polite. As our first time, followed recommendations from some yelpers and ordered beef carpaccio and luc lac " shaken beef". Oh boy, the food was delish! 

Being such a meat eater, I never had carpaccio before, I must say it tasted very fresh, and the texture with nuts and onions mixed with basil...yum! Def going back!
author: angela l.

description:
High end Vietnamese fusion food. Don't expect the general Pho and Pork Chop run of the mill Vietnamese food.

The food is of the highest quality. My favorite appetizers are the Lotus Root Salad and the Soft Shell Crab. The Entree would be the Caramelized Sea Bass and the Curry Short Rib. Fried banana is the best dessert.
author: Jay L.

description: I love this place.  Ambience, service quality of food and Chef Dennis is always making his meals with presentation in mind.  Great selection, quality, freshness of the food and price is all on the plus side! Owner would come by and ask how was our service and thanked us for coming to Le Soleil.   They give you that Family like feeling!!!  MUST TRY and experience it yourself!
author: Darlene H.

description: The food here is delicious. I tried the shaking beef (which was my favorite), and the garlic noodles. I didn't think that the noodles were as good as thanh long's but they were tasty. Service was pretty good. Overall, a great place to eat. I'd really like to come back and try their roasted garlic crab.
author: Emily G.

description:
I been coming here for over 10 years. This place has really updated their menu and remodeled nicely. 

Love the food here. 

Beef Carpaccio with shrimp chips

Shrimp rice krispies-basically shrimp balls with rice that is fried on the outside

BBQ pork spring rolls-delish. Taste just like Dragon Fly's, but missing the crunchy stuff

Lotus Root Salad

Shaken Beef

Seabass with brussel sprouts

Garlic Noodle-wish it was the thicker  noodle. They use ramen noodles. 

Great food, good service, and affordable prices
author: Karen H.

description:
Okay this place is decent.  I am leaning towards a 3.5 stars vs. the four I am giving.  There are just so many great restaurants in SF it's hard to be rated highly for me.

We ordered the tofu mushroom and bean sprout crepe.  Very nice texture of the crepe, very crunchy.  The filling was a little bland but at least it came with a sauce.  It was weird that there were at least 5 pieces of lettuce with the crepe and we didn't know what to do with it so it was a waste.  It came with some pickled veggies that we ate with the crepe.   Would recommend this appetizer.

We ordered:  Short rib curry & shakin beef.  The shaking beef was way better than the short rib.  The shaking beef was nicely seasoned but could be more tender.  It was cooked with onion and had a side of rice.  Too bad there was not more veggies.

The short rib with curry was slightly bland without the curry sauce and it was strangely combined with a garlic bread side.  We would not recommend ordering this dish.  

So all in all, an above average place but nothing spectacular.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description:
This place is bomb af. Decent price for delicious food. It's a casual restaurant so of course I was expecting loud noises and lots of talking. But, the place is really modern and decorated incredibly well. Really nice ambience and I get a somewhat intimate vibe.

I recommend the Shaken Beef, it's so juicy and cooked to perfection. The Curry Short Ribs was amazing and leaves a lasting impression in your mouth. The short ribs were battered and crispy and it works really with the curry. The only issue I had with it was the fat on it. If they trimmed some of it off, it'd be perfect.

Definitely a must try!
author: Jimmy N.

description:
Incredible!!! If you live within 1 mile of this location - GO!!! Food is very very tasty!!
