Skip the spring rolls, the only thing that wasn't good....at all. 

Caramelized Sea Bass was the star dish. Get it and you will love it. 

Portobello dish, Shaken Beef and the BBQ Pork were all amazing!!!

Service was ok. They had a small problem  with our order in the kitchen, but it was fine. I work in the industry and understand nothing is ever perfect. But the food is unbelievable!!!  Please support this local gem!
author: Jorge C.

description:
Delicious food and friendly service! 

My boyfriend and I came here for dinner on Saturday night. The server took her time to explain the menu and recommended Chicken Lollipops, the Curry Short Ribs and Garlic Noodles with Prawns. We also ordered the Quail, which one of servers torched at the table. Cool presentation! 

Everything was fantastic, especially the Short Ribs and Garlic Noodles. I definitely recommend coming here.
author: Monica H.

description:
I never would have guessed this was a Vietnamese restaurant. It's pricey for the usual cuisine but a great experience and the food is delicious! (Bowl of pho is $9 when it's usually $7 elsewhere; bo kho was great but it was $16!). 

I highly recommend the bo kho. One of the best I've ever had. 

I came in craving duck soup - mi vit quay. Wasn't on the menu, but somehow they had it? Surprising and so glad I stuck around to try it. It was good! A very large portion too. 

I highly recommend this place. Clean, nice ambiance and good food!
author: Mimi V.

description:
I can't believe I've lived in the Richmond area for years and have not heard of Le Soleil.  My friend was telling me that it was recently remodeled - which make sense since the pictures and food mentioned in past Yelp reviews do not resemble what I saw during my visit.

Regardless, the "new version" of Le Soleil is fab!  It's so chic and modern yet not overly pretentious at all.  I know it sounds sort of absurd to love a restaurant's restroom but I really do appreciate the cleanliness and simple decor.  You can always tell how sanitary a restaurant is by its restroom.  As a germaphobe, I was pleased :)

Let's move on to the food!  If you check in on Yelp, you get free spring rolls!  My friend and I opted for the BBQ pork spring rolls.  They were the smallest portions I have ever seen, but I think it might be because they were free. 

For entree, I had the Five Spice Chicken w/ Brown Rice.  What I love about the chicken was that it was perfectly crispy around the edges and super juicy on the inside.  I took a bite of my friend's Shaken Beef and it was equally comparable to my dish.  The beef was so tender that it melted in my mouth.  I dunked it in the lemon pepper dipping sauce which gave it a nice tang. 

I recommend also getting a side of garlic noodles to share.  If you love eggs, then you'll absolutely love these garlic noodles.  There are chunks of garlic and eggs goodness buttered all over each strand of noodle.  So yummy!

As if we didn't already stuff our faces enough, we were tempted by the dessert selection and ordered the Fried Bananas w/ Coconut Ice Cream.  No regrets there!  The warm, gooey texture of the bananas were so complimentary to the freshness of the coconut ice cream.  I didn't feel guilty at all polluting my body with the sugar since it was THAT good! 

It might sound like I work for Le Soleil or am a family member of the owners - BUT I am not :)  I am just a new crazed, avid fan!
author: Judy C.

description:
I've been waiting what seems like forever for Le Soleil to reopen. How excited was I when they reopened just in time for my post-Vegas recovery meal. I ordered the "chicken noodle soup" or pho ga (not on the menu) and it totally did the trick! Was just as delicious as I remembered. 
The interior has been upgraded and is warmer and more inviting then before. There are a few bar seats now, perfect for a mid week loner lunch. The menu is limited right now, but just ask and they may be able to make you something if they have ingredients in the kitchen. Wine by the glass is pretty cheap, $6, which I appreciate as well.
I'll be back soon!
author: Jessica B.

description:
I came here on Sunday 2/22 and the experience as a whole was pretty average.

The space is modern, casual, and overall has a nice ambience, the service is friendly enough, but the food itself is bland and you can get way better Vietnamese food for much cheaper all over the city (especially in this part of the Richmond). My family of 4 ordered and shared the imperial rolls, shrimp green papaya salad, five spice chicken, shaken beef, and the lamb chops. Vietnamese imperial rolls are by far my favorite Asian deep fried eggroll, but the ones served here were dry and underwhelming, and the nuoc cham (dipping sauce it's typically served with) was flavorless. The salad was light and nicely plated, but again flavorless. Not surprised since the dressing for papaya salads typically is similar to nuoc cham. I'm guessing they're trying to cater to people who can't handle much fish sauce. The five spice chicken was tender but nothing special at all. The lamb chops were unique but the use of macadamia nuts were questionable and again, flavorless. The shaken beef was probably my favorite dish if I had to pick one. Oh, and the Thai iced tea wasn't bad either. 

In sum, this is a great place if you are just being introduced to Southeast Asian food and aren't accustomed to the flavors of this cuisine, for the menu here has potential but is lacking in those flavors. The portions were a fair size, but if you want flavor for your money, I recommend going elsewhere.
author: Andrea D.

description:
This started as a potentially bad experience that got better, so I am giving Le Soleil 4 stars for a variety of reasons. Let's break it down:

I made reservations for a party of 6 (admittedly on the larger side) for a Friday night. When we got there on time and announced ourselves to the hostess, she looked terrified. The place was packed with nary a reserved table in sight. Turns out they'd overbooked. They asked us to wait 10 minutes so they could clear some tables. That's about how long it took for us to get seated, so good on them. Still, it was a nerve-racking start to the meal. 

But the staff was very apologetic and attentive for the rest of the evening. They gave us complimentary appetizers and desserts and the head chef even came out to ask how we liked our meal. The food itself was quite good and not too expensive. I'd go again, but avoid peak days/hours next time.
author: Julia D.

description:
Wow- really really good food.

The garlic noodles are awesome, as is the rice porridge, curry veggies and eggplant.

I've walked by it 100 times and have only recently discovered how good it is.  Prices are decent portions are big and I'll definitely be back.
author: S M.

description: Customer service was just unbearable. I was in pain waiting waiting waiting just to get seated. I called the lady and told her why you No help me She said I busy... I said me no care, I want fooooood!! She replied back and said I don't careeeeeee!!! Thats when I lost it and I started screaming at her in front of all her customers! She was embarrassed, I started laughing out loud!! The awkward part was I actually sat down and ordered the lamb chops, and they where so greasy and just nasty and my fiancé order chicken, but it tasted like pork. Overall the worst customer service I experienced and worst food!!!
author: Edon T.

description: Me and my friend ate here two nights ago. I got the veggie curry and he got the house fried rice with duck. He threw up that night and i woke up with a terrible allergic reaction! I have never been allergic to anything before. You are warned!!!
author: Adam T.

description:
Ambiance: complete remodel, very comfortable feel, great date place
Food: Vietnamese cuisine, excellent variety, every item on the menu is tasty especially the crab and my favorite quail.
Bevs: Water is memorable! Excellent wine list
Price: Very reasonable, nice happy hour menu
Service: Terrific, attentive,
Overall: Highly recommended, one of the top restaurants on Clement
author: Carlos S.

description:
Food:
Spring roll
Lunch special beef over vermicelli noodles
Came w creamy soup


SERVICE
Good

ATMOSPHERE
Simple clean can tell a designer had his touch on the place.
author: Angela L.

description: The light is dim like you are transformed into a different world.  We had 10 people all together and it was great to have so many because we got to try so many dishes.  The restaurant made us a personal appetizer with Vietnamese rolls, duck salad, and crunchy shrimp balls.  Can't ask for a perfect appetizer dish.  Great presentation.  Ask 10 people and go over there, quick!  All the dishes were great, especially the eggplant, curry veggies, beef, and the sea bass was perfect, too. Service was excellent.  The owner was so gracious.
author: Helen L.

description:
Having grown up in the Richmond district, I was surprised that I had never heard about this place until this week. Based off of the reviews here on Yelp, I decided it was worth giving it a try. 

Everything from the water to the entrees were delicious. I had dinner here with three other friends so we were able to try a variety of things.

Bbq Pork Spring Rolls-- we received for free from checking-in on Yelp. A lot tastier than I expected.
Garlic Noodles-- we really wanted to try this after seeing it in all the reviews, but it wasn't on the menu. If you ask your server about it, they can make it. A large order was enough for the four of us. 
Quail-- prepared tableside. It was a great presentation, and it was tasty!

For our entrees, we tried the Shaken Beef, Grilled Pork, and Portobello Mushroom. All very good! I recommend any of the three.

Service was great as well. Our server constantly checked up on us and refilled our waters (which was infused with a variety of fruits like lemons, apples, and oranges-- very refreshing!). 

All in all, another great restaurant on Clement St. Will definitely be coming back here to try the rest!
author: Zherr-Anne A.

description: The best vietnamese fusion restaurant in the City.  Great ambience and services.  Curry crab is one of my must have, Hainan chicken is a special order item but must have also.  The best crispy spring rolls in town with fish sauce.  Garlic lobster and shaking beef are all awesome.  Got to go back to try everything on the menu.....
author: Ray C.

description:
01.12.10

This restaurant is not equipped for loud people.  We were placed in the corner window table, so we disturbed the other patrons the least.  At least that's how I felt.  If only we could stop giggling about nothing.

Their beers come cold with a frosted mug.  I love that.

Go for the quail.  You won't regret it.  It's set in white rum and finished table side.  Meaning the waitress sets the quail on fire in front of you.  Awesome.

Garlic noodle with prawns plus garlic beef are both fantastic.  Portions are bigger than I remembered.  Big plus since I'm eating the leftovers as I finish this review.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I eat here a TON with my family - so it's about time I did a yelp review... it's our go-to Vietnamese restaurant. The food is always consistently amazing and the menu has a great variety of options. The restaurant is casual enough for a quick dinner on a weeknight but also nice enough to take friends on a weekend. The servers are friendly and very attentive and efficient even when they have large parties. 

We always eat family style and get a bunch of things... 
My mom LOVES the beef curry - the beef is breaded and fried and always super tender & the curry itself is full of flavor. 
My favorites are the Chicken Lollipops and Vietnamese style Beef Carpaccio with homemade shrimp chips. (drool). And the fried banana dessert. (extra drool). The imperial rolls are more classic and are equally as yummy. Garlic noodles are a must. 
We always get the green papaya salad to start - its refreshing and light. 

After a few years this is still one of our favorite places to go! Whenever I'm in town we'll always make a point of going back :)
author: Rachael G.

description:
I'm a lover of Vietnamese cuisine, and this place is pretty good. 

We tried:
-Lemongrass Beef Bun
-Crab & Shrimp Noodle Soup

Their bun was one of the best: tender beef, delicious imperial rolls, and fresh veggies. The noodle soup was alright, but wouldn't get it again.

I love the decor of this space, very modern and clean. The service was alright as well. 

Bottom line: I'd come to this place again.
author: Jade F.

description:
First, my mom ordered a creme brûlée and they brought her a flan. When she asked about it they said "no, that IS a creme brûlée, we get it prepackaged that way". We had to pull up a picture of a creme brûlée on my phone just to prove that a flan is, in fact, NOTHING like a creme brûlée. Finally, after consulting with the manager, the waiter fesses up that the kitchen actually ran out of creme brûlée, so they served her flan in stead (and let it be said that flan is NOT on their menu). And on top of that the flan was the cheapest, crappiest store-bought thing EVER, my mom couldn't even eat it. Even her green tea was flavorless, like from a cheap store-bought tea packet.
Then, I ordered a "cat fish and chips". Total mistake. Everything on my plate was weird: the French fries were covered in sweet mango sauce (terrible combo), the salad had been infused by lavender water or something because it tasted like potpourri, the catfish was completely tasteless so I had so slather it in its accompanying sauce, which happened to be a too spicy bizarre combination of ranch and tartar sauce.
And when we complained that everything was terrible the waitress laughed!
The only silver lining is that my mom wasn't charged for the flan debacle.
I'll never be coming here ever again!!!
author: Nicky S.

description: FRESH food. Great lunch SPECIALS! Great staff, very friendly. I love their non-traditional coconut chicken soup, their rack of lamb for dinner and their 5 spice chicken is pretty damn good. Overall great place for a nice, reasonable place
author: Katie D.

description: So happy Le Soleil has re-opened.  We had an excellent dinner here Saturday night without a reservation -- as much as I like BStar Bar, our usual go-to place in the neighborhood, it mystified me to see a line for BStar and empty tables at Le Soleil, which is less expensive and just as good.  I prefer the new incarnation, and find it still reasonable.  The Trefethen Sauvignon was perfect for the food, and a bargain.  The best from the old menu is still there, with some new additions.  Luxurious seating -- nice spaces between tables.
author: Robin W.

description: Food is delicious.  Customer service friendly.  Go there on a Saturday,  around 1pn and it's pretty empty there.  I'd recommend this place and will come back again.
author: Jer M.

description: Yummy food, great presentation, street parking though. must order: beef stew in claypot (not in menu) crab with garlic noodles.
author: Jo L.

description:
Great service, great food and and good ambiance.

I had the rose tea, which was amazing!

 Also, we had the curry tofu vegetables and the shaken beef.  The beef was a bit chewy, but very flavorful, and the curry was made very well.
author: Riri S.

description: I got invited to a Birthday dinner here tonight. What a scrumptious dinner! I was impressed with their yummy food and friendly service. I also like the atmosphere with a modern décor. Their famous Dungeness crab with garlic noodles, Imperial Rolls, Sea bass, shaken beef and special fried rice are so delicious. It is a true fusion Vietnamese blended with French style restaurant. I already can't wait to come back here to try out their other dishes.
author: Mr C.

description:
Below average food.  there was nothing shaking about the shaking beef.  it didn't taste like top quality beef;  the seasoning was lacking.  maybe we were supposed to be shaken to disappointment.  macadamia lamb chop was bland.  it was supposed to crusted with macadamia nut or rather that was how it was described.  i wont go further, it was poorly executed.  

 also had the papaya salad which was good.  the best dish of the night.

the crepe was okay.  the lettuce that accompanied this was in a sorry state.  .

was not impressed with the food here.
author: Bill L.

description:
Preface: My sister-in-law is visiting us from LA before we move to Germany. She wanted to get together with our niece and her sweetie who live in the city. They suggested Burmese Superstar on Clement. Well, when we got there around 1.30 pm on a Sat, there was a waiting list. Since I remarked that we had a BS in Alameda and that I thought whereas a few dishes were excellent, I thought that Burmese food I had tasted in the Bay Area was a fusion of Thai/Vietnamese and Indian food--but a fusion of the blandest of both! So she thought we could go elsewhere. YEAH!

We walked down Clement toward Arguello and went past several places. Le Soleil looked good despite no menu posted. James said he had eaten there before, and the food was decent. So we went.
We were seated right away. Decor was pleasant, not just basic. The menu was a little weird, all in English. It seemed they had appetizers, soups, rice plates, but no standard "regular" Vietnamese dishes. And even though I do not speak Vietnamese, I'm used to identifying the dishes by their native names. 

So I started by ordering our beers: Bam-ba (bad vietnamese for 33). The waiter knew exactly what I wanted. I then started rattling off "appetizers" tapas-style in Vietnamese. I had no ides which of these were actually on the menu. I ended up asking for my favorite bo luc lac which I did not see on the menu, even described in english. Jack didn't see it either. But he said they had it.

The food was brought out in stages so we could enjoy everything. Condiments were brought automatically or on demand. Beers kept coming also upon request. 

The cha gio and others came with all the wrappings the way they're supposed to be served. Everything was quite tasty. The bo luc lac came with the required  salt/pepper/lemon (or lime) dip, which is rare.

So we left very content. I'd definitely recommend this place.

Post Script: I may have given this establishment 4 stars given yelp definitions. But after reading some of the horrific reviews, I think they deserve all the points to get their score up.
author: Nobbi L.

description:
I was very disappointed after eating here since they reopened.  The menu is a lot smaller than it used to be and the portions are too.  The only thing that has gotten larger are the prices.

I used to love the garlic noodles but they are nothing like they used to be.  You can only get them with crab or as a side for $6.  The side is a very small portion but in the end it didn't matter because they had very little garlic flavor, very bland, and the noodles are now these skinny noodles, not like the fat juicy ones they used to serve.

We also had the Imperial rolls and there were only 4 tiny ones for $7.  The cup of chicken curry soup for $6 was the best thing we had.

I went there the first week that after they had reopened and the staff was over attentive to the point of being annoying.  We were there less than an hour and the waiter asked us how everything was at least 6 times.

One of my favorite neighborhood restaurants gone, what a shame.

At least we have B-star right next door, a much better and more delicious option.
author: Madeline M.

description: we had valentine's dinner here and it was lovely and not that expensive.  My favorite dishes were the turmeric crepes to start, and the caramelized sea bass main dish was melt in your mouth delicious.   The ambiance wasn't especially romantic or intimate though, but it was a very nice place.
author: Clare T.

description: Spent mothers day here tonight and the food was delicious! I was impressed by the quality of the ingredients used. Even a simple five spiced chicken dish was cooked to perfection. Service was great too!
author: R A.

description:
Fresh, delicious food and great service.

Went here last "night" for the first time since the remodel.  Got there around 5:15 for an early dinner with one of my professors, his pick - but I couldn't be happier.

We started with the vegetarian spring rolls (he's a vegetarian).  They arrived promptly as he ordered them as soon as we sat down.  The only thing missing was shrimp/pork, oh well.

I ordered the 5 spice chicken, which came with rice and a delicious slaw/salad.  I expected a grilled chicken breast - I normally avoid anything fried because it makes me feel lethargic and greasy.  The dish arrived slightly before my professor's, which normally makes me angry, but his followed within 30 seconds - so I was happy.  

The chicken was lightly battered and fried to perfection, perfectly crisp and browned on the outside, juicy on the inside - I believe it was a thigh, brown and white meat, but not greasy at all.  It looked to perfect to disappoint my expectations, and it was tasty.  Not heavy at all, and the slaw that accompanied it was a perfect match - light, crunchy, and flavorful.  And what the hell, it's not as if I have any bikini competitions in the near future.  

A neurotic side note, even the mint was freshly chopped - no browning of the edges (a personal pet peeve).  Oh yeah, the rice was good too - but steamed rice is nothing to write home about unless they really fuck it up, which they didn't.  The server made sure to bring two dishes of shiracha as requested, needing no reminder.

The professor's veggie curry looked good too - lots of broccoli, tofu, and a rich broth.  It also came with rice.  

Overall, a good experience - and I already have plans to return with friends so that I can give their wine and beer list a try whilst enjoying a meal.
author: Chelsea J.

description: Great Vietnamese place with a hidden menu!  Been here twice and both times blown away.
author: David Y.

description: I came here for dinner for two in January.  I thought the service was good, but the food was only so so.  We ordered the green papaya salad and the quail as the appetizers, the dungeness crab with noodles as the main course, and the mango sticky rice as the dessert.  The salad was decent.  The crab was very not meaty and the noodles that comes with the course is fairly salty for my taste.  And lastly the dessert was okay, the mango wasn't sour but wasn't sweet either.  And for this quality of the food, I thought the price was fairly expensive.  The crab dish alone was already ~$46.  I much prefer the crab restaurant a few blocks away.
author: Johnston C.

description: We found this place on our drive home from the Legion of Honor. Clement Street is thick with restaurants and cafes but parking is scarce. We decided to park first and then look for a restaurant. Someone pulled their car out of a spot and we pulled in, and we found ourselves right in front of Le Soleil. Lucky for us. Checked Yelp to see what others were saying in order to confirm our choice. There were three of us and we ordered this and that and shared. Yummy vegetarian spring rolls, papaya salad, shaken beef, curry. Good food, good service, nice ambience. How can I take off a single point?
author: Paula H.

description: I returned to Le Soleil after a long absence.  Prior to the remodel, the food had gone downhilll, and I stopped going.  But curiosity got the better of me so I returned last week for dinner and was pleasantly surprised that both the service and the food was very good.  The shaking beef was to die for, and the lotus root salad was tantalizing.  We also had the turmeric crepe and the curry veggies, both of which were excellent.  I will definitely go back for the garlic roasted dungeness crab, the garlic noodles and the caramelized sea bass.  Yummy!
author: Suhl C.

description:
Being a person who isn't too into sodium overload, I judge a Vietnamese restaurant by how good their rice places and other dishes are instead of taking the traditional Pho eater approach. I have to say that I enjoyed the barbecue chicken with rice. Twas very delicious. Their imperial rolls were also really good and not too fishy, like some other places do it. 

I didn't mind that the waiter wasn't the most friendly of characters, as the restaurant was packed and it looked like they were short staffed. As long as the food comes out in a timely manner and is delicious, I'm happy. 

Surprisingly, Le Soleil beats out a lot of other Vietnamese places I've been to, including the massive number that exist in San Jose! 

Again, order the imperial rolls!
author: Stephen D.

description: Great Fresh Vietnamese - awesome food with great prices!! Highly recommend
author: Ltrain M.

description: Good food, good service! Make sure you make reservations first! Crab noodle is the best! Whole crab is good for three people to share! Love this place!
author: Jiao J.

description:
My new go-to spot for Pho, Crab Soup and side of garlic noodles.  They also have really good catfish n chips which is fresh and lightly battered.  The atmosphere and decor is nicer than any other pho place I've been, although a bit dark.

Don't forget to ask for the free pork spring rolls with yelp check-in.
author: Taylor J.

description:
Had planned on having lunch downtown, but since plans got derailed with work, I decided to come here for a quiet, MSG-free and relatively gluten-free Vietnamese-French meal.

It's pricey compared to fast food Vietnamese joints in the T-loin, Richmond and Sunset, but keep in mind the cuisine served emphasizes the original Asian fusion style of Vietnamese-French. There are California cuisine touches here and there in the food as well.

The East-West decor is showing some signs of age, but it's still appropriately beautiful and bourgeois for the mood and food presentation.

I've been dying to have Vietnamese crepe (Ban Xeo) for quite some time now, but most places have jumped on the pho bandwagon and don't make it. Thank goodness Le Soleil makes Ban Xeo and it does it right!  

They don't cheat by putting eggs in the crepe  -- it's actually yellow from turmeric spice and made with rice flour which makes for a very crunchy crepe (eggs will make it soggy and runny). Local iron chef, Charles Phan has written about Vietnamese crepe in Food and Wine and Le Soleil's version is appropriately thin, crisp and crackles like thin glass under the fork and knife.

It came with the traditional fixings -- leafy lettuce, fresh mint (TONS of it -- they don't skimp on it here) , pickled onions, cucumber slices and julienned carrots.  The dipping sauce might look and taste the same as what's typically offered at cheaper Vietnamese places, but what is amazing is that they don't use MSG in this and any of their dishes and can still make savory meals.  

Another thing I like about the Ban Xeo Vietnamese crepe at LS is that they use shrimp, chicken and bean sprouts instead of the traditional shrimp, pork and sprouts combo.  I don't mind paying extra $$ since I could tell the ingredients were premium -- fresh and antibiotic/preservative free. They offer a vegetarian version which I'll have to try next time.

The service was very prompt and pleasant.  I only ordered soup (egg drop with asparagus and fresh crab which was delish, too) and the Ban Xeo crepe, but the waiter didn't have an attitude about it and was attentive throughout my meal asking me if everything was alright and filling my glass when empty.

I ended up here on a whim, but next time I'll definitely come back to sample more.
author: Bodhi D.

description: Wish I could write a better review - we stopped in for lunch two days ago.  At first we were the only customers.  We ordered banh xeo and a chicken salad.  The banh xeo was so-so, and the salad tasted nice intially until my daughter discovered a large hair plus follicle in it.  We questioned the waiter about it; he went back to confer with the chef.  He returned and stated: "The chef says it is a hair from the chicken."  Hello - last I checked, chickens have feathers.  Le Soleil did not offer to comp the dish - of course, my daughter did not finish it.  Poorly handled - we won't be back.  Cannot talk this place up to you at all.
author: Manya B.

description:
Delicious food at a decent price. I've been here a couple of time and am always puzzled by how empty it always seems. Don't be put off by the lack of a wait for a table - the food is still good and the service is quick. 

I like to order the clay pot rice, but their other dishes are pretty yummy. Their soups have tasty broth and their lemongrass chicken is tasty.
author: Apple P.

description: Innovative menu and the best Vietnamese foods I have eaten anywhere so far. The place is clean and usually crowded. The price is also reasonable considering the quality and the demand.  I have yet had a dish I didn't like.  Be sure to use the Carfinder app in your smartphone since you may not be able to find your car parked blocks away afterwards. I would gladly pay $20 for valet parking. Hint: Food is the best when the owner-chef is cooking.
author: John C.

description: We loved this place.  Great food.  Super fast service.  Reasonable decor.  Not bad prices.  Overall excellent experience.
author: Daniel D.

description: I really want to like this place.  The food was just OK (ordered shrimp salad) and the service has been slow twice now.  I will try it again, but it's just a little lacking.  They also didn't honor the yelp check in deal which was weird.
author: Andrea R.

description:
Pros: quality food, nice interior and ambiance. 

Cons: terrible service. Waiters ignored us the entire time, and didn't respond to requests for more water and rice. Also, they flat out never brought out two of our tables drink orders and still tried to charge us for them. 

I likely won't be coming back. Overall, this place was not outstanding,  and we did not appreciate getting ignored.
author: A W.

description:
Stopped by this place after reading all the positive reviews on Yelp.
After waiting at the entrance kiosk for awhile, my spouse, kids & I finally just grabbed a menu from the stack and started to seat ourselves. 

After someone finally came out to seat us, they ignored us after the water service.

After 10 - 15 minutes, 3 hungry kids, and a virtually empty dining room, we couldn't wait any longer and left.

Of course, as we all got up to go it was THEN a staff member came over!

A shame, really, as we were looking forward to a good meal. (Hard to see what was on the menu though, because the lights were really dim.)

This was on Friday, Nov 23, around 6pm. 
What a disappointment !!
author: C H.

description: Very unbefitting place to dine! I Have to drive around for 40Mins before finding a parking spot and still cannot dine here because I did not have a reservation beforehand. How am I suppose to do that when I am only visiting SF for a day? Anyways the staff or at least d person who I talked to was superbly foolish & condescending. I'll give this place 'NO STARS' at all if allowed to do so. I won't recommend them to anyone who's worth something!
author: Darlington N.

description:
Went here with my cousin for the first time today because he's been on a health kick lately and wanted something that would fit that need. Le Soleil came up on a Yelp search of "healthy lunch", so we decided to go with it.

We each got the special lunch plate -- I got the BBQ Pork Chop and he got the Five-Spice Chicken. Fellow Yelpers, you weren't kidding about the large portions! Thankfully, we were hungry enough to polish off our whole plates.

The meats were tender and done just right. The soup with pineapple and tomato was delicious and unlike anything I've had before. The Vietnamese salad and perfect-consistency rice served as a perfect complement to the rest of the meal. And I couldn't possibly ignore the imperial rolls, which were a tad greasier than I would have expected given the rest of the meal, but delicious nonetheless. The lunch specials were reasonably priced at $9.80 apiece, which is more than one might pay for a Vietnamese lunch in SF, but the price is certainly indicative of the quality and portions we received.

Service was kind and attentive, and we were greeted by the waiter opening the front door for us to welcome us inside from the rain. 

All in all, it was a very satisfying experience, and I am sure to return to try their other menu items.
author: Dave A.

description: First time walked in this restaurant for lunch special $12 included Coconut Chicken soup, Lemongrass beef with imperial roll!. Very disappointed with the coconut chicken  soup! Is wasn't has much coconut flavor and I wasn't able to tell if there is chicken pieces or not ! Some taste like white chewy stuff, I guess that was chicken! I like the imperial roll the best and it was a small piece and dipping sauce is good too! Lemongrass beef is decent but not very remarkable! I will come back for other dishes like others recommended! But this first experience is just a 3 stars!
author: Iris N.

description: Vegetable curry and tofu eggplant were good. The fresh vegi rolls were cold and overpriced. Our server was not very pleasant and seems to be inexperienced. The head server  was nice.
author: G Y.

description:
If you're ever in this neck of the woods and feel like having some Vietnamese...check this place out! ... I've eaten here a few times, and each time was a very delicious meal. Good service every time! I'd also say that prices are reasonable for what you get. 

I had dinner here w/ a girlfriend tonight. We ordered the following: 

1) Shrimp cake - ok 
2) Five Spiced Chicken - yummy 
3) Vietnamese crepe - delicious 

...Very healthy and delish! 

I'd definitely come back to try the other items on the menu!!
author: Annette L.

description: The coconut soup, garlic noodles, and pork and shrimp spring rolls were all mediocre. There is better Vietnamese food nearby.
author: Gabriel S.

description:
The place looks very nice from the outside and it is very clean inside.  Both times we've come here, it is always hard to get the attention of an employee ... and yes we are always having to flag one down or approach one about every little thing (i.e. our water ran out, or for hot sauce).

They don't have all the regular items that every other Vietnamese place would have and it is a bit more pricey then the others as well.

Both times I came here I asked for no mint on any of the items we ordered, and it seemed as though they just added the normal mix, and literally picked out the mints they saw ... which did leave traces of mint in the foods that we can obviously still taste.

I tried it once and was not impressed, thought I'd give it a second try ... and still my opinion stayed.  Oh well, it's not like there aren't any other classy Vietnamese places in the area ... *cough*pot de pho*cough*
author: Pia V.

description: Excellent service and satisfying food. I recommend the Macadamia Pork Chops.
author: Eric A.

description:
My friend had discovered Le Soleil while on the way to checking out B Star, which is right next door. I'm a huge fan of Vietnamese food, so I was excited to try something that was not in Little Saigon. The restaurant met my expectations.

- Ambiance: Cozy, sufficient space between tables, and not too packed on a Fri night. 
- Parking: A bit difficult. This may be the main downside. It is not easy for find parking in Inner Richmond, let alone for a restaurant right on Clement. I got lucky and had a spot 2 blocks down. 
- Perks: I checked into the restaurant on Yelp and immediately got an offer! This is the first I've ever gotten. We got a free pork spring roll, which was quite small but the process was super fast. I just showed the offer on my phone to the waitress and she immediately marked it on the bill. No scanning or anything needed.
- Food: We ordered Bo Lac Lac, Sea Bass, Lamb chops and the Papaya Salad. Everything was delicious! Flavors were strong, but they had this lime/lemon sauce paired with each that helped to balance things out so I wasn't eating rice the whole time. They did offer brown rice. The meat for all 3 dishes were very tender, and though the portions looked small, I was surprisingly full after eating everything -- and there were 3 of us sharing all of this!

I would definitely recommend this as a nice alternative for good Vietnamese food, which isn't in Little Saigon, but not as far as Sunset. If you're willing to make the slight trek and circle for parking a bit, then Le Soleil is for you!
author: RJ C.

description:
This review is based on the food, location and service.  

Food:  The clay pot chicken and beef vietnamese rolls were absolutely delicious.  Very healthy, but full of flavor. 

Location:  The location is super easy to get too, you don't have to be invested to the city and drive all the way into it and fight for parking.  This is a good easy spot to go to if you just want good food, good prices and easy for people on a schedule.  My friend came into the city from Marin and I came into the city from the south bay.

Service:  Great efficient friendly service.

The next time I'm visiting SF, I hope to come here again and try more things on the menu, because there were a lot of things that looked like they'd taste great!
author: Rhonda W.

description: How did I not know about this little gem in the inner Richmond! I had my bday dinner #6 here and what a memorable dinner I had here. Good wine selection and yummy delish food. We did order a lot so let me try to list everything.  I remember having the spring rolls, quail, shaking beef and the yummy yummy crab and garlic noodles.  As I am typing I am probably due for another trip here soon!  How can I forget to add that the staff here is amazing....thanks Le Soleil!
author: Allison T.

description: This place was better than advertised. If you like curry, get the short rib.
author: M W.

description: Le Soleil has topped my list of favorite neighborhood restaurants for years, serving wonderful Vietnamese fusion food. I'm never disappointed by their delectable dishes and excellent service. Among my menu favorites are Imperial Roll appetizers, succulent Carmelized Sea Bass with brussel sprouts, and spicy sweet-hot Garlic Noodles with Prawns (or Crab in season). Their short wine list of excellent California and imported wines is obviously selected with care by a connoisseur.  The dessert menu has heavenly selections such as fried bananas with coconut ice cream and sweet Vietnamese coffee.  My guests and I never tire of their delcious cuisine.
author: Ashley A.

description:
i usually don't frequent fancy looking vietnamese places, but since b star was booked, why not?  Lets face it, the only thing I really eat in a vietnamese place is some kind of noodle soup.  I try to pick the rice plates or make a comment about how the pork chop looks good, but who are we kidding.  Give me the pho selection!  Basically the same pho selections as your usual place.  I always order the combination with some kind of tendon.  

When it arrived the meat was nicely laid out on the bowl.  All the sprouts and lemon were even stacked on the plate.  Usually a sign of over priced pho with all fluff and no substance. Surprisingly the broth was excellent!  I can alway tell if the pho is good if Im drinking the soup when all the noodles and meat are gone.

Best Pho in the city!
author: dion c.

description:
This is upscale Vietnamese cuisine by Clement Street standards and the best Vietnamese food I've had in the City.

Warm, pleasant ambiance with nice track lighting and pretty wood tables inset with glass cases holding decorative pieces.  The food is outstanding.  We started with the combination appetizer plate which came with imperial rolls, strips of bbq lemon grass beef and grilled prawns served atop vermicelli noodles with scallions.  Accompanied by a platter of fresh greenleaf lettuce, shaved carrots, fresh mint, fish sauce and rice papers to wrap it all up in.

We were there at dinnertime, but wanted rice vermicelli noodle bowls, which weren't on the dinner menu.  The servers were completely accommodating to our request and graciously whipped up a couple of bowls.  In fact, the service was very attentive and polite, and they seemed genuinely interested in our reaction to the food and restaurant.

Reasonably priced too: mom and I feasted on hefty portions, all for a little over $30.  The place appeared to be clean too, even the bathrooms.

This restaurant certainly deserves all the accolades it seems to have collected on its walls over the years.
author: Rick H.

description: The reviews are craziness! 5 stars??? Food was way too salty. Maybe I picked a bad night to go. Maybe I should have given my gift certificate to someone that would appreciate it. Ehhh...There's too many maybe's. The shaking beef was alright. The sea bass was fried in batter and had the saltiest brussel sprouts drowning in sauce. The beef carpaccio was so thin i couldn't get it off the plate. LOL. Highlight of dinner was going down the block for crepes at Genki's.
author: Gessa C.

description:
love this vietnamese restaurant. sure it's fancier and pricier than your average pho, "order by number" kinda place, but the quality, service, and ambiance warrants a little more out of the pocket.

the vietnamese deep fried imperial rolls are some of the best in the bay area. and you know it's authentic because it comes with a side of lettuce, rice noodles, mint, and the fish sauce. you're actually supposed to put the imperial roll in the lettuce with all the other fixin's and roll it up...then chow down.

the seafood crepe is light and crispy. i have no idea how they get the eggs to be so thin...it's darn great. another thing that you should order is from the dinner menu (not on the lunch menu)...the "look luck" beef. small chunks of tender, tasty, addicting beef with thin red onions.

the noodle soups also fare very well. the pho is tasty and the noodles still have their bounce. (i have no idea why other reviews say there is no pho on the menu). the beef in the noodles are actually flavored and marinated, not just a few simple slices of cow. the crab and shrimp noodle soup is fantastic. don't be alarmed when it comes out and the whole bowl is red. it's a tomato based soup with ground up shrimp and crab that creates a very rich seafood flavor. 

and don't forget the authentic vietnamese coffee!
author: Charmaine L.

description: Enjoyed their version of bun rieu, along with the vegetarian spring rolls. For the price, the soup was skimpy in portions, but was very good. The veg.spring rolls was about equal at other Viet restaurants. Clean place, fast/friendly service is what I encountered. It's in the less-hectic portion of Clement.
author: Derek N.

description:
Great Date spot. Very comfortable environment, good food, and prices that won't break the bank. Great service

I was in Vietnam earlier this year and this is the best Vietnamese food I have found since returning. You can definitely taste the French influence.

The Garlic noodles- Get this! about $9.00 

The imperial rolls- best I have ever had - $8.00

The garlic lemon beef- out of this world lemon sauce- $13.00

The sauces here especially the spicy chili sauce is tough beat

If you want Pho, a quick meal, or cheap this is not your place
author: James B.

description:
Finally. Finally I have found a yummy vietnamese restaurant that doesn't scare me with their cleanliness standards and doesn't skimp on the extras with the Pho. Of course you pay for that privilege at Le Soleil. It's more of a fancy version of your typical Viet place. Coming from Southern California, where I worked near one of the biggest Vietnamese communities in the state, I have been hunting for a decent place to match the quality of the food I was used to eating down south. So excited to find Le Soleil. I had the Beef Pho and the Imperial rolls. Both SO DELICIOUS! I was almost giggling when I ate it. And like I said they didn't skimp on the side goodies like lettuce, carrot, mint etc on the rolls and the Basil for the Pho. Which impresses me because invariably every time lately I order those dishes elsewhere I get like one sprig of basil and always have to ask for more. So this made me very happy to have such an abundance without even asking.
So I'll be back, I wish it was a little cheaper but the quality is obviously high here, so I don't mind paying a little extra.
author: Amie N.

description:
Mango salad was delicious.

Beef and tendon Pho was full of flavor, perhaps the best broth I've had in a while.

This place is way better than turtle tower with much friendlier service than you'd find at most smaller asian food establishments.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I have been coming to this restaurant for quite some time, yet I just haven't gotten around to writing a review.  There are certain dishes that are a MUST HAVE here.  The beef look-luck, garlic noodles, and the chicken spring rolls are my absolute favorites.  Service can be hit or miss, but often time the food makes up for it.

Today I was craving those 3 dishes (5 mos preggo FYI) and the restaurant was bustling.  I got stared at 3 times, only to be ignore 3 times.  Trust, I am familiar with that "look" since I am the master of  "looking busy" so that no one will bother me.  We waited another 5 minutes (thus making it a total of 10) and after I waved/flagged one of the flustered servers down for his attention "party of 4 please"...I got dismissed with a "wait just a minute".  So my family and I left to get some pizza at Georgio's.  

This unfortunate incident won't stop me from coming back for those dishes.  I will just remember not to go there on such a busy night where the waiters are WAY overwhelmed.
author: Karen C.

description: Upscale Viet food done extremely well! Ive been here several times and not once have I been disappointed by the food or the service.  Always love coming here. I recommend the rice krispies, lotus root salad, and the shaken beef... but honestly, you cant go wrong with anything on the menu (atleast i havent run into any spoilers yet).
author: Sean T.

description: Really nice meal reasonably priced and served well.  I enjoyed the interesting blend of spices and the portions were well sized.  Everyone in our group of six enjoyed their time here.
author: Victor W.

description: UNBELIEVABLE. Sunday evening. 7:45pm. Only one other party in the restaurant ! ? ! ? Meanwhile, there was a line down the street at Burma....The spring roll was very fresh and delicious, the turmeric crepe ( note to owners: I would change the name of the crepe )  with shrimp and chicken was the best I've ever had. Very crispy on the outside. The lotus root salad, the garlic noodles are phenomenal. I would take off 1/2  a star for the creme caramel which is not bad but not quite right and definitely boring. I don't know about the creme brûlée. I will try that instead next time.
author: Patale M.

description: The food was amazing. I took my mom here for her birthday and it was just the best thing ever. I ordered Chicken Lollipops, my goodness taste like heaven The quail appetizer was delicious. My favorite dish I would have to say was the "Shaken Beef" I recommend this plate to anybody that likes meat. The lemon sauce OMG the best thing ever, make sure you dip it in that. The service was great. The waiters always checking up on me, making sure I was okay with my order and everything and always refilling my water. They were so nice and thoughtful. I can't wait to go back!!
author: William D.

description:
My experience at Le Soleil was extremely positive (hence the rating). What feels like an authentic Vietnamese atmosphere with lots of fresh flowers, handsome wood tables inlaid with a variety of artifact-like bowls and figurines makes for a great compliment to good service and excellent food at the right price. The coconut ice cream was perfect in dessert.

Furthermore, it provides respite from the usually packed restaurants in the area without sacrificing quality of food or ambiance.
author: Benjamin H.

description:
Let's see. I have been using yelp ever since it was made available to the general public and this is the first review I am making for a specific reason. I love this place. You know that saying "don't know what you have until you loose it" i have been coming here ever since I was a little kid because I use to live right around the corner between Geary and clement on third. I was trying to get my quick fix while I was in the neighborhood one day and bam! They had newspaper on their widows. I was so mad.. I thought I was never getting my fried ice cream again. But after a few months I realized they were just remodeling.. Shit how happy was I to find out?!? 

VERY

Once they finished their renovations me and baby mama flew (drive very fast) there
 
My favorites are the typical viet/chink choices.. Banh Xeo with lettuce as wraps and nouc mum for sauce, flambé quails and /or the tradition viet catfish soup which they also have an option with prawns. For entree the veg curry, bo luc lac (cubes of filet sauté in a dark rich soy base sauce over onions), ox tails, sea bass, and of course steam rice (chink choice of carbs). Then finally one of my favorite childhood memories.. Fried coconut ice cream.. My first response was WTF they say this was? But no really.. Just do it.. And if you have really read up to here.. Dude get off yelp and get fk out there to try it.. #stayhungrymyfriends
author: Kevin L.

description:
I'm so fortunate that my fiance decided to take me opposite the direction I wanted to go for lunch. I was upset at first but then very thankful when I saw Le Soleil, a place I've always been curious about. I got a bit excited when I saw the nice setting of the tables and out of the corner of my eye, a review from Yelp, which I avoided reading, in hopes not to be biased. 

The beef imperial rice rolls were delectable when I poured my sweet vinegar sauce into it until it was saturated.  My lunch special was the BBQ pork combination with fried imperial rolls, salad and soup. The soup was interesting as it has a sweet flavored tang to it. It went very well with the pork chops and rice. The fried rolls my dish came with were hmm... umm, oily? Not to say I wouldn't know that, but I could taste the oil they deep fried those babies in. I was slightly turned off, so I didn't finish it. But overall, I was slightly bummed that I never visited this restaurant sooner when I used to live less than 2 miles away.  I'd definitely come again and next time order a sweet drink...
author: Sharon B.

description: Great place to eat at! My best friend brought me here and it's definitely one of the best places I've tried out in SF! Love their pho and tofu eggplant, staff are super friendly and nice, the environment is excellent, and the food is wayyy above average! Go try it out for sure!
author: CaRol L.

description: LOVED this place! We ordered the crepe, five spice chicken and the caramelized sea bass. Everything was delicious including the rice. I had the rose tea which smelled incredible. Great, fast service as well. Was very impressed. Can't wait to return.
author: E. N.

description:
Soooo delicious! 
We came here the other night after looking at cars on Geary and were super hungry. We had imperial rolls, which you can wrap in lettuce and put other goodness inside besides the fried roll. 
Then I had the lemongrass beef, which was super tender and soft and utterly delicious. My husband had the asparagus beef (it was beef day :) and that was also really good. Brought the remainders home as there was a lot of food. 
It's a little on the splurgy side, or maybe we just ordered too much. But this is a place where you can eat really delicious vietnamese food. And the staff was really sweet too.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Wonderful food and great service!  We had a bunch of dishes including the fun Quail appetizer that get's "flamed" at your table. Very tasty, but of course not a lot of meat on those quail bones. 

Loved the Caramelized Sea Bass and had the Short Ribs too. The service was very good and we went on a Saturday night. The owner stopped by and talked to us for at least 15 minutes. This is a good neighborhood find!  I'm going back again that's for sure. ;-)
author: Natalie W.

description: Outstanding. Great food, delicious tastes, fair portions and fair prices. I especially like the humility and personal touch of the owner/chef checking in on our table to see how dinner went. This place is really great. The menu is diverse with a really unique variety of textures and flavors. Definitely a little hidden gem in the city. Try it for sure!
author: Brian W.

description: Amazing soup. Steak is also prime time. Always wonder why this place ins't more crowded (the food and prices are incredible), but at the same time, no complaints!
author: Mark C.

description:
I was excited to know that this place was going to open up again.  But, the way I found out about it was even more thrilling.  I got invited by my aunt, who's a good friend of the owner's, for a pre-opening family dinner!  The service was stellar, since we got the entire staff for ourselves!  We felt like kings and queens!  And the cuisine has gotten more refined since the remodeling.

My absolute favorite, which made me say "WOW!" from the first bite is:
- The "Quail Flambe with Rhum".  Absolutely outstanding in taste!
- The Chilean Sea Bass - this improved version which used to feature in their old menu is a must!
- Their Fish and Chips!  A true fusion dish between "East and West".  SO good and greasy!

Other suggestions would be the:
- BBQ pork spring rolls
- Garlic Noodles with crab, a classic!

A gem in the neighborhood!
author: Nadine M.

description: Yelp still has this restaurant labeled closed..it re-opened Monday 3/12/2012...Today is St. Patrick's day and we are here for lunch. The lunch menu has changed since the renovations but I won't complain. I had a beef dip sandwich which is one of the best I've had..probably because the dip wasn't just plain au-jus like everywhere else..the kids had the catfish fish and chips..the sweet chili fries were great, crunchy with spicy-sweet flavor to it. We need to return and try the dinner menu, but if these two menu items are this good...I'm sure dinner will be as well.
author: Orlando J.

description: Great food, nice decor, friendly staff
author: Fresh M.

description: Amazing!! Try the house fried rice w duck and pineapple. I am picky about my fried rice and this blew my mind.
author: Amelia S.

description: I've had two really nice dinners here in the past month - a great option when the line at B Star goes up the block.  Don't forget to save room for dessert!
author: Steve P.

description: Delicious! Reasonably priced. Made for a lovely evening. Spring rolls, Lotus Root Salad, Caramelized Bass, 5-Spice Chicken, Macadamia Lamb, Shaken Beef, and garlic noodles (not on the menu)--all with their own unique vibrant flavors. Jordan was an excellent waiter, and the whole staff seemed like they wanted us to truly enjoy our meal. Can't wait to go back!
author: Marc E.

description: I've had two phenomenal meals here since the reopening - the atmosphere is much classier than before, and the food is probably the best Vietnamese I've had in SF. This is a great place for a date or to impress an out-of-town guest with consistently stellar food. It's tough to make a recommendation because everything has been great, but I think the shaken beef is a must-try.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Absolutely delicious!  Thinking about their menu now is making me drool. 

My favorites are:

- Garlic noodle with Crab
- Luc Lac Shaken Beef
- House Fried Rice
- Beef Carpaccio
- Flambeed Quail 
- Imperial and Spring rolls
- Soy glazed Seabass

And don't forget the desserts! Fried coconut ice cream, sticky rice with mango...YUM!
author: Karen L.

description: This Vietnamese restaurant with good decor on Clement Street offers pretty good quality dishes at an economical price.  A Vietnamese chicken salad at $6.95 was quite filling.  When I asked the server for a dish he recommends, he chose lunch combo#2, five spice chicken with fried rolls, which included salad and soup ($8.30).  All the items of the combo, including the cup of soup, were served on one dish; consequently, dressing from salad transferred over to rice.  Chicken was pretty good, although it wasn't anything to shout about.  All in all, not a bad place for a filling lunch for less than $10/person.  Maybe 3.5 Stars.
author: トモ T.

description: Best things to order: shrimp chips ($2 during happy hour!), quail which is flambed tableside, the shaken beef, and the caramelized sea bass. The sea bass had a delicious soy glazed crust which was perfect. A lot of the lower ratings for this place came before it was remodeled and reopened. The food was amazing!
author: Lauren C.

description: It's been remodeled and reopened in 2013.  I personally love the good ambience here with dark wooden furniture and dim lighting which helps create feeling of intimacy. Waiters are super friendly and polite.  I've tried here 3 times now and tried different dish every time (yummy crunchy deep fried shrimp balls, beef porridge, duck and pineapple fried rice) and they were really delicious!! I just cannot wait to go back to discover more delicious dish!  Lastly, they have a great list on dessert menu. I had rich chocolate cake with coconut ice cream. And I'm going back to try fried banana with ice cream! I highly commend going here!
author: Hanna B.

description:
Total of six for dinner.  Two families of three each counting one pre-K child in each family.  The restaurant is not optimized for children (e.g. no kid's menu, no crayons, etc.) but they are certainly tolerant of kids.  There were at least two other tables with young children.

Summary.  We really enjoyed the food.  I do not understand why the lines for Burma Superstar are as long as they are and I do not understand why La Soleil always seems empty when we walk by.  

Pros:  Love the food.  We ordered:
Imperial Rolls (Appetizer)
Fried noodles (from the lunch menu, for the kids)
Eggplant 
Curried Vegetables
Pineapple and Duck Fried Rice
Shaken Beef

The curried vegetables have just a slight kick.  If you enjoy spicy food (e.g. Spices I or Spices II), this is almost certainly too mild for you.  Otherwise, it was "just right!"

The Eggplant was delicious and the Shaken Beef was so tender and wonderfully spiced.

Cons:  The dessert took far too long - and the two dishes that we ordered came out at least ten minutes apart.  We actually had to call the server over to ask what happened to the chocolate cake.
author: Thomas L.

description:
There are 4 places where I'd get crab & garlic noodles in the city.  Le Soleil is one of them.  Warrants the cliched comment: finger-licking good.

Besides the crab & noodles, other items we get:  fried egg rolls (wrapped in lettuce and dipped in fish sauce), seafood/vegetable crepe, and fried banana with coconut ice cream.

PS. For some reason, its always cold in this restaurant.  If you get chilly easily, bring a sweater.  I recommend one that you can easily roll up.  Remember - finger lickin'.  =)
author: Deanna A.

description: Had my birthday lunch there, I had the shrimp and tomato paste soup. Awesome. Vietnamese coffee rocks! Service is great and I would recommend this place anytime to my friends.  I will be back for the garlic noodles.
author: Candy B.

description:
What to say about a Vietnamese restaurant that doesn't have pho on the menu? Well, they explained that it's on the lunch menu but not the dinner menu and they made it for us, anyway. But what then to say about a Vietnamese restaurant that employs waitstaff that doesn't know what pho ga is. Seriously, without the menu to refer to, I asked for a bowl of pho ga and the waitress said "I don't know what that is. We have pho soup." 

So OK, I got the pho soup. A large bowl, because apparently the small is really small, like a normal bowl of soup small, not a small bowl of pho small. The broth was OK. The beef was well well over well done and there were also meatballs, which is a plus or minus depending on how you chose to look at it. 

But it's a really nice looking place inside. And it's nice that they employ white people. Because not enough of them have jobs.
author: Will R.

description: We had a New Year Eve dinner here. I was impressed of the upscale environment there yet the price on the menu was really reasonable. The food was tasty. We ordered the baked sea bass  and curry vegetable clay pot. Both were very well presented and the food proportion were just right. The only complaint is the table not on an even floor, so we have dinner on a wiggly table.
author: CL C.

description: I found Le Soleil to be a bit disappointing. Wait staff did not know much about the menu, and the cuisine was not that impressive.
author: Gina N.

description: I'm guessing I visited this restaurant post-remodeling because it looked very modern, clean, and nice. Lunch menu was not very extensive but the couple items that we ordered at our table were pretty good (lemongrass chicken, pho ga, crab soup, and escargot soup). Waiter was pretty friendly and efficient. The tableware was probably the nicest, highest quality I've seen at any Vietnamese restaurant that I can recall.
author: Kent W.

description:
Fantastic Vietnamese food!
Super fresh and tasty
Also, the service is extremely friendly and accommodating
We went there recently on Christmas Eve as our child was in a nearby hospital
We were late and they rushed our food so that we can could go back as soon as possible
Very nice of them!
author: FOO D.

description: Outstanding Vietnamese cuisine. Remodeled and elegant, this is an extraordinary restaurant. I recommend the off-menu Lemongrass Chicken, Duck and Pineapple Fried Rice, and Turmeric Crepes.
author: Sam R.

description:
Update:

 Excited! New signage going up that says Le Soleil! Hope they keep all my favorites, there, intact. Every time  I've asked workers when they're opening, they've said, "next month" starting back in December.
author: louise f.

description:
Update 2015

Came back and had a great meal here, everything was very tasty. Prawn noodles, green beans, beef were highlights. Unusually for Vietnamese restaurants, they don't really have pho 


---

Tasty and a tad expensive. The sea bass was amazing, everything else was good but the flavors are all kind of the same.
author: Mike L.

description: I love this place. The food is so tasty. Especially their veggies and fish. The service doesn't compare to the food. The staff gets the job done and theyre friendly but are on the young side and could polish their serving skills a tad.
author: Kristina C.

description: Every time I've come here, I've had a great experience. The sweet sour tomato fish soup is excellent . . . Also the goi cuon . . . the soft shelled crab. A good place to come with family for sharing on a large scale, or go on an intimate date.  Pleasant decor.
author: Lily C.

description:
I've been to Le Soleil a few times and have really enjoyed the papaya shrimp salad, basil chicken, and the Vietnamese coffee.

The yelp check-in offer fresh rolls were so-so. Not sure I'd order them again.

Le Soleil is really a hidden gem on Clement street. Significantly shorter waits than a lot of the other restaurants, but excellent food and reasonable service.
author: Lissa T.

description: Friendly staff, the Executive Chef found time to stop at each table and socialize with the guests, offered us free dessert and it was awesome - I've had several versions of the Sweet Rice Mango but the red rice was a refreshing change and well executed.  We had the short rib curry and the grilled pork and chicken - the side salad were actually edible and a good accompaniment to the main entrees.  Limited menu but Im sure choice ones.  I would come back for the green papaya salad.  Service is unobtrusive, the way I like it.  Decor is minimalist, simple but tidy.  I would come back with friends - maybe for lunch.
author: Soc G.

description: Great food - good service - if you haven't figured out yet, I am a sucker for chicken wings!!! - here they are not on the menu and you have to ask for the "chicken pops" (I think)...worth asking.  Food is of very high quality and the service is very friendly - pho is above avg but not quite up there with Turtle Tower.
author: Richard D.

description: Very average meal with uninspired service. So many good restaurants in the area but this one is a disappointment.
author: jenifer t.

description:
We were debating on where to eat and finally decided to venture into the richmond area and give Burma Superstar a try. They were closed, as I somewhat suspected, since it was about 4pm. We were going to try Clementine, but yes, they were closed until 5 as well. After that, we eventually stumbled into this place. 

It looked like a little cafe on the outside (nothing special), but was nicely decorated on the inside. The service is a little better than your average vietnamese restaurant, but not spectacular either. 

Now for the food-
1. the sampling platter w/ lemongrass beef, imperial rolls, shrimp, lettuce, pickled carrots and this rice paper tortilla was pretty good. I enjoyed the fact that it was a hands-on type of dish. We had to assemble it ourselves, and they were lucky that I was in that assembly mood that day.
2. The curry chicken w/ rice was good. We all liked it, but for my personal taste, it could've been a bit thicker and heavier tasting. The chicken was very smooth (the way I like it, so probably chicken breast. Yes, I'm ABC), and maybe even packaged. 
3. The lemon grass beef w/ rice was just what it was. It was good, but not necessarily better than the ones I've had elsewhere. 

Prices are average and probably a tiny bit higher.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Are you a vegetarian? Do you crave the sizzling rice pancakes? Well, Le Soleil can give you your fix of an enormous, crispy, and delicious sizzling rice pancake that's so good, you want to slap your grandma. Instead of the usual pork and shrimp, there's a delicious medley of veggies like mushrooms and bean sprouts. 

Back before I was a vegetarian, I tried the soft-shell crabs and those are pretty damn good as well. Try one of those if you don't try the pancake (I know what it's called, but I'll look stupid trying to spell it out, so I won't).
author: M L.

description:
I went here a few weeks ago for dinner on a Friday night. It was early so they weren't very busy and I got seated quickly. The service was great, but the food was only so-so.
The crispy shrimp appetizer didn't have any flavor. The crab noodles were good leftovers (more flavorful on the reheating).
I recommend it if you are looking for a mellow evening and aren't picky about food.
author: Lucinda P.

description: Vietnamese cuisine with a French flare! This is my go-to if I want a pricier Vietnamese food than just pho/noodle soups! Everything is reasonably priced and portioned. I absolutely love the Brussels sprouts here, no bitterness at all (why I fell in love with Brussels sprouts!)! I love the appetizer sample which usually includes a piece of fried chicken, salad, spring roll/imperial roll, and crispy rice thing. It's a great way to try the appetizers that they offer ( they have a dessert platter too which is similar!). I have gotten the shaken beef (amazing!!!), sea bass (used to be better but now, a little too fishy for me), the curry with French bread (LOvE!!), and papaya salad! In the past, when they have lobsters, they cook it with sticky rice (I'm in heaven!) and it's the best!! That is the only reason I need to come back! :) dessert sampler is pretty epic too, black rice mango is the must try!! :) overall, very cute date place and great food!
author: Jennifer W.

description: My family and I have loved coming here for over a decade. This restaurant has great dishes! You should definitely get their Vietnamese crepe from their appetizer menu! Their sour catfish soup is excellent!
author: Joe Y.

description: Are these guys still in business??? Phone appears disconnected, as does their website. Last time I walked by I thought it said closed for renovations. Maybe that mean renovations for a new restaurant. If so I'm buuuuuuuuummed.
author: dan b.

description:
I came to this restaurant wanting something that taste like home.  Since I live so far from home now I crave Vietnamese food more and more.  It is a good thing that I can find a decent restaurant closed to where I live.  I've dined at this restaurant twice and take out once and there will surely be future visits.  The first time I came here was for lunch.  I had the lamongrass noodle soup with fish and shrimp, which was delicious, because it tasted so authentic.  The grilled or charbroiled lemongrass pork and cucumber roll with fish dipping sauce was also delicious.  Besides the fact the it's not a traditional spring roll, all the other components are truly Vietnamese.  

Second time I came at dinner time.  I had the hot and sour soup with catfish and grilled pork.  I was taken by surprise how good the soup was.  It tasted like my mom's soup.  The rest would be history, because I came back and ordered the soup to go.....which will be the first of many times.  It's so difficult to find a restaurant that makes foods taste like something your mom makes.  The noodle soup and hot and sour catfish soup here achieved to do so, which is number one in my mental book.  

If you love Vietnamese food you must try this place.  Even though the concept is Americanize, the food lives up to its name of being AUTHENTIC!  However, you must go in the restaurant for the actual menu, because the one online is not even a portion of the menu in house.
author: Mai-Tam N.

description:
I really, really wanted to give this place more stars... but I just really can't. My husband loves it here.. Me? Not so much. It's alright.. It's just not great. Admittedly though, I've only been once.... and it's entirely possible that the thing I ordered was just NOT a good representation of their food.

I had the Crab & Prawn noodle soup... I had visions of succulent prawns and chunks of sweet, juicy crab meat floating around in delicious broth... What I ended up getting was something that looked and tasted much more of canned cat food. The "crab & prawn" had been all mashed up together into this weird chunky mush (seriously- like canned cat food) and was sitting in globs in my soup. It was extremely unappetizing. 

I ended up scooping all of the "crab & prawn" out and just eating the noodles and broth (which were tasty on their own). 

The service was GREAT though... super fast and very friendly. I'd like to give this place another go.
author: Tamara B.

description:
3 1/2 stars. Every dish was quite good.

Authentic? Maybe. Traditional and true flavors? For most dishes, probably not.

We had four people and everyone was pleased. However the flavors are pretty muted and don't display as much range as I'd expected.

The servers were friendly, but not as well versed as they could be in terms of the cuisine and the wine selection. (I tried to get clarification on one wine and was told - twice - that it was both dry and sweet.)
author: t w.

description: My girlfriend and I hosted her family bday dinner here (13 adults + 2 babies). I'm glad that we made a reservation because the place was packed, even on a Sunday night. This was our first time took this as a good sign, and it proved to be true.The food was delicious! Her family, who are not easy to satisfy, kept commenting on how tasty the dishes were. While you can dress casual, the interior decor is trendy and stylish and really adds to the dining experience. I'd recommend this place for a relaxing, delicious lunch as well. Looking forward to my next visit!
author: yumm y.

description:
Although it's been awhile since I dine at Le Soleil, I am still a fan of the Cuisine at this Vietnamese-French restaurant. 

When my aunt suggested an impromptu Friday night dinner at Le Soleil, I supported her idea and met her there. At 6:30PM, the place was already packed. It was a good thing we snatched the last table for four. By the time we order, the line was out the door. I guessed after being in business for more than a decade (as long as I can remember for they could be in business much longer), their menu and quality of food are still consistent and offering authentic dishes like Bun Siu (rice pancake) and imperial rolls. 

On this visit, we had: 

For appetizers, the mango salad, beef cappacio and my all time favorite -- Bun Siu (Vietnamese pancake made with rice flour and stuffed with sauteed bean sprouts and shrimps). The pancakes came with fresh lettuce leaves, mint, pickled carrots, daikons and garlic. The way you eat Bun Siu is take a helping of the pancake and wrapped it with a piece of lettuce leaf, add some mint, top with some pickled vegetables and drizzle some fish sauce and chow down the yummy, crispy pancake. So good! 

For our entrees, we ordered some garlic noodles, sizzling seafood plate and sauteed string beans with garlic sauce to share family style. The garlic noodles were made with egg noodles sauteed with garlic butter. It was creamy, garlicky and hearty. A little goes a long way when it comes to this dish. 

Then on to a plate of sauteed string beans with garlic. The string beans were cooked perfectly al-dante so that it still has a crunch to it. Overcooked string beans can be such turn off for me. Our final dish was the sizzling spicy seafood plate with Manila clams, fish fillet, shrimps and calamari. A combination of seafood sauteed with a spicy garlic and basil sauce and serve on a screaming hot sizzling plate. It was perfect dish to eat with steamed rice. The seafood is spicy and hot (temperature) and the sauce was so delicious. 

By the time we finished our dinner, we ran out of room for desserts. But we were satisfied, so no desserts required. Even though it's been a while since I visited Le Soleil, the food quality and taste still remained its consistency. That said a lot of the restaurant and its management. No wonder they expanded their business overseas and opened a branch in the Royal Garden Hotel in Hong Kong two years ago. You know the saying: if is good enough for the Hong Kong foodies, is good enough anyone. Hong Kong's foodies are so luck!
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description: Pretty disappointed on our first visit. Hot and sour soup was way too sweet for me, the shrimp in our spring rolls was in little square patties of pressed shrimp meat and tasted a bit like canned. Five-spice chicken was juicy and flavorful, but flavors were pretty mild. Not especially cheap. Service was very friendly.
author: Tom D.

description: A pleasure! Nice space, excellent food, attentive service. Gotta get the right things: Beef, salads, spring rolls, 5-spice chicken. Just a good vibe.
author: Ben L.

description:
I should have learned by now that when a restaurant says they are "Authentic Vietnamese Cuisine", they're full of crap. They might as well be called, "I'm Stealing Your Money." Yes, that's how it feels. This restaurant serves neither authentic food, nor good food for that matter. In fact, it's a bit pricey too.

Never crowded. I WONDER WHY....
author: MJ T.

description: Not authentic Vietnamese food, nor do they try to be. Unfortunately, for a fusion restaurant one would expect the menu to be creative and inventive, but this one was not that inspiring. Also kind of pricey for what it is. Good ambience.
author: johnson c.

description:
Yes, it's authentic!  

Vietnamese in the kitchen, Vietnamese waitstaff, Vietnamese customers.  Very cool.  

We walked by about 8:30 pm on a Saturday, and although the restaurant was full, there was no line.  We got an estimate of 5 minutes, and two other parties lined up behind us.  By 9 pm we were all seated.  

The appetizer sampler was a roll-your-own spring roll dish, with various goodies including some very tasty teriyaki-style seasoned beef.  More beef with asparagus, and scrumptious ocean scallops were the two entrees we ordered, and we had steamed rice on the side. My Lady ordered tea, which we both enjoyed, and I ordered a Hue beer that tasted a lot like Bitburger.  Our waitress told us she was from Hue, but she liked America better because there were more opportunities.  I convinced My Lady to try the sticky rice for dessert, which had a nice base of sweet beans and coconut on top.  All this joy came to $60.22 + tip.  The service was fast, friendly, and attentive, and they earned a nice tip.  

I am very happy with this discovery, and I am sure we will return.
author: David D.

description:
What a great day for Pho!!!  Came here today with one of my workers and Tony H, from Hard Knox.  I told him that I am going to teach him how to eat Vietnamese food...........him being Vietnamese and I being Chinese was already kinda funny.  A Vietnamese guy who owns a soul food restaurant being taught how to eat Vietnamese food from a Chinese guy who sells insurance.  A great comedy in the making. Onto the food..............

Imperial roll (this is the way you are suppose to make traditional rolls.  Rice paper!!! The lettuce and mint leaves were super fresh.  I always like it when restaurants serve their imperial rolls with this and the pickled carrots and vermicelli.) 8.50

Vietnamese potstickers ..(exact same ingredients as the imperial rolls but with crispy rice flakes.  It's different.  Just stick with the imperial roll)
8.50

3 bowls of Pho dac biet 8.50 each.  Broth is awesome.  You can tell that this base has been marinading.  Beef and tendons are of very high quality.

Total 47.00

I didn't treat so it tasted even better. hahahah.  Thanks Tony H. for the meal.   Like Mai H said.............I don't mind paying a little bit more for this quality of food.  Plus she was the one that recommended this restaurant to me.  This restaurant will run you 15% more than your mom and pop places but it is well worth it.

The service was awesome.  The water was refilled all the time and the food came out in a timely manner.  You can always tell from a great Vietnamese restaurant by their fresh condiments.  I think they might even grow the stuff themselves.  

Overall.  An excellent lunch.
author: jason g.

description:
WHAT THE FXXX!
It should not be like it.
I ordered Spicy beef noodle soup but the noodle was WAY OVER COOKED and SOGGY!
WHY WHY WHY, Over cooked soggy noodle?
Over cooked soggy noodle isn't right, No good piece of crap for no matter where you from.
The noodle break between chopstick!
Noodle breaks between chopstick means:
1. use old noodle
2. the noodle isn't fresh made.
3. the noodle is packaged and over cooked.
4. the cook doesn't care for noodle.
5. soggy.
What the Hell is it?
Authentic Vietnamese My Ass!
I know Vietnamese places a lot better than this.
It's too bad because everything else was pretty good.
But a noodle like that, DISAPPOINTED!
BIG DISAPPOINTED!
Eating Noodle is very important thing in my life!
author: Nobu K.

description: Great Vietnamese food! We came here on a Monday night and had the best service we've had in years! Our water glasses were never 1/2 empty, the food came out hot and tasty. The imperial rolls are to die for! Very cute family run type place with good quality food. Only problem is parking on Clement street ugh!
author: Michelle H.
