description: I was very disappointed with the food.  Ordered veggie noodles, eggplant curry and vegetable curry.  I expected more given the great reviews.  The sauces were not to my liking and the presentation totally lacking.  The atmosphere  was pleasant and the service was excellent.  Great location.
author: Dina L.

description: Excellent local restaurant that is clean, tasty, and rarely has a long wait. The French/Vietnamese mix I enjoy much more than typical Vietnamese cuisine and portion sizes tend to be large- and considering how tasty it is without being super expensive this place is one of my absolute favorites!
author: Double T.

description:
The Chronicle article on Vietnamese rolls dragged us here.  Good amount of leafage and taste with that dish.  For folks that don't know how to properly eat this dish- you get a piece of lettuce, place the fried roll on top, toss a little noodles and pickled veggies, dip and bite.  It's that easy!  

We also tried the eggplant in the garlic sauce  (looks a little weird because they peel the skin off) and also had the steamed sea bass (f'ing tasty!!! watch for the bones).  Really excellent service where you don't have to ask for water or more rice, it just comes like its bottom-less.  Parking sucks on Clement, so try looping around 1-2 blocks away.  Really looking forward to coming back to try more of the menu.
author: Jason A.

description:
3.75

We came here on election night after strolling around the neighborhood before heading to a campaign party.  

Kinda pricey for Viet food, especially since it was just the two of us, but it was pretty good.  We ordered the sampler appetizer, crab fried rice, tofu curry thing, and this seared meat dish.  Oh yea and two Thai Iced teas.

Sampler appetizer: it's a do it yourself spring rolls, comes with the rice paper, a selection of beef and shrimp, veggies, noodles, and sauce.  It was pretty good and it makes me miss making spring rolls with the BF (we haven't made any for at least a year). The appetizer also came with Imperial Rolls, which were pretty tasty.

Crab fried rice was okay, I wasn't really a fan of it because I don't like onions but the BF loved it.  I probably would've liked it more without the onions, however they did have big pieces of crab meat in it.

Tofu curry thing, was a mix of veggies and tofu in curry but a bit to spicy for me so I didn't really touch it that much.

The seared meat thing (because I forgot the name), this was probably my favorite dish of the night.  I LOVED the vinaigrette that came with it.  If you ate the meat by itself, it was sorta sweet but if you dipped it in the  vinaigrette it was tangy lime-ish sour.  SOOO good. 

Nothing too special with the Thai Iced tea.. I've had better.

Overall the food was pretty good and tasty.  The hot tea they served was one of my favorites.  Oh and the decor of the restaurant is really cool especially with the glass covered wooden tables which contained intricate vases under them.
author: Natalie G.

description:
5 stars people!  5 stars!  

I gotta say, I've read other reviews that say they don't serve big enough portions.  If you feel that way, then you eat too much.

I've been going there for about the last 4 years and it's consistent.  It's freaking yummy!!!  We usually go there once a month and somehow the staff always seems to remember us.  They're really nice people and work as quick as they can to get your food to you.  The establishment has definitely improved from what it looked like before.  The place is very clean and maybe just a little tight.  It's all good though cause the food is worth it.

It definitely isn't one of those dirty and cheap pho joints that you find just anywhere.  Don't expect to go here and find yourself a dozen variations of pho.  Because of this, it is just a little more expensive than what you would expect from a Vietnamese restaurant.  But again, the food is worth it.

If you go, try the friend banana with coconut ice cream for dessert.  Sooooooo delicious!
author: Duckie A.

description:
The best pho I have had in the city.  

Very generous with the portion =)

It costs $8.50 a bowl, but its worth every penny!
They give you a lot of meat and the meat tastes GREAT!!!!  Tender, flavourful, , just plain yummy.  The quality of the meat is just awesome!

I never wanna leave the place without finishing my pho.  Gotta try their other stuff too......... soon..............
author: Mai H.

description:
I came here a couple nights ago with 10 other people as part of a Meetup event.

FOOD:
I had the vegetarian spring rolls and Shaken Beef.  The springs rolls were OK.  The beef was mediocre - every piece was tough at the center.  Two people had the garlic noodles and both said the dish was very salty.  I tried the green papaya salad and it was bland, very little taste of anything.  The lotus root salad was OK.

SERVICE:
Service was pretty bad.  They lost track of two orders, didn't clear the tables completely, had some delays, and had trouble getting the bill correct.  It was a bad combination of an inexperienced server and a large group.

The owner gave all of us a complimentary dessert - I think it was jasmine ice cream with fried bananas.  Not enough to make up for mediocre food and service.

DECOR/CLEANLINESS:
Restaurant was recently renovated and it has very nice minimalist look.  Bathroom was clean.
author: David C.

description:
Ok, first off:

Why the heck is this restaurant listed under "Korean" food?
There is no Korean food on the menu.
In fact, the name specifically mentions that it's Vietnamese Cuisine for gawdsake.

But that's not the restaurant's issue.

Anyway:
FOOD HERE IS AWESOME! AWESOME!!!
And if you thought that vietnamese food was only pho and those tasty sandwhiches then you are in for some yummmmy surprises!

Favorite dishes there include the vietnamese style stuffed omelet, the beef look luk, and the seabass.
OMG the seabass is like... the KOBE of seabass!
They must give the fish backrubs and sake and classical music and hot underaged asian poontang or something but... that fish is TASTY and fricking melts in your mouth.

Delight! I go there about 2x a month.
Never had a bad experience there ever. EVAR.
And everyone I've brought there has declared it among there new favorites.
author: Min Jung K.

description:
We walked in on a Saturday afternoon and they were relatively empty compare to other restaurant around. We decided to try anyway.

We ordered:
1)Imperial roll: 5 stars. Execellent taste, very crispy, mint leaves are fresh like we never seen.
2)Rice crepe: 4 stars. Very tasty. Would have been a 5 stars if it wasn't for the Imperial roll. Crispy, fresh, just right.
3)Lemon grass pork chop vermicelli: 3.5 stars. Good taste, nothing stands out.
4)Cube beef streak(Lok Luc): 2.5 stars. Not many restaurants do this right. But, this dish is my ultimate test. 

Waiters are 5 Stars for this class of restaurants. Very nice and attentive, could be because of the slow day.

Overall: 3.5 stars if possible.
author: SP Y.

description:
I brought my family to this place when they were in town. I live in San José and don't get a lot of opportunities to sample Vietnamese cuisine in the city, so we came by Le Soleil after finding them on Yelp.

First off, the restaurant is very clean and well decored. As for the menu, it actually confused me and my mom at first because the dishes were listed in English instead of Vietnamese. (My Vietnamese is not great but I know what all my favorite dishes are called!) However, our waitress was very helpful: She let us read the waitstaff's "annotated" menu with the Vietnamese names written in. It was a big help.

Because of this, we were a little concerned that the cuisine would be too Americanized, but all the food was delicious. The beef "look luck" (i.e., bò lúc lác or "shaken beef") was tender and flavorful. The spicy lemongrass chicken (gà xa ót) was good as well, although prepared a little differently from the traditional style with a somewhat "wetter" sauce and string beans. The price was a bit high for Vietnamese food ($14 a head) but warranted by the quality of the preparation. Overall a very good dining experience.
author: Tony L.

description: The food is good. But it's very overpriced. I ordered a special dish that was tiger prawns on top of garlic noddle. I'm sorry but any shrimp and a noodle isn't worth $30.
author: Samuel L.

description: Yum. I always get the Banh Xeo here (pancake wraps). Very fresh. Comes out with super crisp and fresh veggies to put in your wrap. Very satisfying and close to mom's home cooking. Try the spring roll and the garlic noodles, their classic items. Not cheap and not expensive either. But you are paying for what you get.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: My sister and brother-in-law took us there last weekend, as they live in San Francisco and frequents this restaurant often.  It was our first time and the food was excellent!  The service was wonderful.  Loved the infused water, too! When we're in San Francisco, we definitely would return!
author: Y F.

description:
I've eaten here twice. The first time was take out for lunch. I had the pho and my friends had a couple of other dishes. All in all I liked.

Then I went for dinner this past Saturday (Dined In), They have a more upscale fancier menu for dinner time. At first I was a little eh, because I wanted my Bun Bo Thit Nuong. Instead I ordered a couple of a la carte dishes and I must say it was quite delish.

We ordered the lemongrass pork chops, Green beans and chicken fried rice. The pork chops I had were a lil dry-esque for some, but for me I didn't mind it well done to a crisp. I kinda like it like that, sprinkle some of that Vietnamese sauce sauce and your good to go.
author: Kris C.

description:
We ate family-style with some meat-eating friends on one half of the table, vegetarians-only on the other half.  The meat eaters ordered the Seafood Curry and Ox-Tail stew. Garlic beans and other tofu products were on the vege side. The portions were small and prices were moderate to high.  With that combination, you're basically never going to win me over unless the food is absolutely spectacular.  Overall, the food did nothing to "wow" me or offend me.  Thus, the three stars.

I ordered the Mango Salad and Eggplant Tofu Curry to go and it was equally small-proportioned, inoffensive and unspectacular for $23.00 (including tip), I'm sad to report.

However, the Banh Xeo was perfect in proportion and taste and made for a great appetizer.  It's pretty much the only reason to go out of my way to return to this restaurant.
author: Michael W.

description: Usually like this place,but they have gotten very sloppy and no longer clean.  Floor was so sticky, I had to wash the soles of my shoes. When we asked for salt, they handed us a shaker that was greasy and sticky.  They lack caring about the customer. They were off on so many things , but never offered an apology or comp us for a glass of wine or dessert.  You can do much better elsewhere.
author: Susan T.

description:
Really great home style cooking. I thoroughly enjoyed my dining experience there. The menu had a nice variety. We ordered beef w/ lemongrass and pan fried noodles with garlic and shrimp. The noodles were a home run. Really really good. Beef was tender and went well with the meal. Iced coffee (a must) also yum. Perfect compliment to a lovely meal. 

The place was packed. We had to wait, there were two tables before us and people came in after us and waited to be seated. I'm not sure if they take reservations, but it might be worth it if you don't want to wait during the rush. 

The restaurant was really well decorated. I wish I took photos of the tables, they were tempered glass on top of wooden tables with ceramics displayed in between. Lighting was nice and dim enough to be considered romantic if you were going for that. Nice date place! We got a seat in the corner by the window so were more secluded, which I think made for a nice meal.

The service could have been more attentive, but I'm not going to knock them since there were only two servers and no one helping out with the demanding crowd.
author: Annie T.

description:
This place is one of my FAVE restaurants in SF.

I've been coming here for years with my family. it's a cute and cozy little space with great food. whenever i come here, whether it's with my whole family (and I'm Filipino, so i have A LOT of relatives) or just with my boyfriend, we always have a perfect night.

order the flaming beef with prawns. it's AMAZING.
the cook it right at your table so you get a show along with your meal.
the beef look luck is so tender and perfectly marinated.
the fried imperial rolls are crunchy and full of flavor.
the chicken in a clay pot.. the chicken and cabbage salad.. 
i could go on and on about the many dishes i adore at this place, but i won't or I'll end up typing out most of the menu.

the drinks are good too.
the Vietnamese coffee is really good. so is the Thai tea.
I've never had the beer, but my uncle always gets it and he says their selection is pretty good.

all in all, this is a great restaurant.
its a small little hole in the wall on the end or clement st.
larger parties can be a problem seeing as its so small, but if you call ahead of time, they'll be happy to accommodate you :]
author: Michelle P.

description:
So we were in rush, I was famished, and we needed to find someplace close enough to walk to G3 where a band I wanted to check out was playing. I saw this sign and immediately headed towards it. 

The restaurant was completely packed! But luckily enough for us, we came just in time to be seated at the only vacant table left. Vietnamese food, here we are!

Ordered spring rolls, garlic asparagus, and a wok-seared beef with something else that I can't remember. The waiter was quick and efficient. He recommended the last dish and it was delicious! Spooned over rice and sipping on some Vietnamese iced coffee, it was filling and hit just the right spot. 

Our waiter was awesome and always came by to refill my glass with water since I was super dehydrated and inhaled all that liquid!

I totally want to come back and try out some of their menu items. Hopefully, I won't be as rushed as I was this time.
author: Julia W.

description:
Over the past several years, I've watched as Clement Street has evolved from a pedestrian-scary (crosswalks + rolling four-way stops = get the hell outta the way) strip of Asian restaurants and markets of sometimes questionable nature into a boulevard destination for great dining and even some shopping and pampering (Peche Mignon, Ginger Day Spa - neither of which I've checked out, but both of which look alluring). One of the great mainstays this whole time has been Le Soleil vietnamese restaurant.

Le Soleil is the place you head to when you want your food to satiate, your wallet not to cry, and service to be steady. My husband and I have taken to getting a lot of take-out from here as of late, but it's a pleasant sit-down environment as well - especially after a recent sprucing up of the space a couple of years ago. The owner/manager is always friendly and easy-going, and ensures his staff is as well. 

So ignore the waft of pizza from Giorgio's on the corner, step inside, kick back with a thai iced tea (yes, it's a Vietnamese restaurant - I don't care), and order the beef luk lok, barbecued pork and garlic noodles. I can't confirm how authentic it is, but it sure does taste damn good.
author: Kiesha R.

description: Awesome vietnemese food! Best pho ga ever! I love his place!
author: Malcolm M.

description:
My coworker had been raving about this place for weeks.  For awhile I  think she was eating there weekly.  I was leaving work just as she was craving the bass so we walked real fast cuz it was real cold to Le Soleil.

The interior is lovely.  (Although I am still wondering how the framed Roman columns fit in with the otherwise Asian decor.) Our table had what appeared to be three small perfume bottles embedded in the center under glass.  

I didn't examine the menu as completely as normal since we knew that we were going to order blocks before arriving. 

We had the sea bass with the garlic and soy green beans.  Sooo good.

Bonus points for offering brown (it looked more red than brown) rice in addition to white rice.

The service was good, but a little sloppy with the water.  Our glasses were frequently filled, but a big splash of water was added to our tableclothless table with every pour.

And wear a sweater because it was chilly in there.
author: Amy M.

description:
Le Soleil is one of my favorite "not-so-typical Vietnamese restaurants, " you know ones without the word "pho" in its name!  Very authentic and not the least bit fusion-esque.  Great for lunch or dinner, and everything I've ever ordered is always tasty and fresh.  Some of my favorites:  lemongrass coconut basil soup (I LOVE lemongrass!), spring rolls you wrap yourself, veggie bird's nest, and lemongrass chicken (told you I love lemongrass!).  

Moderate prices, clean and inviting atmosphere, nice wait staff, consistently good food and no wait time makes me coming back to Le Soleil.  Plus, I miss Le Cheval in old Oakland (used to work in that area for 6 years), so Le Soleil is a good replacement closer by.
author: Marie B.

description:
Ok. So, I have to say, that prawns wrapped in bacon is definitely one of my favorite things in life. Really. I mean, bacon just gives that salty flavor that is hard to beat. I even crave it.

That being said, the husband and I decided to pop into Le Soleil for some dinner. Being on this weird "no carbs" diet, I decided to forgo the imperial rolls and stick to just meat. As I perused the menu, the word bacon called out to me. Again, how can you say no to bacon? 

So, for dinner, we ordered the prawn wrapped in bacon with napa cabbage and carrots. Huge pieces of prawns  with huge slabs of bacon on top. YUM! There they were on the plate, 6 prawns with the bacon, just screaming EAT ME! And so, I did. Lots of flavor, lots of vegetables, and very filling.

The husband ordered the "Look Luck", which is the garlic beef. The beef came in tiny bite-sized pieces, which were tender and full of flavor. The citrus sauce was kind of sweet, but so tasty, I started to spoon the sauce over everything on my plate. 

Staff was friendly, prices were just right. Decor of the restaurant was nice, although sitting next to the fireplace on this warm night made it rather muggy inside. But overall, i thought Le Soleil was a great choice for dinner. I'll definitely go again when I am in the area.
author: Jan Z.

description:
It is a rare SF restaurant where the service is this good and the servers are as knowledgeable as the kitchen staff. The attention to patrons here isn't just good, the service is comparable to cities outside of SF. The bathroom is stylish, large, and extremely clean. These factors alone put the restaurant in very good company. 
I've been here about four times for lunch with a friend. The menu is a relief - not too long. The kitchens focus is quality not quantity. The food gives you the impression that they are proud of what they create.
Lemongrass beef lunch special is excellent, incredibly tender. Grilled pork is wonderfully smoky with read barbecue smoky flavor - the real thing.
Appetizers are all creative with playful texture. Soups have unusually good flavors as well as texture.
Vietnamese coffee, both iced and hot are made from a custom blend. Salads are balanced and well done.
If you are new to Vietnamese food, then this place will make you fall in love with it. If you have only enjoyed banh mi and summer rolls, this place will introduce you to more.
I look forward to tasting more creations of this dynamic restaurant's chef and owner.
Dont come here if you are looking for cheap fast food - in fact, please go elsewhere.
author: Nan L.

description: Great food with great service. The spring rolls are great and the pork chops are delicious.  The prices aren't cheap but the food is worth it.
author: Adam M.

description: When I used to work across the street I would get takeout from Le Soleil. It was a bit more than the other places around but I never felt bad for giving them my money because they had great food. Nothing was too salty, oily, and the meat was always good (never fatty). Dinning in is also a nice experience because you can eat at a slow pace in a comfortable setting with attentive waiters instead of the normal loud and fast Vietnamese restaurants. The staff is very friendly and will take care of your needs quickly. I wish there was a place like this by my current job.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Yum. I wanna come back. 

We had:
Imperial Rolls - Good, although slightly burned for some pieces.
Some beef thing - I can't remember which one but it was GOOD.
Hot & Sour Soup of Catfish - Catfish was yummy; not a huge fan of the soup.
Five Spice Chicken - Delicious!
Crab Fried Rice - Yummm.
Soy & Garlic Green Beans - Pretty good.
Pan Fried Rice Noodles with Chicken - Pretty good.
Garlic Butter Noodles - Alright, wasn't a big fan.

As for drinks, I was disappointed that thai iced tea was almost $4. Didn't even know if I could've swallowed some thai iced tea that was $4.

But I will be back for that beef! If I can figure out which one it was...and for some scallops!
author: Sandy L.

description:
My wife and I have been coming here for over 20 years, from the time when it was called Garden House. We have never had a bad meal. I don't think they know how to make a bad meal. The vegetarian spring rolls are the best in the city, period. 

The service is also fantastic. They are always friendly and glad to see us. The kitchen gets a little backed-up when they are crowded though, so expect a slower-paced meal at busy times.

I couldn't recommend it more highly.
author: Keith W.

description: the curry short rib was great. however, the lamb chop was a bit raw to me, they should have ask how I want it to be cooked. apart from that, it tasted good, too.
author: Herman K.

description:
The food at Le Soleil is very authentic - and delicious!  It's served by helpful Vietnamese servers in a setting that's date-friendly (ie, this is not a hole in the wall).  The decor and food are pretty enough to allay the concerns of my white friends who are suspicious of ethnic restaurants that don't serve burritos.  Le Soleil is a great place for newbies to Vietnamese food -- and natives who miss the real deal.  Slanted Door who?

Faves
- Vietnamese Crepes (Ban Xeo)
- Beef Luc Lac
- Steamed Sea Bass
author: Tina T.

description:
The food does not justify the price. I ordered three things:
1) Garlic Noodles: Came out cold.
2) Beef Lok Luck: One of the worst version I ever had.
3) Clay Pot Shrimp. 2 tiny shrimp with heads on and 1 tiny shrimp with no head for over $15!
The food was not Americanized Vietnamese, it was not Fusion, it was not authentic, it was just plain bad. The dinner cost more than 40.00 and was not worth a single penny.
author: Erica B.

description: So happy you are back! I heart you Le Soleil. Walk to Green Apple, buy a book, go to Le Soleil and have lunch. Everybody wins.
author: C. S.

description:
Another one to add to the growing Clement Street arsenal.  This is tasty vietnamese fare with a wide menu selection including lots of vegetarian options.

Courteous and efficient staff.
author: Narendra R.

description: I finally had dinner here with my same friend.  I highly recommend this place.  Great service and wonderful meal.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Birthday girl in our circle of friends wanted to celebrate dinner here, so on a Saturday 11 of us w/reservations headed there. Street parking is limited but not that much better than other areas downtown, etc..

I thought it was French cuisine at first judging by how my friend pronounced the name of where we'll be eating, but decor & menu inside suggested an upscale Vietnamese cuisine... not the mom 'n pop pho houses. Despite the large group, we were seated promptly at a long rectangular table. Service was fairly good for attending a large group.

Two dishes that stood out in my mind: the combination appetizer and Beef Look Luck (whatever the tender marinated beef dish was called). I enjoyed making my own rolls w/ the fresh rice paper, and the marinated beef was just plain good. I could probably have just that and rice and would've been happy.

The bill came out ~$20/person and I was about 80% full. I'd go back to try that dish where they cook it at the table (we noticed that at other tables during dinner).

Food: 4/5
Decor: 3/5
Service: 3.5/5
Cost: 3/5
author: King L.

description:
After attending the Bluegrass festival last weekend, my friend and I decided to wander Geary and Clement Streets.  We poked our heads into a couple bars, played some pool, and listened to a juke box...and then realized we were hungry.  Something about Le Soleil drew us in (I think it was the guy in the window with the fried rolls of some sort).

We started with a chicken coconut mushroom soup that was nothing like we were expecting but ended up tasting very good.  Main courses were a chicken thing and a vegetable stir fry with some white rice.  The sauce on the veggies was kinda odd to me, it was just a thick gray goop that was not very appetizing.  All the food tasted very fresh though, and service was quick and attentive.  A pleasant meal, but not a place I'll come across the city to go to.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Shaken beef, curry prawns are delish!! Oxtail stew is not on official menu, but my parents come here often and knew it is sometimes available. Service is very attentive. The owner comes out to greet guests. Did not leave with parched "MSG" after-effects that you get from many Asian restaurants.  It gets busy, but not as packed as B-Star next door. Very nicely remodeled and nice bathrooms.
author: N c.

description:
I would have given this place 5 stars if it had the one and only dish I was craving. We came to Le Soleil b'c our original pick was too crowded but I wasn't disappointed at all. Le Soleil had a great selection but not overwhelming menu of appetizers, soups, meats, vegetarian dishes, noodles and rice. We started off with the corn, asparagus, and crab soup. This was good after we added a little white pepper. A little thick but still tasty. The imperial rolls are definitely a must order for any vietnamese restaurant and definitely this place. The marinated and sliced pork and shaking beef were excellent choices! The meat was flavorful and tender. The garlic butter noodles with egg was also a nice complement. 

Service was excellent and very friendly!

So the dish I was craving you ask....the vermicelli bowl with pork and imperial rolls with the fish sauce - yah, you know it. I'd try to spell it but I'd probably butcher and offend someone. The restaurant actually had all the ingredients for it but didn't offer it on the menu.... Otherwise, they just may have received 5 stars.
author: Josephine H.

description: I was really bummed when this place closed because we ate there frequently and really enjoyed the food.  I was really excited when I saw that it reopened....until I looked at the menu.  There's only one veggie option!  What a slap in the face.  This place used to be very vegetarian friendly, which is one of the reasons that we liked it so much.  It's surprising that they would take away all the veggie choices in a city with so many vegetarians.  I realize that not all places are veggie friendly and have no problem staying away from those, but this place used to be awesome and now they have given their vegetarian customers a huge middle finger and basically told us to go somewhere else.  Message received.  I guess from now on we will have to eat at Minh's instead.  Such a shame because I really liked the food before they eliminated most of their menu.
author: Katie B.

description: My fiance and I tried this gor the first time ever today while trying to figure out what we wanted to eat. We loved the decor, the atmosphere, the cleanliness, as well as the friendliness of our waiter. The only problem was, we didn't get to order exactly what we wanted. Supposedly, the person who was supposed to be there pan frying the dishes hadn't come in yet. We instead opted for their pho and lunch combos. I ordered the five season chicken combo and my fiance ordered the seafood pho. We also ordered an imperial roll appetizer, and vietnamese iced coffee, all of which was scrumptious! It definitely didn't taste like other, inexpensive vietnamese places we've tried before. We loved the food as well as our experience there. I give le soleil five stars regardless of the fact that we didn't get what we originally wanted. Trust me, it's that good over there!
author: Monica M.

description: Unbelievable pre-opening luncheon. Opened yesterday evening!  This place just never disappoints and now with it re-opening we will be there every chance we get!! Highly recommend the sea bass, crab with garlic noodles, and clay pot.
author: Corinne F.

description:
Excellent food, nice ambiance and decorating, and a clean bathroom. The attention to detail in everything from the food to the bathroom furniture left me feeling like somebody really cares about this place. I only spent a couple weeks in Vietnam but as far as I can tell this is very authentic gourmet Vietnamese food. It reminds me of this really upscale place we went to in Saigon where we literally had a waiter behind every chair.

Oh, and I noticed somebody criticizing them because they had two wait staff and a full house ... lets cut them a break shall we? Perhaps someone didn't show up for work that day? Or perhaps they are usually dead that day and they got an unusually large rush right when you showed up. Reserve service criticism for rude staff or slow service despite an abundance of waiters.
author: Thomas P.

description:
Le Soleil serves up some really tasty and filling dishes.  Here's what you should chow down on:

Classic Vietnamese 5-spice Chicken
Sizzling Seafood Platter

We also got the  Vietnamese Pot Stickers.

Appetizer, dinner for two, drinks for $42.
author: Jason R.

description:
The food didn't seem that authentic to me but I'm not Vietnamese.
It wasn't exactly bursting with flavor but the service was attentive and they seated us quickly on New Years Eve.
author: JaM W.

description: Had lunch.  Enjoyed the attractive, pleasing decor upon entering.  Had the luncheon specials.  Tasty coconut soup, delicious Imperial Rolls.  The chicken, rice and vegetable plate was spiced well.  The beef dish (over noodles) had exquisite flavors; however, the perfectly-done noodles seemed like that could have had some more flovors and I would have liked the noodles served hot.  Overall, we'll be back and  order off the ala carte menu.
author: Howard G.

description: very friendly service, great pho, and the appetizer platter is great!  If you love vietnamese food come here, they will also tell you where to find the ingredients to make it at home!
author: Rebecca W.

description:
People, will you please stop looking at me when I order the Flaming Beef? It was on the same menu you were perusing 10 minutes ago when you thought "Flaming" meant that it was super spicy and not, actually, on fire.

They prepare it at your table, in a bowl, sitting in a pool of flaming, cooking alcohol, on a plate. (And yes,  I have never used that many prepositions in one sentence before, thank you.) The server uses extra-long chopsticks (so as not to sear herself) to mix the beef, onions, tomatoes and goodness around. When it is done, she douses the alcohol with water and serves up the Flaming Beef with wet rice flour wraps and fresh mint, cilantro, carrots and that glorious fish sauce solution that you must pour all over the Flaming Beef and whoever is within spitting distance. It's that good.

Order, as well, the Butter Garlic Noodles. It's a good starch alternative to plain old rice. No need to order prawns or chicken in the noodles. It just dilutes the buttah.

For dessert, order the 3 bean jelly thingie. I have not actually paid attention to what this dessert is called, but I am always keen on ordering it in a large bowl. Because, how in the hail can you mix that dessert up in a tall narrah-ass glass? Really?  Nyooow.

Anyhoo, next time, order the Flaming Beef and have *other* people gawk at your fiery entree.
author: Rey T.

description:
Though the high prices make this place a rare treat for me, I really enjoyed the two trips I have made there. To start off, the ambiance is charming and the service is impeccably polite. 
Each time I went I ordered the Egg flower soup with blue crab meat, the mango salad, and the sizzling seafood platter. These dishes were ridiculously delicious, and I will order the exact same thing on my next visit. The total was around $40, so, though it's up there for a poor college student like me, it is affordable for many and totally worth it.
author: A. A.

description: We love Le Soleil restaurant. My daughter love eating meat ball noodle soup every time she comes here and she is almost 3 years old. She said Pho was so yummy. The soup tastes so fresh and delicious. I love roasted crab with garlic noodles, my favorite! My husband love the lunch menu, he always orders Bun bo nuong cha gio BBQ beef and imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles, it comes with a small soup! The price is reasonable and the the service is very good!
author: Kim L.

description: The new dinner menu has more of Chef Wong's specialties and unique dishes. The curry short ribs are the best...and taste even better the next day. You can't go wrong with the shaking beef or the lamb chops either. Have to try the lunch menu next time...the escargot soup sounds awesome!
author: Cindy T.

description:
Dishes are not novel or inspired but are always delicious at this reliable Vietnamese restaurant on Clement.  With a full menu--from garlic noodles to fresh clams to bbq lemongrass beef--this isn't just another pho shop.   Recent  renovations, designer furniture and moderate price increases lead one to wonder if the restaurant has been sold or simply aspires to be  the Slanted Door.  But for now, thankfully, the food remains solid and unchanged--even if it is now served on rectangular green plates.

Or so I've been told.  Regrettably, San Francisco's arcane and prejudicial health regulations do not allow me to dine in this restaurant.
author: spot d.

description:
Tasty goodness!

Imperial rolls, Crepe, Beef look luk, shrimp fried rice and a fried banana for desert!

Order it and you won't be disappointed!
author: Keith A.

description:
Not cheap but very very delicious food. Some of the menu items borrow Thai and Chinese flavors which makes it interesting. Everything we ordered was fantastic. We got:

Garlic noodles: a MUST
Appetizer Sampler: marinated steak, imperial rolls (!!!!!!), shrimp with all the fixins (lettuce, pickled vegis, mint, etc)
Beef with green beans
Chicken dish - ground chicken with peppers. spicy!
Mango salad - highly recommend
Sauteed tofu and vegis - eh, okay

Favorites definitely were the garlic noodles and imperial rolls. Great place for a sit-down Vietnamese lunch or dinner.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
went here today and we were very very very disappointed.  We ordered our two favorite dishes to go and it was horrible.  At approx. $8 dollar per dish we expected better.  

Crab fried rice -bland.  bland. bland.

Combination pan fried noodle with gravy sauce - portion was small and bland
author: L C.

description:
Probably the best Vietnamese restaurant on Clement Street. The food and service is good, you do get a lot for your money. The place is pretty clean compared to others on this street. Some dishes may lack consistency at times. But this is a place I would certainly return to.

Overall, 3 1/2 stars.........
author: L K.

description:
I tried this restaurant after walking past it many times to get to B Star right next door, and after hearing good things about it from my boyfriend's co-worker. 

The restaurant is cute and the lighting is warm and soft, which made everyone look nice. For some reason, at least on the night we went, there was no music. I think it needed music. 

I liked the crispy vegetarian imperial rolls, served with leaf lettuce, rice noodles and mint. I loved the salty plum soda, which has a smashed up salty plum in the bottom of the glass! I was a little disappointed with the soft shell crab dish. I know it's not fair to compare to Slanted Door (there's a reason Slanted Door has such a loyal following and you have to make a reservation months ahead of time for a weekend night), but Slanted Door's soft shell crab is so delicately battered and fried and just so delicious and complex tasting... Le Soleil's was heavily battered and fried, so it didn't look like a little crab anymore... it could have been a piece of fried fish, or a piece of fried zucchini, or a piece of fried anything. The oiliness overpowered the crab-ness, and although the portion was very generous (four little crabs), we ate one each and declined the others. 

We also ordered a grilled chicken dish, which is served with rice wrappers, and you roll it all up yourself. They give you a stack of plastic steamer separators with the delicate rice wrappers between the separators, but we got an empty stack. I politely explained this to our server (I wasn't mad, I thought it was kind of funny) and he explained to me that between each separator is a rice wrapper... etc.
I explained that I understood, but there really were no wrappers in the stack. After some back and forth he lifted some of the separators and, looking surprised, disappeared with them and came back with the wrappers. 

It might have just been an off night for Le Soleil, but we probably won't go back, because it was just okay, and there are other really delicious places so nearby.
author: Dani Y.

description: Had a mixed experience. The chicken coconut soup had very chewy chicken, but the green papaya salad was yummy. I like that it's quiet enough to bring people with difficulty hearing, but found it a bit expensive for the quality.
author: Sassafras F.

description: To me, this will always be the original Slanted Door.  I've been coming here for 15+ years and it's always a good meal.  The catfish soup is awesome.  The shaking beef is also a fave, and while it's not as good as the Slanted Door's, you won't have to break the quarters-only piggy bank to pay for it.
author: Ernest S.

description:
Been coming back for years. Look forward to visiting my mom at work for an excuse to come to this restaurant. 

Service always friendly and attentive.

Food is fantastic. Fresh and reasonably priced - lunch is super filling for $8. Get the imperial rolls, crab fried rice and bbq pork chops. Also pan fried noodles are great.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
The colonial Vietnamese restaurant formula strikes again: villa storefront, French name, menu in English, abundance of "lemongrass" this and "exotic" that.  If you still find that sort of thing amusing, but have the self-respect to avoid Danted Sloor, you could visit Le Soleil.

Actually, Le Soleil used to be a good Vietnamese restaurant, even if the menu was mostly in English.  But now it's something else, with mostly non-VN staff, and the target customer market coming for the newest bourgeois bohemian indulgence, that exotic Vietnam flavor.  You know it's a certain type of place when it advertises itself as "authentic."  Everything is heavily sugared (and no, it's not just the Southern VN cooking style), and it's a creepy Polynesian-kitch-restaurant flashback that they have a fondness for the varied culinary possibilities of the pineapple.  Can I have a mai-tai?

Le Soleil is neither as expensive nor as stupidly pretentious as Danted, the servers are serviceable, and the food isn't terrible.  It could be a gentle introduction to Vietnamese food.  The lack of spice and seasoning could be a benefit for certain crowds.  But the place has limits.  Any of the linen-tablecloth Vietnamese restaurants in San Jose would give Le Soleil a smackdown.
author: Non P.

description:
Eh, I know, I'm in the minority on this one, but I thought Le Soleil was one of the more disappointing vietnamese meals I've had in the city.

Full disclosure before I write more - we were in the mood for pho, and our original destination was closed, so this became plan B. And we came to learn they don't serve pho (at least for dinner).

But the menu was still very appealing, and shared between us:

1. Chicken and pineapple soup
2. Chicken rice wraps
3. Steamed asparagus. 

Complaints in order

1. Not nearly enough chicken and pineapple
2. Minimal options to fill the wraps, and the chicken was super oily
3. Perhaps steamed, but then covered in some oil based sauce

It didn't feel healthy or filling.

And when you add in minimal service, to the point where it was at least 15min between our plates being cleared and our check, it clearly was a disappointment.

Others around us seemed to be enjoying much more appealing entrees, perhaps it was our ordering. But I was not impressed, and would not recommend.
author: Jason B.

description: This is my second time eating here. They have recently remodeled and updated their menu. We ordered the Imperial egg rolls, Lotus root salad, Shaken beef and garlic noodle.  The Lotus root salad is very good and unique. Also, I really love their garlic noodle, not very greasy. This is one of the hidden gem in the Richmond district.
author: Christine S.

description:
So last week I was home (that is: not at work) with what seemed like a cold.  I was sniffling, sleeping, not feeling good.  In fact I was whining- to myself I might add.  If talking to oneself is bad, and answering is crazy, then whining to yourself is total-tinfoil hat-batshit nuts.  I'm glad I was able to conquer my mental illness and make it out of the house.  Anyhoo, I digress.

Point is, I was feeling under the weather and wanted some chicken soup.  Seemed like an appropriate thing to do. Cold+Me= Chicken soup.  Simple math.  Seeing as how I abhore canned food as much as possible, and how I had been lying in a puddle of self-pity watching terrible daytime TV for several hours, I decided not to go to Arguello Supermarket and get a can of soup.  No! I would boldly resist my cold viruses (virii?) and venture across Geary to Clement and get some chicken soup, dammit. 

Somehow I ended up at Le Soliel.  Probably because I was sick and tired of walking and Soliel was right there.  I went in and would've gotten their imperial roll/bbq pork lunch special but I was there for soup!  And lo and behold, out comes the most bland soup I've ever had.  Even the noodles surprised me at their boring-ness, and I go into a noodle eating situation with every intention that the noodles were boring.  These were really, really boring noodles.  And the chicken was somehow dry, despite being served in hot soup.  Don't understand that one myself, but I took a bite of the chicken and said, "Damn! That's some fucking dry chicken!".

Should've gone to Pho Clement.  Oh well, live and learn.  I did go home and watch Cool Runnings on cable though, and that cheered me up even though I still get kinda choked up at the end when they crash their bobsled and they all (even Sanka Coffee!) has to carry the sled across the finish line to finish the race.  Powerful cinematic moment if you ask me.

Good service, bland food, nice decor.  Two Stars.
author: Jake S.

description:
Downhill alert! I used to love this place, especially since most Vietnamese restaurants down Clement Street leave something to be desired in the cleanliness department. However, a pleasant decor and tablecloths do not make up for the poor dining experience I had last week, when I ordered my usual order of rice noodles with lemongrass beef. Previously, I've really loved Le Soleil's version of this, since they used to serve very fresh ingredients: herbs, lettuce, seasoned, grilled meats and always threw in some pickled onions - yes! 

However, my last meal there, the beef was chewy and gristly but tasted okay, all the way to the very last bite, which unfortunately, was off -- as in BAD, very BAD, leaving a liver taste in my mouth that I had trouble washing out even hours later. I still get the shivers thinking about whether I was permanently poisoned. Thankfully, I did not get sick (I've had that happen before), but I'm not going back. 

You take your chances.
author: Melissa G.

description: I came here for dinner with my family last week and was surprised with how attentive the service is at this family run establishment.  The Shaking Beef, House Fried Rice, and Curry Prawns were delicious.  I heard this place recently went through a remodel and it shows.
author: Casual C.

description: Our dinner with this place is wonderful.  I can said De Soeil will be my favorite Vietnamese's restaurant.  We was order many dish, all every dish are delicious.  The service are great.
author: Kittisak L.

description:
This is a nice sit down vietnamese restaurant. I have never dined in before. I always take out and the food is good! The portion is very generous and the service is fast. It's my fave place to order for my lunch =)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
06/10/07

Okay, I have to revise and take two stars off from the awful service I got today. I'm having a terrible headache and tummy ache from my hang over and I needed to eat immediately. My stomach was in pain so I called to order take out but this waitress told me to call back in 5 minutes because they were really busy! Boo hoo! I'm sorry for not being sympathetic or whatevs but restaurants on the weekend are always busy and they can't even take a simple to go order? Ask me to call back in 5 minutes?! It just doesn't make any sense to me. What kind of restaurant would turn down an order? I called the second time and this guy hung up on me!! If I wasn't in hang over pain and I wasn't starving, I would've probable waited though it wouldn't justify their action. Too bad. 

You're too busy for me, I will gladly take my business somewhere else.
author: Perry S.

description:
Our late-night quest for Vietnamese Hot and Sour soup led us into the pricey but promising Le Soleil.  Since our favorite spot is closed on Sundays, we thought we'd indulge in the fine dining the prices foretold.  But wishy washy wait-staff left us wondering whether we would ever get our food.  

The hostess's face lit up when I asked what time they closed, as if she'd alighted on a bright idea.  After pausing to weigh the propriety of her approach, she ventured, "9:45pm," then as if she'd just rubbed off a lottery ticket and wanted to see whether fortune was with her, she challenged us:  "What time is it?"  Discouraged by our 9:25pm answer, she seated us, asked with a still smoldering spark of hope whether we might be in a rush, scowled at our non-affirmative answer, failed to bring us a 2nd menu, nearly tipped over my water glass during a "drive-by" set down, informed me that only 1 of the three Vietnamese beers on offer was in stock, and all-in-all left us feeling like we'd better hurry up and spend our money or she might just complain to our supervisor!  

Fortunately, the hot and sour soup was good.  Or maybe we just really, really wanted it.  Actually, it was a bit too hot and not quite sour enough. 

But at least the place had ambiance.  A nice Vietnamese screen partially blocked wonderful views of the kitchen and bathrooms, and the acoustics were cleverly designed so my wife -- Laura -- and I had less difficulty hearing a voluptuous, early-twenty-something rescheduling her manicure by cell phone and telling her date about all that befell her after posing for Playboy than we were able to hear each other.   Maybe I was just distracted by the soup.

Well, at least the clientele were interesting.

Won't be going back anytime soon.  

Unless it's a Sunday...

p.s.  Laura just read this review and tells me that the sass wasn't talking about Playboy at all, but rather about something to do with a clothing line she'd released.  Hmmm.  What DID they put in that soup...
author: Darryl K.

description:
I've walked by Le Soleil so many times over the years but never went in.  For some reason, I thought it was a French restaurant, but it's Vietnamese!!  

Just had lunch here today with an ex-coworker and it wasn't bad.  I liked the decor and the service was excellent.  We split the Vietnamese Crepe and the BBQ Pork and Imperial Rolls with Rice Noodles.  The crepe was huge and packed full of bean sprouts.  I like bean sprouts as much as the next person, but that was a LOT of bean sprouts!  The BBQ Pork and Imperail Roll dish was typical.  It tasted the same as it does at every other Vietnamese restaurant I've been to.
author: Kris L.

description:
Well this place was always a fave to take Jack to on his birthday but I suspect we'll change it up this year.  Just recently went with our hardcore Vietnamese friend and it seems that the quality was reflecting the menu.  Not as Vietnamese and more Americanized.  Which I guess just means that it's not as authentic tasting and as good as it used to be.

Some of the dishes like the omlette were still good but some of the featured entrees seemed to be a bit less punchy and flavorful.  

Ah well, I guess the 100% in English menu might have been a tip off... Still decent though this city has some rocking spots,
author: Gene X.

description:
I've been here several times over the past... at least 6 years. They've gone through a lot of ownership changes so I've seen the staff, decor, and food change. I'd say my 18th birthday dinner here a long time ago was way more memorable than the dinner I had here a few nights ago -- well not just because of the fact that it was my birthday, but food-wise too!

The food is good, but nothing spectacular. I wouldn't call it authentic Vietnamese cuisine, but it's definitely not fusion either. Can't go wrong with the bo luc lac! The mango salad was highly disappointing -- the mangoes were sweet and mushy; in traditional Vietnamese cuisine, they should be green (or at least more on the sour side than sweet) and crunchy. 

Important to note: If you want the crab, make sure to call ahead of time and let them know! They don't have it on hand because they buy the crab fresh from the market to order.
author: Miss H.

description:
We used to come here in the early 2000s, they have since changed the decor and the menu, but we were happy to find they still serve some great Vietnamese.

The lotus salad was good, a bit spicy for me.  The Saigon marinated pork slices were just perfect, and the blue crab fried rice was top notch.  The service was very good. 

You pay a bit of a premium for the nice decor and service, entirely worth it as it makes for a more special dining experience, good for a date or for special guests.
author: Localista I.

description:
Always saw this place and never went in, until a routine Monday closure at Pot de Pho forced us to look for an alternative tonight.  It definitely looked promising, though there was no pho on the menu.  Fair enough - this is not a pho kinda place.  Still in the mood for soup (feeling under the weather and all), the three of us shared a lemongrass coconut chicken soup.  We had to order two bowls because one is not enough for 3 to share.  Pretty good...not memorable.  Could have used more substance (more chicken, more pineapple...that's their thing).  We also shared "steamed" asparagus that came out in a sauce and definitely looked more sauteed than anything else.  Again, fair enough...they were definitely tasty asparagus, but not steamed (I know my health-conscious dining pal was peeved).

But the biggest disappointment was with the "Table-side fire grill chicken", with which came rice paper and all the fixings to make small rolls.  There was no fire, there was no grill.  More upsetting was the fact that we saw a table with a flaming piece of meat that looked amazing.  Are we not good enough for a flame?  The chicken (and resulting rolls) were good, but not memorable.  And frustratingly, as we sat and ate perhaps our ill-ordered items, I had table envy.  I wanted that flaming beef at table 2.  I wanted those delicious looking rolls at table 4.  I wanted the crispy little dumplings at table 7...

If I go back, I'll be sure to order differently...as there's nothing more frustrating than not getting what you thought you were getting.  OK service, kinda slow, and water refilling was slow too.  Then again, I know I was a total camel tonight and for some reason or another, kept drinking water like it was going out of style.  Fair enough.
author: Louis M.

description:
Certainly not the most authentic Vietnamese, Le Soleil does the job when it comes to entertaining. They have upgraded the decor continuously over the past decade. It's a great place for food that's very decent but attuned to the Western palate. 

Parking is a bit tough in the neighborhood.
author: R K.

description: Have been eating here for almost 20 years and it's as good now as it was then.  We especially love the Vietnamese Crepe and the Flaming Beef & Prawns.  The service is always impecable and the check is continually reasonable.  We take out of town guests here - always.
author: G G.

description:
Pouring rain + steaming hot bowl of Pho = heaven. With all the rain we have been having lately I confirmed this equation once again today at lunch.

They do a pretty good bowl of Pho here, but their Imperial Rolls are the best in the city that I have been able to find so far. Prices did go up after their renovation, and they are definitely priced higher than your average hole in the wall Pho place, but they don't dent the pocketbook too badly.

This isn't a "drive across the city" kind of Vietnamese place, but if you are in the neighborhood and need some decent Vietnamese food (especially if it is raining), be sure to check it out.
author: Brad Y.

description:
I am so fortunate to live within walking distance of this restaurant.  But, I drive anyway.  There's a children's toy store across the street, whose owner let's anyone park there for free.  I go there for carryout and sit-down dining.  Here's why:  The staff there are the most friendly people you could ever meet.  The food is the best Vietnamese you could ever eat.  And, the service is lickety-split quick.  It is a quiet environment, filled mostly with local adult patrons.  

Once, I phoned in my favorite carryout dish for dinner and mistakenly got the price off the lunch menu.  They knocked a dollar off the price anyway and still gave me a dinner-size portion, taking two days to finish eating!

This restaurant has won its share of awards, too.  Highly recommended over the hour-long wait for Burma Superstar.
author: Tony L.

description: Eh, the thing that the love and i liked were the imperial rolls. they were so delicious, that we probably could have had another dish and called it a meal. i don't know if we ordered the wrong food from the menu or what, but the clay pot rice was just alright (the sausage had an interesting flavor), and the five-spice chicken was not my cup of tea. the seating was a little awkward as well. i was also disappointed about the lack of noodle dishes on the menu, and i was expecting at least one pho dish. really good service and friendly employees, but i have had better vietnamese food.
author: Lisa B.

description:
I was excited to go here because the place is so cute.  However I was disappointed...my imperial rolls tasted like flour.  Those are my favorite part, so it really ruined the rest of my meal.  My  grilled beef vermicelli was just ok...I've definately had better....but it was better than the rolls.

I really like the atmosphere in here though.
author: Luci B.

description:
I can't honestly say the food is bad.  However, there is nothing that gets me more upset than a restaurant that charges you an arm and a leg and leaves you hungry!!!  For example, the green beans with garlic sauce dish (over $10) we ordered can literally be eaten in 3 bites, and I am only 160 lbs.  There were 6 of us eating family style dinner.  This type of dinning typically leaves you too full to walk out with plenty to take home.  But no, not this place.  We averaged over $20 each and had to order some plain white rice (with some free soy sauce) just because we were still hungry...   Oh yeah, we had to go to the kitchen to tell them what we wanted because service was slow.

Again, food is not bad.  But if you want even better vietnamese cuisine and more PORTIONS and reasonable price, go to Dragonfly on Sunset.  

My 1.5 cents
author: Mike H.

description:
decent, clean, casual restaurant with friendly staffs.
my fave here: Vietnamese Vegetarian Spring Rolls & brown rice with sm vegetables stir fry hmm yummmmmm cant wait to visit le soleil again :)
author: Ms C.

description: I ate the lemongrass beef with vermicelli. The quality is ok. You play extra $ for the atmosphere and also the better appearance. I have been told they just renovation recently.
author: Westcott S.

description:
Since my first visit to Le Soleil a couple of weeks ago, this little gem of a restaurant has quickly become my favorite go-to place for a satisfyig meal.  On my first visit I had their signature wok-tossed Luc Lac "Shaken Beef" which was tender, juicy and cooked to perfection. The lemon pepper dipping sauce that came with the dish added just the right amount of "tang" to the dish that I wanted to savor every morsel.

I wanted to try another one of their signature dish very soon, so on a lazy Friday night a week ago, I went back to Le Soleil to try their garlic roasted dungeness crab that chef Dennis recommended.  I did a yelp check-in and got a complimentary spring roll which was fresh and delicious.  I ordered half a crab pan fried in browned butter & garlic served over garlic egg noodles. There were big pieces of crab claws, legs and meaty pieces all perfectly roasted and oozing with a heavenly finger-licking sauce. I ate with gusto, but the order was large for one person. I also got a free light dessert of warm sweet tapioca and cream corn with coconut milk, which was also delicious.  The doggie bag of crab & garlic noodles that I took home was as good as the night before.  I was surprised that the egg noodle was still firm and chewy. The chef said it is their own special brand served only at their own restaurants.

I cannot decide which of the two dishes I liked more: the shaken beef or the garlic roasted crab?  When in doubt, try them both!
author: J L.

description: More high end than the most vietnamese noodle places you have been to. Good selection vietnamese cousines, not just noodles or spring rolls. Of course price is higher than the other noodle houses but its worth the extra bucks to try it out!
author: Angela H.

description: I have loved this place for years.  The look luck beef is tender and the sauce is so good.  Even spotted Amy Tan dining here for lunch awhile back.  Yum!
author: birdabee j.

description: Simply delicious. Came here on a whim after noting the 2-hour wait at Burma Superstar and was not at all disappointed. My friend and I had the beef look luck (*so* tender) and the eggplant, after which we still wanted more, so we ordered the stir fried chicken, which was garlicky yummy and hit the spot. I almost licked the plate. It's on the expensive side for Vietnamese cuisine, but the food and service is upmarket, so I'd say it's worth it. Brought back good memories of my visit to VN this summer....
author: amanda a.

description: Not a single thing I would call fantastic but everything was extra tasty if not as elegant as the dining room might portend. A solid dinner option in the Inner Richmond, which, in fact, does not need any help in that department. Any given block of Clement probably kicks the whole of Castro's butt, food-wise.
author: patrick g.

description: I love this place, the food was great ,lots of flavor.  The vegetarian dish was also tastey.  The presentation good, appetizing lots of color. There brown rice was great, not hard, The waiter Dave was very helpful and friendly.  I will go back for sure.
author: Susie S.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese restaurant, a friend of mine recommended to go here.... I have to say this is the best Vietnamese food that I've ever had, its not all fried and prepared in 5 minutes..... food is great, large selection and tastes great.... 

Its at a great location that you can do a lot of other things in the neighborhood, I was here the other night and loved the service and has a nice small feel of vietnam....
author: Len A.

description:
ok, the nice decor, (minus the pee yellow painted walls) the english only menu, and the lack of chopsticks made me really weary that they food was going to be remotely tasty.
boy was i glad i was wrong.

i recommend the sampler appetizer.  you get a lot of thin rice wrappers to load up on the nicely seasoned shrimp, grilled beef, pickles, and noodles.  with the authentic dipping fish sauce, each bite is heavenly.

oy, i ordered the softshelled crab with garlic noodles.  i was enjoying my bloated bliss till the server whisked away  my dish with fresh juicy tomatos before i could finish them.  boy that bothers me.

i took the dessert to go - coconut bean drink since i had to digest a bit.

i wonder if i spoke vietnamese, they'd give me a bilingual menu.  maybe i just looked like i'd butcher the words, who knows.

regardless, i have to go back and try out more, maybe after i run a few miles...
author: Anh V.

description: My aunt and uncle took us here for lunch one day. Everything, I mean, EVERYTHING we ordered was delicious. What got me hooked? The calamari. Try it.
author: Bee O O.

description: i love the 5 spiced chicken there. definitely recommend it. and it also comes with these amazing mouth watering imperial rolls. im actually getting hungry thinking about it.
author: Jordan P.

description: We were  just walking in the neighborhood and came up on this restaurant.  I ordered the crispy noodles with vegetables and it was delicious.  I also tried the eggplant curry which was a  bit bland but I asked for hot sauce on the side and...problem solved.
author: Swati K.

description: A nice place to grab lunch --  the pork was spot on, and the imperial rolls were addictively yummy.
author: Tim G.

description:
I don't know if this place was better before given the large number of high ratings.   I can only tell you that it was pretty bad when I and my girlfriend went there today.

1)  The rice was dried and hard by any Asian restaurant standards
2)  We ordered Egg Drop Soup.  It was over saturated with some form of corn starch making it basically slimey and not soupy at all.  It basically tasted poor.
3)  We ordered "Salt & Black Pepper Tiger Prawn" and you know what?  It was basically a super duper salty typical stir fry shrimp with onions and no pepper.  

No tiger prawns.  No pepper.  Just Salt.   We *did* ask the waiter if this was the correct dish his reply was "Yes this is how the Vietnamese style of cooking is".   I almost laughed because.... That doesn't make sense as my Vietnamese girl agreed was not true.  It was just a typical cheap Chinese stir fry dish done poorly with WAY WAY too much salt.

Maybe they were better before but I have to say avoid this place for now.
author: So L.

description: WOW....what a gr8 restaurant this is....for you who are looking for delicious vietnamese food...you gotta visit this place...they recently renovated the whole restaurant.....very homey..you have to try their flambed quail....with a yummy lemony sauce...it is a bit sour so if you enjoy sour like i do, then u would really like it...also you have to get their veggie spring rolls...it comes with a spicy sweet sauce...then save room for their peppery crab and garlic noodles....their crab is prepared very uniquely...as it is done with egg...the pieces of scrambled egg is perfect if you mix with the noodles or just a bowl of rice will do....hopefully your mouth is starting to water so hurry over there and don't forget to order a glass of ice coffee or tea with ur meal...it is just the perfect combo..
author: Mee-stique K.

description:
ooh, this place has yummy food, excellent decor - how do they make those tables with stuff under the glass? - and a lunch special that you can get at four pm!

it lives up to all the excellent reviews.  don't miss the fresh sweet and sour soup with shrimp and fresh veggies... to die for.
author: H.A. ..

description:
the exterior facade of this fancy restaurant doesn't match what they gratify to their customers.

if you were walking or driving by at this place, you would think that this is your typical hole-in-the-wall place, until you step in!!!

the furnishings are contemporary with nice, good-sized wood tables topped with glass with nice matching chairs and the lighting gives a pleasant, cozy atmosphere.

the platters that they used  were lovely and attractive which comes in different designs and shapes.

the foods were tasty & satisfying, but a little bit on a petite portion, which can still please your stomach! the crab meat fried rice was really tasty (you can really taste and see the crab meat) the pot stickers were crunchy and loaded with flavor and sans the hoisin sauce YET!
however, some of the meats in our bbq pork slices marinated in lemongrass were tough/chewy...but then again, it was delish!

moreover, prices are not that reasonable!!!!!
author: Nelle A.

description: This is my fave lunch restaurant during the week, when I'm working at home.  The staff knows me and is always super nice.  The food is good and plentiful.  My favorite dishes are the Shrimp, Beef with Rice Noodles, and the lunch special with their famous Chicken is good too.  The average cost for one person is about $10 with a drink (no appetizer).  It's got nice ambiance and pretty relaxed.  I like to hang out, eat lunch, and read a book to chill out.
author: Audra E.

description: really love the dinner here...menu is more sophisticated and upscale compared to the lunch menu, which is good as well.  Definitely come for dinner to get the full experience of this restaurant.  Make sure to come early during the weekend because it gets packed. The soups are great, and the salads are yummy.  We asked the waiter to recommend a dish from each category, BEEF, VEGETABLE, SEAFOOD, and CHICKEN.  We left very satisfied...oh yeah and the service is GREAT!!!
author: Maria B.

description:
4 stars for the food alone. but they've lost stars on service (not friendly) & it always seems cold in here.  our usual:

lunch:  great bbq beef & shrimps with rice noodles (very tastee)

dinner:  
starters:crisped turmeric scented rice flour crepe (light, refreshing with all the fixins -- mint, basil, lettuce, cucumber, carrots or chicken roll 

entree:  beef "look luck"/shaking beef -- the best i've had so far
lemongrass stir-fried chicken
garlic noodles (a bit oily, but i like the flavor)
pan fried thick rice noodles w/prawns & chicken (hub loves this one)
w/ jasmine rice of course

beverages:
guayabano shake (yummee -- don't know if they still serve this)

looks like they've changed some of their menu items  & they've changed/extended the names of some of their items, giving 'em longer names with more descriptive words -- would like to try the mango salad, cripsed garlic & black pepper calamari, clay pot garlic prawns, indochinese style salt & black pepper tiger prawns, wok seared sea scallops w/chives & mangoes.

parking sucks especially in the evenings.
author: Cindi N.

description: Le Soleil is a restaurant located in the Richmond district.  It's decor is very nice since they remodeled it a few years ago. The food is pretty good.  I usually order the Clay pot special.  The Grill pork ball and Imperial rolls are also very tasty.  For dessert, Fried banana with Ice Cream  is my  # 1 choice
author: norine h.

description: I like this place a lot when I'm not in the mood for greasy-spoon Vietnamese. The bomb: imperial rolls, pho soup, oxtail stew, and much more. Reasonable prices, friendly, and low-key.
author: Sumi Y.

description:
I have eaten here 3 times. The first time, I went with my mom because for some reason Burma Superstar was closed. My mom was PISSED because that is her favorite restaurant! So I had to do something quick to make her happy... I had never been to Le Soleil but the yelp reviews were decent and it was only a couple blocks from Burma.
We had the yellow curry coconut chicken, garlic noodles,  and veggie spring rolls. Each dish was really good and my mom (thankfully!) was also very happy with it.
I'm pretty sure she still wished that we got to eat at Burma Superstar but come on, Le Soleil had to have been pretty good if she was into it!
Minus one star because everytime I've eaten here the service has been on the slow side.
****************************************
UPDATE 08/04!
Last night we were waiting to eat at Burma Superstar and at 6:30  they said it would be a 45 minute wait. After an hour and 20 minutes there were still 13 parties ahead of us so we said "F--- it" and went to Le Soleil. I have upped it to 5 stars because the food was tastin' better than ever and  they were on top of their shit!!  Never ran outta water or white rice and everything was timed perfectly. It wasn't slow at all and it was pretty busy.
author: Jackie O.

description: I went back here after not having been for at least 4 years.  The food was still delicious and the service was pretty good.  They have since updated the entire restaurant and made it a little more modern/upscale.  I think they may have raised the prices along with the upgrade - it was still relatively inexpensive but not as cheap as I remember when I was on a Grad-student budget.
author: jane f.

description: I didn't know about this fancy vietnamese place, I feel like I've been missing out...it was a really good find, I enjoyed the food very much and the place is very homey.  I will return.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Had the garlic noodles, lotus roots w pork and shrimp salad, lemon chicken (although this is not a very special dish but they definitely did a good job!!), imperial rolls..... YUMMMMM You will be very satisfy after the meal and not feel you over ate.
author: Ervinna L.

description: My wife and I love the hot noodle soup for take-out.  Its always really fresh and tasty w/ nice accents.  Great food for a night in watching a movie.  Highly recommended!
author: Steve S.

description: Ok, I've only ever had the Pho and spring rolls. But they were both delicious. A nice place to take a first date out for dinner for something other than maybe Chinese or Korean, but not so "hole in the wall" pho that you wouldn't impress.
author: Jenny R.

description: Always walked by but never went in because it looked very pricey. One day I finally gave it a try and went in for lunch. Service was great and the food was really good and it wasnt as expensive as i thought it would be. i love the decor and the atmosphere, great for an intimate date. However, their dinner menu is a little pricier. Overall, cute little restaurant for a nice lunch!
author: Vivian D.

description: I tried this place several years ago when I didn't live in CA, my sister used to live nearby.  She asked me if I wanted to try catfish, no thank you.  But we did, and I liked.  The last time we were there in March, we ordered spring rolls, BBQ pork and lemongrass chicken.  All very satisfying.  The restaurant is pretty clean and service decent.  Next time you don't want to wait for Burma Superstar, give this place a shot, you won't be disappointed.
author: Casey F.

description:
Back when I lived in the outer outer Richmond, my boyfriend and I had dinner at Le Soleil with almost alarming regularity.  Parking was a bitch, but it was worth it just to stumble in past their giant fish tank at the entrance to breathe in the scent of their vegetarian hot and sour soup on a cold foggy night.  Then I moved to Berkeley, broke up with the boyfriend, and haven't had an excuse to go back in about six years.

Until Saturday night!  My friend Rico was in town from LA and looking for a quintessential SF dining experience, so in a burst of inspiration I suggested Le Soleil.  The decor has improved considerably in the intervening years (no more fish tank!), but the food hasn't changed a bit and is just as fantastic as it ever was.  We started with the aforementioned veggie hot and sour soup, and it came brimming with tomatoes, pineapple, and tofu in a richly aromatic broth.  Next up were vegetarian spring rolls and the Vietnamese vegetarian crepe, the latter delightfully light and crispy and stuffed full of mushrooms and bean sprouts.  That was actually plenty of food for me right there, but Rico and his friend Jim also ordered main courses of the pan fried rice noodles with prawns and the lemon grass beef, with rice on the side.  And then for dessert I insisted on splitting a fried banana drizzled with honey and accompanied by coconut ice cream. There were absolutely no complaints.  

I'm so happy that despite its face-lift the restaurant is the same old Le Soleil I loved back in the day.  I do miss that fish tank though.
author: Heidi D.

description: When I'm in the mood for white table cloth Vietnamese food - I eat here. So yummy - an awesome option when you're not in the mood to wait for Burma Super Star. Everything is good here: especially the Imperial Rolls and the Vietnamese Crepes!!! The Veggie curry is great too.
author: Julie L.

description: Fairly reasonably priced, if memory serves.  I recall their vegetarian spring rolls were delish.
author: Deb T.

description: I hadn't been here for a long time because a friend told me that when they remodeled the prices went up. I had lunch here a couple days ago and the prices seemed reasonable to me and I enjoyed the new decor. Love the imperial rolls and bbq pork meal. Sooo good.
author: m t.

description:
This is another great Vietnamese place on Clement St. in the RIchmond District.

It's a slightly upscale place, especially since they did a remodel in 2005 or 2006. My wife and I joked that they raised their prices because of the remodel, but hey, it might be connected.

Anyhow, the food's the thing, and it's got "it". I don't know exactly how they do it, but it's consistently good. Before Le Soleil, I wasn't a big fan of Vietnamese food. My wife would get me to go to the cheap Pho places, but those places don't compare to Le Soleil.

It's been a while since we've been back, but from what I remember just about everything we had was good. The beef look luck was tasty, the garlic noodles were noodly, and the service was good.

The only complaint is that maybe prices shouldn't have gone up as much as they did after the remodel. But that's a minor point.

It's in my top three for Vietnamese places in SF.
author: William S.

description: Scrumptious to say the least!  If you are a crepe lover, try their vegetable crepe.  Light crispy shell with sauteed vegetables.  I love the sprouts!  All around great fresh vietnamese dishes.  Their wine selection is pretty good too.
author: Diane V.

description: Reasonable and good food here. Good for lunch or dinner. Order the Catfish... crispy and so yummy for dinner. For lunch birdnest dish is ok, mild flavours, but curry chicken in excellent. Best part is the check......you will definitely be surprised given the quality of food
author: Sandy p.

description: We had a wonderful meal at le soleil last night.  The coconut soup was delicious and complex.  The appetizer platter was great: the meat was wonderful with a lovely grilled flavor.  The mixed vegetables were only so-so but the meat and green beans were also yummy though not as spicy as we excepted.  The decor was nice though the bathroom didn't feel completely finished.  The service was good.
author: Sesily M.

description: Le Soleil was really my first taste to Vietnamese food.  I remember not liking what I had the first time, but that was over two years ago.  I HIGHLY recommend going at lunch.  They have the most amazing vegetarian pho soup.  I also love to get their garlic shrimp with veggies and rice.  All on the lunch menu.  You can request these at dinner, but they'll charge you like a dollar more per item, which really isn't that bad.  Afterwards, head over to Genki and get a crepe!
author: Olivia S.

description: great iced coffee. the food looks to be WAY overpriced but i haven't tasted any of it so i can't tell you if it's worth it or not.
author: Regina C.

description: I had take out imperial rolls, lemon grass beef, potstickers, prawns wrapped in bacon and shrimp fried rice.  The food was all over cooked.  THe seasonings were just okay.  I don't get the hype....not sure what everyone else tasted...and no pho on the menu?   I never see people in there when I pass...that should have been my clue
author: Nikki W.

description: Another run of the mill Vietnamese place, with better service and ambiance. The food is decent, but that's pretty much it. They do have really good Vietnamese Coffee. Give it a try if you've tried most of the joints on Clement. Should be fine once in a while.
author: Tushar V.

description: The pan fried beef was delicious. It had just the right amount of spice to it, and the beef was infused with the great flavor...It reminded me of dishes that my mom cooks whenever I go home to visit. We also ordered the tofu and eggplant curry as well as a noodle dish. Both of them were nothing out of the ordinary. The tofu in the curry dish consisted of small deep fried tofu triangles, which wasn't the healthier option I had expected.
author: Carrie W.

description: There are no cooking geniuses here, but food is decent. Though I ponder if it would be better for the price. The yellow curry shrimp is good and the fried rice is decent. Again, you can probably find similar quality for the cheaper price across the street.
author: Sav B.

description: Tic toc, Tic toc... If you have 2 hours for lunch and 3 for dinner then this place is for you.  Horrendously slow, it's like they are moving in molasses.  Food is actually really good, but it takes 1 hour to get the first dish and another to get your water refilled.  I gave it an extra star for the Chilean sea bass.  Pho at lunch is good, but for some reason they don't have it on the dinner menu.  Don't expect to catch that movie after dinner though.  Much better Vietnamese places that take up a quarter of your time.
author: Darren I.

description:
This is one of those examples where I wish I could give no stars. 

I have to admit my culinary experiences have not been the same since I started watching Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares, I do analyze restaurants in ways that I never had before. But I feel if RKN came to SF this place would be a prime location for a show. 

We settled there because we were walking around Clement for some time trying to figure out where to eat, and out of sheer hunger we decided we'd give it a shot. I should have know when we noticed the place was completely empty on a Thursday night, besides one couple sitting in the back of the room, that this place was gonna bomb. And bomb it did. 

Getting back to RKN. Judging by the old newspaper clippings and various dated awards this place so proudly displays on the walls, this joint used to be pretty good.
