But the fact that the latest clipping on the wall was from 2000 should tell you something. I think this place must have lost it's chef or come under new ownership or something because the restaurants in the newspaper clippings, was not the restaurant I was in that night. 

It would be another classic episode.

Restaurant was good.... Something happened... Now, not so good. 

The customers start to dwindle and the place starts losing money. The chef has lost his passion and the owner is trying to hold on to the old reputation and still charge the high prices for food. Even though the quality has gone down because the chef has been cutting corners. So the customers dwindle more because the food they are receiving and the prices don't match up. So Gordon comes in and tries the garlic shrimp clay pot (like me). He realizes when it comes that he's just paid $17 for 2 whole shrimp with heads on and 1 shrimp with no head (that's right 3 shrimp, and not big ones either) in a broth that absolutely reeks of fish sauce. Then his lemon grass chicken comes and he is appalled by its flavorless, lifeless existence. Then he gets up from the table goes to kitchen and tells the chef "that food was absolute shit mate". Then he spends an hour (TV time) whipping the place into shape and giving customers value for their money. Alas, Le Soliel is back to its former glory (i think) and finally giving some competition to Burma Superstar and the Pizza place down the street. 

Nibb High Football RULES!!!!
author: Lawrence A.

description:
Food is good but not for the price. Ordered two things here for dinner

Egg vegetable seafood "crepe" Banh Xeo .    This is one of the better banh xeo's I've had in San Francisco, over $10 but almost worth it.

Sizzilng beef/ over fire was a disappointment.  It was like $18+; waiter came and lit the plate on fire to cook/heat the food inside the bowl.  It took him several minutes and I could see where the cost for the dish was from.  It was a pretty good show but.... it smelled like fuel which is not appetizing.  The taste just was not there.  I rather pay for taste over show.
author: Bob D.

description: The barbecued beef w/ rice noodles is HEAVEN!!!!!!!!!!  Most dishes are very good or better, I would go here every day if I could. Fast attentive service,  very nice place.
author: paula m.

description: Delicious food, service was only so-so.  The waiters were really nice, but they forgot to bring me my wine, and brought my entree out 15 minutes before my girlfriend's entree made it to the table.  I'd probably come back based on the food, but not if I'm in a hurry.
author: Rich C.

description: Super friendly wait staff serving top-notch exciting dishes.  The roasted pork rolls were moist and heavenly, and two beef dishes were sizzling, perfectly medium-spicy, and fresher than anywhere in recent memory.  The clay pot chicken fell flat, just too plain and too heavy on the 5-spice.  Not an impress-the-boss kinda evening but a solid neighborhood go-to.
author: elnora d.

description: I decided to give this place another try after insistent reassurances that it is indeed good.  It took some convincing because I have been here many years ago and was not impressed.  However, yesterday's dinner was surprisingly pretty satisfying.  My dining partner and I shared the egg drop soup that contained minimal crab meat, some asparagus, and corn.  The consistency was right, but I could do without the corn in the soup.  Then we had the beef and cucumber rolls, which were decent since I've had better elsewhere.  We also had the Vietnamese crepe that was prepared on point with a crispy, curry flavored exterior and the right ingredients inside.  Lastly, the roasted chicken in a clay pot was pretty good, but it lacked the ginger flavor that was advertised on the menu.  I liked that the menu was extensive but many of the selections seemed to be more of a Chinese influence than Vietnamese.
author: Linda P.

description: . Of course we tried Burma and B X. Anyway we finished trying Le Soleil. They were very trick with our pretend meal. We asked for garlic noodles with shrimp and we got a little amount of noodles with four shrimps.Fried rice with crab (just a bit of crab and rest rice), fried beef with greens beans(4 pieces of beef and the rest green beans and red chili). Very expensive and very trick.....Please make your money worth it. Go to Q, Burma,Clementine, Giorgio's etc....
author: Mia S.

description: I've been trying all the Pho places on Clement and went to Le Soleil last weekend. I've heard many wonderful things and my friend thinks it's the best Pho in the city. The prices are a little higher than other Pho restaurants but the interior and service are certainly a bit nicer. Although not a "fancy" place per se, a lot of Pho places have more of a cafeteria feel. The food was good, but I could not say that it was THE BEST Pho I've ever had, but it was good. The crispy imperial roll, however was excellent.
author: J B.

description: Oh how my bf and I wanted to really like this restaurant. We came here for a late lunch the other day. We've seen this place and have driven by so many times. I guess we had really high expectations for this place and thought that it would be like upscale Vietnamese cuisine. Why pay more for Vietnamese food if you can get something tastier down the street for a way better price?Not sure, but we thought that we would just try it. The decor in this restaurant is lovely, but that seems to be the only thing that they have going for them. We walked into the restaurant and waited for someone to acknowledge us. Took a bit, but I guess I was expecting too much? We were seated and were handed our menus. It was interesting that the menu was in English only. My bf wanted to order Bun Bo Hue, but we couldn't tell which item it was on the menu(depending on where you go, it's called something different in English), but if it was in Vietnamese we wouldn't have had a problem. I guess it didn't matter since my bf ordered in Vietnamese anyway. I ordered the lemon grass chicken over rice. My rice plate came out first. I was pleasantly surprised.... the chicken was really tasty, not dry at all and the green beans were cooked just right no soggy green beans I thoroughly enjoyed it, but...... the portion was way too small for the price, like I said earlier. I could get more and something that tastes better for a fraction of the cost down the street. Don't get me wrong, the plate was esthetically pleasing and the the rice plate was not absurdly expensive, but for the price somewhere else, I would've have more on my little plate. When my bf's bowl of Bun Bo Hue arrived, we were pleasantly surprised, but not in a good way. You know how when the Bun Bo Hue arrives and it's piping hot  with that spicy oil floating on the top of the broth? He had none of that going on, none at all. The broth was the blandest that I have ever tasted. He had to add a whole lot of hot sauce, but you know what that did? It just made the bowl of soup taste just like watery Sriracha. Very disappointing. The service was super slow. When he asked for the hot sauce, he waited and waited. I was practically done with my rice plate before the hot sauce came. Half the restaurant was filled, it was not super busy and there were also two waiters. All in all, I would probably not come back here again, not for the service or the food, which is too bad, since we both really wanted to like this restaurant.
author: carebear l.

description: First they are out of viognier which looked to be the only decent white on the menu and i'm told that they've been out of it for awhile (should have been the first clue).  The fried crepe was a decent app but after that, the "Wok Fried Sea Scallops" turned out to be a chinese sauced dish of mixed veggies w/ a smattering of small bay scallops (that had too much baking soda/flour agent, eeks) to the tune of $16.  The Large Mushroom and Tofu clay pot had only a few pitiful slices of mushroom pieces.  And where was the Vietnamese flavor in all of that?  Gone are the days of Dennis' flair for Vietnamese spices and French style cooking that made him infamous at the Taste of Asia Wine/Menu Tasting series is my guess.  And now in its place is overpriced chinese food ($70 for 2 ppl) disguised as vietnamese catering to a non-asian crowd.  I'm bummed!
author: Vivian C.

description: a nice vietnamese spot. i epsecially love the vietnamese coffee. plus its fun when someone orders food that requires the boiling pot to be placed on your table. if your in the area its always a good spot to bring friends for dinner. reasonably priced also
author: Andrew D.

description: The lunch plates are delicious and a real bargain. I have been coming to this place for years. I needed a Vietnamese restaurant with at least  some nod towards the health code...made the mistake of visiting the bathroom at Tu Lan once and could never get the nerve to return. Anyway, I digress. The food took a noticeable turn for the worse about two years ago but seems to have righted itself during a recent visit. Imperial rolls are awesome and once again have flavor; ditto the five spice chicken. Decor okay, but the skirts on the tables make it hard for me to get my legs under the table. It was a welcome remodel several years ago, when the place stopped being a dump thanks to new owners, but you got your money's worth and it's time to have tables more appropriate for sitting.
author: Christopher H.

description: this place makes the best vermicelli with vietnamese style bbq pork, and fried imperial rolls.  unlike a lot of vietnamese places in the tenderloin, the imperial rolls here come out fresh tasting instead of rancid (due to stale and overused oil in the fryer).  their rolls are also REALLY tightly packed, so they come out with a nice firm texture, instead of the oily, loosely packed rolls you get at most other places that end up falling apart.  their dinners are also outstanding.  i highly recommend the fish curry, the eggplant, the dry cooked green beans, and the vietnamese crepes (for lunch or dinner).  the crispy vietnamese crepes (made out of a mung bean batter, and infused with yummy coconut milk, and filled with sprouts, chicken, shrimp, and topped with fresh mint, et al are heavenly.
author: Curtis Y.

description: Had lunch here the other day with a friend and the food was very good. Lovely decor and the bathroom was clean (a good indication that a restaurant cares about the whole package, so to speak). I had the lemon chicken and it came with green beans which were excellent. The dessert was lovely too. The portions were plentiful and were tastefully presented. The service was attentive but not intrusive. I would definitely recommend Le Soleil to people, based on my experience alone. I was being treated to lunch so cannot accurately make a comment on pricing, although I did not think it was expensive when I first looked at the menu. Bon Appetite.
author: mary f.

description: consistently good inexpensive vietnamese...the best rolls in town. the last time I was there, it seemed the portions have gotten smaller, but it may just be me...or a bad night. it's worth trying when you are in the area...
author: Melissa A.

description: it seemed like we were waiting foreeeeever for our food, and when it came, it was lukewarm. i would give the food a 3 since it was tasty (albeit cold). service was a 2, for sure. slow and sparse. we could have walked out without paying and no one would have noticed for a good ten minutes.
author: eve l.

description: This was my first Vietnamese cuisine experience in SF a few years ago, back when they still had linen tablecloths and, apparently, good service.  The ambiance of the place has improved: polished wood seats, tempered glass tabletops, and nice flatware.  However, in a Yelp world where service makes all the difference, I was disappointed in that arena.  They have my favorite dish in the city, the sizzling seafood platter, so when we were seated and given menus, I hardly had to look at mine.  With 4 tables in the place and a guy in the back making eye contact with me the whole time, we had to wait 15 minutes before they came by to take our order.  Then the beverage guy started running from table to table filling up water glasses, spilling water all over the table in the process.  I might be able to forgive and forget if the place was even remotely busy but, unfortunately, that wasn't the case.  But that dish...oh that dish...yum yum goodness!!  Once the food arrived, I had practically forgotten the unpleasantness and entered culinary euphoria.  Fresh calamari, clams, and catfish, saturated in a to-die-for chili & cilantro sauce, sizzling, and massive to boot.  Fab, fab, fab : )  The bf settled on the catfish dish, which sounded healthy & light on the menu but came out fried and bland.  I felt bad for him because mine was so good and just as I was about to chalk all the bad service up as an off night, I bit into a piece of something extremely hard and so loud that the bf grimaced! The face I gave made him look down at his plate and say,  "I sense a scathing Yelp review".  I would write off this place if they didn't have the amazing dish and we know that sometimes the tummy has the final word, so I'll be back... to pick up my take-out!  And remember... Chew responsibly.
author: Tara G.

description: the mango salad is great but everything else i've had is rather disappointing. With so many amazing places on clement this shouldnt ben choice #1 (or #2 for that matter).
author: Genevieve H.

description: Lunch hour prices aren't that bad--it's good but not great Vietnamese food and while the inside looks nice, I wish they would turn the heat up in the winter. It's freezing inside!
author: nadines d.

description: I first ate dinner at Le Soleil in 1988.  I will be introducing new friends to it next week.  My family helped sponsor several Vietnamese refugee families (in Florida) in the 70's so I grew up eating Vietnamese food - with a French flare.  Do not be so naiive as to think there is only one style of Vietnamese food.  That is like saying southern cooking is "US cuisine."  The service if friendly and I have always been treated like family.  The Vietnamese-French fusion menu is delightful.  It has the subtlety and complexity of French colonial with the fresh, light touch of Vietnamese.  Their raw marinated beef is delicate and I love the crackle when you eat if with the rice crackers it is served with.  Their flaming bowls are succulent.  I also have always enjoyed the crab asparagus soup.  So, I live in Santa Cruz County and am going to drive to The City with friends to introduce them to this jewel on Clement.
author: Drew M.
